projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: OBSERVATIONS Hi≈øtorical and Genealogical: IN WHICH The Originals of the EMPEROR, KINGS, ELECTORS, And other the Sovereign Princes of Europe.
WITH A Series of their Births, Matches, more Remarkable Actions, and Deaths.
AS ALSO The Augmentations, Decrea≈øings, and Pretences of each Family, are drawn down to the Year MDCXC.
Written in Latin, by Anthony William Schowart, Hi≈øtory-Profe≈ø≈øor at Francfort:
And now made Engli≈øh; with ≈øome Enlargements relating to ENGLAND.
LONDON: Printed for J. Walthoe, in Vine Court, Middle-Temple, adjoyning to the Cloi≈øters. MDCXCIII.

div.head: To the much Honoured EDWARD SAYER, Of the Middle-Temple, E≈øq;
div.p: A Dedication, from its frequent u≈øage, is now grown, as it were, ≈øo ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary, that a Book without One, may be ≈øaid to be much in the ≈øame Circum≈øtances as a Child without a Parent to own it, or at lea≈øt a Godfather to an≈øwer for it: A Pre≈øcription for it may be pleaded beyond the Aera of Printing, even from the fir≈øt u≈øe of Letters, and the very Infancy of Learning: This may Warrant it in general, but my own many Obligations exact this publick way in particular of expre≈ø≈øing my grateful acknowledgments to you; which I mu≈øt confe≈øs, neverthele≈øs are at be≈øt, but a very un≈øuitable and indifferent Retribution.

I ≈øhall ≈øay little here in relation to this Alien, which I have ventur'd to Naturalize; nor of you whom I have cho≈øe to Patronize it. I am ≈øen≈øible, a true Gentleman bates a nau≈øeous piece of Flattery, and would not much care for a Recital even of tho≈øe mode≈øt Encomium's he is known to de≈øerve. If he may merit your E≈øteem, and the Book's Commendations may balance its Errors it will be a ≈øufficient Recompence and Satisfaction to the Tran≈ølator.
Such as it is, I have ventur'd to ≈øubmit it to Cen≈øure, reque≈øting your Protection and Patronage, which favour will ≈øtrictly engage me to be in the highe≈øt regard,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt Obliged, and mo≈øt Humble Servant, C. B.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
MEeting, ≈øometime ≈øince, with this Book in Latin, I thought it well worth my Money, did it but an≈øwer its Title Page; and finding my ≈øelf, upon the Peru≈øal, not much di≈øappointed, I re≈øolved to turn it into Engli≈øh, for the benefit of ≈øuch as might not, perhaps, under≈øtand the Latin; and yet be no le≈øs curious than my ≈øelf to be Inform'd of the Matters contained therein: Since, by being In≈øtructed in the Genealogies, the Matches, the Increments, and the Decrements of all the Families in Europe; together with the many Pretences that ari≈øe from thence, which is chiefly the Subject of the en≈øuing Di≈øcour≈øe, they will, (in all
probability) be the better enabled to judge of the different Intere≈øts which have engaged almo≈øt all the Princes of Europe in a War, the Event whereof ≈øo much concerns this Nation, and con≈øequently, is the general Topick of Di≈øcour≈øe.

I ≈øhall not here pretend to give an Account of the many Advantages which may be drawn from the Knowledge of Hi≈øtory; and how nece≈ø≈øary a Qualification 'tis for a Gentleman, ≈øince to ≈øay all One ought on that ≈øubject, would ≈øwell this Preface to a Bulk, di≈øproportionate to the Treati≈øe it ≈øelf, which pretends to no more than a Compendium.

Yet, ≈øince 'tis probable the Reader would gladly know ≈øomewhat of the Author thereof; the be≈øt account that can be given of him is from Him≈øelf and Book. In order to which, he lets you know, in his Epi≈øtle Dedicatory, That he is a Profe≈ø≈øor in the
Univer≈øity at Franckfort, and that the Book was the fir≈øt Fruits of his Office; It having been read as Lectures, or a Compendious Introduction to the Genealogy and Hi≈øtory of the pre≈øent Princes of Europe, for the benefit of the Students there, and ≈øince Printed, to be rendred more publickly u≈øeful. The Method he has taken herein is Ea≈øie and Plain; the Genealogical Ob≈øervations are exact; and the Hi≈øtorical as full of Matter as the nature of his de≈øign would bear: Not but that having laboured in a Soyl, capable of mighty Improvements, as to the la≈øt, if this fir≈øt Impre≈ø≈øion find that kind Reception as may be expected, it may incourage the Tran≈ølator, or ≈øome Other, to re≈øume the Work; and by engrafting on his Stock, bring the Growth to a greater Perfection; an E≈ø≈øay whereof you already have in the Engli≈øh Hou≈øe.

In the mean time, the Book, as it now ≈øtands, is of good U≈øe, and may merit a favourable Reception, as well from the mo≈øt Learned, as from the Ignorant: For altho' the former may be ≈øuppo≈øed to be already acquainted with what is contained herein, yet it will always ≈øerve them as a Summary or Common Place. And tho' the latter will not be rendered thorough-paced Hi≈øtorians hereby, yet will it give them a general In≈øight into the modern Story of Europe, together with a curio≈øity of being farther Informed.

There is one thing more, I thought fit to acquaint the Reader withal, which is, That in the Latin Copy, among≈øt King James the Second's Children, there is one mentioned and called, The Prince of Wales; but the late Licen≈øer, Mr. Bohun, having expunged Him, the Tran≈ølator could not, by the Warrant of the Latin Original, pre≈øume to in≈øert Him.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Genealogy of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria.
div.p:
¬ß. I. BEing to give a Genealogical Account of all the Soveraign Princes now flouri≈øhing in Europe, 'twill be but ju≈øt to begin with the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, as being of the Fir≈øt Dignity: Which as it owes its Original without doubt, to the Earls of Hab≈øburg; ≈øo in tracing the Pedigree of tho≈øe Earls, mo≈øt Genealogi≈øts are at a lo≈øs. As for us, we ≈øhall not doubt to derive 'em from the Counts of Mont-Aventine, of the Anician Perleonian Family, which was formerly of the greate≈øt Repute and Authority of any in Rome; and had its Seat on Mont-Aventine, being chiefly induc'd thereunto by the Arguments us'd by Pet. Lambechius, in his Comment. de Biblioth. Cae≈øar. lib. 2. c. 6. In the Twelfth Century there flouri≈øh'd in this Family, one Leo Anicius Perleonius, Count
of Mont-Aventine, who≈øe Epitaph may be read in Cardinal Baronius's Eccle≈øia≈øtical Annals, ad Annum MC XL. He was de≈øcended in a direct Line from the Emperour Flavius Anicius Olybrius; and in the Title to his Epitaph, is ≈øtyled, The most Noble of the Romans. His Son was Peter Leo Anicius Perleonius, Count of Mont-Aventine; who≈øe Epitaph may be likewi≈øe found in the ≈øame Eccle≈øia≈øtical Annals, Tom. 12. ad Annum MC XLIV. This Peter begat leo Maximus Anicius Perleonius, who died in 1162. witne≈øs his Epitaph, which may be ≈øeen to this day before St. Alexius his Church on Mont-Aventine in Rome, and is recited by Arnoldus Wion, in the Fir≈øt Part of his Lignum Vitae, ≈øive Hi≈øtor. Ord. Benedict. as likewi≈øe by Johan. Seifrid Abbot of Wethalen, in his Arbor Aniciana, lib. 1. c. 8. His Son was Albertus Dives Anicius Perleonius, who was driven out of Rome in 1144. by the Arnalda≈øtick Hereticks, together with his Brother Rudolph, in defence of the Roman See; whereupon he travell'd into Switzerland, and there married the Daughter of Wernerus, la≈øt Earl of Habsburg, of the Family of Altenburg; and by that means became the fir≈øt Earl of Habsburg, of the Anician Perleonian Race: See Abbot Seifrid. Loc. Cit. c. 12. and lib. 3. Epi≈øt. Dedicator. Whence this Wernerus drew his Extraction, the brevity of our pre≈øent De≈øign will not permit us to di≈øcour≈øe; tho≈øe that wou'd be inform'd in that particular, may con≈øult, among≈øt others, the famous Philip James Spenerus, in his Oper. Herald. lib. 1. c. 9. ¬ß. 62. 'Tis ≈øufficient for us to know, that Albertus Dives Anicius, was great Grandfather
to Rudolph, the fourth Earl of Habsburg, and fir≈øt German Emperour of the Anician Perleonian Family: See the Patent of the Emperour Rudolph, publi≈øh'd and cited by John Stumphius, in his Hi≈øt. Helv. lib. 7. c. 12. His Father was Albert, ≈øurnam'd The Wi≈øe, Earl of Habsburg; his Mother, Hedewig Counte≈øs of Kyburn; and his Grandfather, Rudolph, ≈øurnam'd The Silent, Son of Albertus Dives Anicius Perleonius Earl of Habsburg.

¬ß. II. Rudolph the Fir≈øt, whom we ≈øhall here ≈øet down as the Common Father of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, was born May 1. 1218. and brought up in the Court of the Emperour Frederick the Second: Afterwards made Lord High Mare≈øchal, in the Court of Ottocar King of Bohemia. Returning home, he enter'd on the Government of his own Hereditary Provinces, and had frequent Wars with his Neighbours. In 1273. he was cho≈øen Emperour, by the unanimous Con≈øent of the Princes of the Empire, and Crown'd the ≈øame Year at Aix la Chappelle: But when Ottocar King of Bohemia refus'd him Homage, he had a ≈øharp War with him to force him to it. Moreover, he freed Germany from Robbers; had Au≈øtria ≈øetled on his elde≈øt Son Albert, and Schwaben on Rudolph, in 1282. at a Dyet then held at Ausburg; introduc'd the u≈øe of the Teutonick, both in publick Acts and private Contracts; alienated the Cities of Florence, Genoua, and Luca, from the Empire, and declar'd 'em Free States: And la≈øt of all, ended his Days at Germer≈øhelm, July 15. 1291. having had fifteen Children by his Empre≈øs Anne, who
was Daughter to the Earl of Hohenberg. The Daughters were
1. Jutta, married to Wence≈ølaus King of Bobemia and Poland; decea≈øed 1292.
2. Clementia, to Charles Martell King of Hungary; decea≈øed 1295.
3. Maud, to Lewis Elector Palatine; decea≈øed 1304.
4. Margaret, to Diderick Earl of Cleves; by ≈øome omitted.
5. Agnes, to Albert the ≈øecond Duke of Saxony; decea≈øed 1311.
6. Hedewig, to Otho Marque≈øs of Brandenburg; decea≈øed 1303.
7. Catharine, to Otho Duke of Bavaria; decea≈øed 1285. And,
8. Euphemia, a profe≈øs'd Nun in the Au≈øtrian Covent, at Tolne.
Of the Male I≈ø≈øue, only three liv'd to be Men; viz.

list.item: 1. Albert the Fir≈øt, Archduke of Au≈øtria, born July 29. 1242. of whom more in the next Section.
2. Hartmanus, a Prince of excellent Endowments, but lo≈øt in pa≈ø≈øing the Rhine, as he was going to meet his Father, in the 18th Year of his A ‚Ä¢ e, An. 1280.

3. Rudolph the Second, Duke of Schwaben, who married Agnes, Daughter of Ottocar King of Bohemia, on whom he begot a po≈øthumous Son, named John; who proved afterwards the Murderer of his Uncle Albert the Emperour; for which he was thru≈øt into a Mona≈øtery, where he died, in 1313.

div.p:
¬ß. III. Thus we ≈øee how Albert the Fir≈øt, ≈øurnam'd Monoculus, from his having but one Eye, the other being lo≈øt by Poi≈øon in his youth, was the only Propagator of the Au≈øtrian Race; who having vanqui≈øh'd the Emperour, Adolph of Na≈ø≈øau, ≈øet the Imperial Diadem on his own Head. He had likewi≈øe good ≈øucce≈øs in his Wars with the Electors of the Rhine. His Empre≈øs was Elizabeth, the Duke of Carinthia and Earl of Tyrol and Goritia's Daughter, who bore him one and twenty Children: Neverthele≈øs he came to an unnatural Death, in the heighth of his Felicity, being kill'd by his Nephew John, May 1. 1308. His I≈ø≈øue that ≈øurvived, were
1. Agnes, married to Andrew the third King of Hungary, 1296. decea≈øed 1364.
2. Elizabeth, married to Fredereck the third Duke of Lorrain, in 1312. decea≈øed 1353. being the Mother of ≈øix and twenty Children.
3. Anne, married to Hermannus Marque≈øs of Brandenburg; and after his decea≈øe, to Henry the ≈øixth Duke of Bre≈ølaw: She died 1361.
4. Catharine, e≈øpou≈øed by the Emperour Henry of Luxenburg; but he being poi≈øoned in Iraly by a Monk, ≈øhe was afterwards married to Charles Duke of Calabria, Heir apparent to the Kingdom of Naples; and departed this life in 1324.
5. Gutta, married to Lewis the ≈øeventh Earl of Oetingen in Schwaben; decea≈øed 1328.
6. Rudolph, elected King of Bohemia; but died an untimely death, and without I≈ø≈øue, An. 1307.
7. Frederick the Fair, elected Emperour in 1314. and Crown'd by the Elector of Cologne: Neverthele≈øs, making War upon Lewis of Bavaria, who pretended to the ≈øame Dignity, he was defeated (An. 1324.) and impri≈øon'd by him for the ≈øpace of three Years; and then not ≈øet at liberty, but on condition he ≈øhould renounce all Preten≈øions to the Imperial Authority, retaining only the Title. He departed this life without Male I≈ø≈øue, in the Year 1330.
8. Leopold the Fir≈øt, Duke of Schwaben, Landtgrave of Al≈øace, Earl of Tyrol, &c. He attempted his Brother Frederick's relea≈øment by Magick; but in vain. He began a War with the Swi≈øs, but was likewi≈øe un≈øucce≈øsful in that. His Dutche≈øs was I≈øabel, Daughter to Amadeus Duke of Savoy, by whom he had only Daughters,
9. Henry, ≈øurnamed The Mild, decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue Male, in the Year 1327. having, in this the ≈øame fate with Frederick and Leopold.
10. Otho Duke of Stiria, ≈øtyled The Delight of his Subjects; who had two Wives, and by them two Sons; but both died in their Infancy. And,
11. Albert, ≈øurnamed The Wi≈øe, in who≈øe I≈ø≈øue alone the Au≈øtrian Family was pre≈øerv'd.

¬ß. IV. This Albert, quitting his Cloy≈øter, married the Lady Joan, ≈øole Heire≈øs to the Earldom of Pfirte: He likewi≈øe founded St. Stephen's Church at Vienna, and departed
this life in the Year 1338. leaving I≈ø≈øue,
1. Margaret, married to Mienhard Earl of Tyrol; and after his decea≈øe, to Otho Marque≈øs of Brandenburg.
2. Agnes, to Henry the ≈øecond Duke of Sile≈øia.
3. Catharine, profe≈øs'd a Nun.
4. Frederick the Second, kill'd by a chance Shot a Hunting, An. 1362.
5. Rudolph the Fourth, decea≈øed likewi≈øe without I≈ø≈øue.
6. Albert the Third, and la≈øt of all.
7. Leopold the Second, of whom more in the next Section.
Albert the Third, in the Divi≈øion of his Father's Inheritance 'twixt him and his Brother Leopold, had Au≈øtria, Stiria, and Carinthia for his Lot; in which he was ≈øucceeded by his Son
Albert the Fourth, ≈øurnam'd The Patient; who by Joan Daughter of Albert Duke of Bavaria, had

Albert he Fifth, a very fortunate Prince; who (not to mention his excellent Endowments of Mind) was, in the ≈øpace of one Year, inaugurated in the Bohemian, Hungarian, and Imperial Crowns, An. 1438. before which, the Marqui≈øate of Moravia had been given him in Dowry with his Wife Elizabeth, Daughter to the Emperour Sigi≈ømund, whom he ≈øucceeded in the Empire, by the Name of Albert the Second. He
was imbroil'd in a War with the Hu≈ø≈øites. Moreover, he undertook an Expedition again≈øt the Turks, to put a ≈øtop to their Inroads into Hungary; but was prevented by Death (which ≈øeized him in his Camp) and lies buried at Alba Regalis. After his death, the Empre≈øs was brought to bed of a po≈øthumous Son, named Uladi≈ølaus, who ≈øucceed him in the Kingdoms of Bohemia and Hungary; but died likewi≈øe an untimely Death, in 1457. in the ≈øeventeenth Year of his Age.

¬ß. V. Look we back therefore to Leopold the Second, who in the divi≈øion of Lands above-mention'd, 'twixt his Brother and him, obtain'd Schwaben and Al≈øace. He had ≈øharp Wars with the Swi≈øs, by whom his Army was routed, and him≈øelf ≈ølain, at the Battel of Sempach, An. 1386. His four Sons were,
1. William, a Prince of great Courage; decea≈øed Childle≈øs, 1406.
2. Leopold the Third, who had the ≈øame fate with his Brother, though married to Carathine Daughter of Philip the Bald, Duke of Burgundy.
3. Frederick the Third, who labour'd under many Hard≈øhips, by rea≈øon of Pope John the Two and twentieth: Upon who≈øe account he was excommunicated by the Council of Con≈øtance, and pro≈øcribed and outed of all his Territories, by the Emperour Sigi≈ømund. Neverthele≈øs, being again received to Grace, he was re-inve≈øted in
the Counties of Tyrol and Al≈øace, but cou'd never recover Schwaben. His fir≈øt Wife was Elizabeth, Daughter of the Emperour Rupert, by whom he had only a Daughter, of its Mother's Name, which died in its Infancy. But on his ≈øecond Dutche≈øs, which was Anne, Daughter of Frederick Duke of Brun≈øwick, he begat a Son, named Sigi≈ømund, a great Lover of Letters, thence ≈øtyled The Me ‚Ä¢ oenas of learned Men: Twice married, yet decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue.
4. Erne≈øtus Ferreus (or Iron≈øide) the only Propagater of the Au≈øtrian Race, married fir≈øt to Margaret, Daughter of Bole≈ølaus Duke of Pomerania; and then to Cimburg Daughter to the Duke of Mo≈øovie; which la≈øt bore him nine Children, whereof four at lea≈øt liv'd to be of Age; namely, margaret, married to Frederick the Second Elector of Saxony: Catharine, to Charles Marque≈øs of Baden. Frederick the Fourth: And Albert the Sixth, ≈øurnam'd The Prodigal, excommunicated and pro≈øcribed, as Author of ≈øeveral Tumults and Seditions. He died 1463.

¬ß. VI. Frederick the Fourth (but third Emperour of that Name) was elected Emperour in 1440. Crown'd at Aix la Chapelle, in 1442. and ten Years after at Rome, by Pope Nicholas the Fitch. He had Vienna taken from him by Matthias King of Hungary. In his Reign PRINTING was fir≈øt found out; the
League of Schwaben confirm'd; and Con≈øtantinople taken by the Turks. His Empre≈øs was Eleanor, Daughter to Edward King of Portugal, who bore him five Children, whereof Chri≈øtopher, John, and Helena died in their Infancy: The two that ≈øurviv'd, were Cunigunda, given in Marriage to Albert the Fourth Duke of Bavaria; and

Maximilian the Fir≈øt, in whom the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria was pre≈øerv'd, was born at Naples, in the Year 1459. From his Infancy he pronounc'd his Words with ≈øo much difficulty, that he was judged by mo≈øt little better than dumb; which Imperfection he ≈øo far ma≈øter'd in the end, that he became famous for his Eloquence. He was of a generous Di≈øpo≈øition, and a great Lover of learned Men. He was often under very dangerous Circum≈øtances; but always ≈øurmounted 'em happily in the end. In 1486. he was elected King of the Romans, his Father Frederick being yet alive. He refus'd to be Crown'd by the Pope; but pretended to the Papal Dignity him≈øelf. In ≈øhort, he magnified Ju≈øtice, loved Humility, exerci≈øed Clemency, and took much pains in ≈øearching out the Original of his Family. In his Reign the Reformation was ≈øet on foot by Luther; the Imperial Chamber in≈øtituted; the Empire divided into Circles; Vienna re≈øtor'd to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria; and Burgundy, and the Provinces of the Low Countries, annexed to the ≈øame Family. The Con≈øorts of his Bed and Fortunes were, Mary, Daughter and ≈øole Heire≈øs of Charles Duke of Burgundy; and after her, Blanche Mary, Daughter of Galeazzo Duke of Milan. By
the fir≈øt he had I≈ø≈øue, Margaret; who after many turns of Fortune, was in the end made Governe≈øs of the Netherlands; and died 1530. And Philip, a Prince worthy the noble≈øt Character, of whom more immediately in the next Section. As for Maximilian, being full of Days and Content, he piou≈øly and peaceably departed this Life, on the Twelfth of Jan. 1519.

¬ß. VII. Philip the Fir≈øt, ≈øtyled The Delight of Mankind, fir≈øt ≈øaw the Light, in 1478. At three Years old he was in≈øtalled Knight of the Golden Fleece: At ≈øeventeen, his Father gave him the Government of the Low Countries and Burgundy. In 1496. he married the Prince≈øs Johanna, elde≈øt Daughter and Heire≈øs of his Catholick Maje≈øty Ferdinand King of Spain; in who≈øe Right he became immediately po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of the Kingdoms of Arragon and Ca≈øtile: But he was not long to pre≈øide over ≈øo many and ≈øo great Provinces, being taken off by an untimely death, in the Year 1506. and the 28th. of his Age; neverthele≈øs, having fir≈øt ≈øeen him≈øelf Father of a fair I≈ø≈øue, by his mo≈øt beloved Con≈øort Queen Joan. The Daughters were,
1. Eleanor, married fir≈øt to Emanuel King of Portugal, and after his decea≈øe, to Francis the Fir≈øt, King of France.
2. I≈øabella, married to Chri≈øtianus the Second, King of Denmark, which prov'd a very unhappy Match. She died in the Low-Countries, An. 1525.
3. Margaret, married to Lewis the Infant, King of Hungary; and after his unhappy death, made Governe≈øs of the Netherlands.
4. Catharine, born after her Father's decea≈øe; betrothed to John Frederick Elector of Saxony; but afterwards married to John the Third, King of Portugal.

His Sons were, Charles the Fifth, and Ferdinand the Fir≈øt, betwixt which two Princes, there was a Divi≈øion of the Provinces; whence the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria became likewi≈øe divided into the Spani≈øh and German Lines. And fir≈øt for the Spani≈øh.

div.head: Of the Spani≈øh Line,
div.p:
¬ß. VIII. THe Author whereof was Charles the Fifth, born at Gaunt in Flanders, in 1500. At fourteen Years old he had the Government of the Netherlands given him; at ≈øixteen he was Crown'd King of Spain; at nineteen, elected Emperour, and Crown'd the Year following at Aix la Chapelle. In 1521. he held his fir≈øt Dyet at Wormes. He had very great Wars with Francis the Fir≈øt, King of France, whom he defeated and made Pri≈øoner, in the Year 1525. He likewife ≈øeized Rome, and be≈øieged the Pope in his Ca≈øtle there; and annexed the Dutchy of Milan for ever to his Hou≈øe. In 1532. at a Dyet then held at Ratisbonne, the Prote≈øtaut Confe≈ø≈øion of Faith was exhibited, and publickly read before him. Some Years after, he had Wars with the Prote≈øtants, wherein he took John Frederick Elector of
Saxony Pri≈øoner, in 1545. and thereupon transferred the Electoral Dignity from him, to Maurice Duke of Saxony. He likewi≈øe cau≈øed Philip Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, to be put in cu≈øtody; yet in the end concluded the Peace of Pa≈ø≈øaw with tho≈øe of that Religion, in 1552. Three Years after, he abdicated the Government, leaving the Empire to his Brother Ferdinand; and the Kingdom of Spain, with the Low-Countries, and its other Dependencies, to his Son Philip. After his Abdication, he retired to a Cloy≈øter in St. Ju≈øtus's Mona≈øtery in Spain; where, having ≈øpent about two or three Years, he piou≈øly and peaceably ended his days, 1558. leaving I≈ø≈øue by I≈øabel, Daughter of Emanuel King of Portugal, one Son and two Daughters; viz. Mary, married to the Emperour Maximilian the Second; Joanna, to John Infant of Portugal; and Philip the Second, of whom more in the next Section. Be≈øides the≈øe, he had one natural Daughter, named Margaret, begotten on Madamoi≈øelle de Plumbes, and married to Alexander de Medices, Duke of Urbin; and after his decea≈øe, to Octavio Farne≈ø≈øe, Duke of Parma: As al≈øo a Son, by Madamo≈øelle de Blomberg; namely, the mo≈øt Valiant and Renowned Hero, Don John of Au≈øtria.

¬ß. IX. But to return into our way: The only Heir of Charles the Fifth, was Philip the Second, born 1527. made King of Sicily and Naples 1543. King of England and Ireland in right of his Wife, 1554. Lord of the Low-Countries and Duke of Milan, 1555. and la≈øt of
all King of Spain, 1556. He obtain'd the famous Victory of St. Quintin over the French; but ≈øoon after, lo≈øt Calice to them. He was Author of the Spani≈øh Inqui≈øition. Moreover, he lo≈øt ≈øeven of the Low-Country Provinces; as al≈øo the famour Armada ≈øent again≈øt the Engli≈øh. In 1580. he overcame the Kingdom of Portugal, and by force of Arms cau≈øed him≈øelf to be Crown'd King thereof. His fir≈øt Queen was Mary, Daughter to John the Third, King of Portugal; his ≈øecond, another Mary, Daughter to Henry the Eighth, King of England, and then Queen of that Kingdom; his third, I≈øabella (or Elizabeth) a Daughter of Henry the Second's, King of France; and his fourth, Anne, Daughter of the Emperour Maximilian the Second. By the fir≈øt he had Prince Charles, born 1565. decea≈øed in Pri≈øon, 1568. By the third, I≈øabella Clara Eugenia, born 1566. married to Albert the Seventh of Au≈øtria; decea≈øed 1633. and Catharine, born 1567. and married to Charles Emanuel, Duke of Savoy, on the Eleventh of March, 1585. By the la≈øt, a Son of his own Name, viz.

Philip the Third, born 1578. in who≈øe I≈ø≈øue the Spani≈øh Line was continued: He ≈øucceeded his Father in his Kingdoms, in 1598. And in 1610. expelled nine hundred thou≈øand Moors and Jews out of Spain. His death bears date 1621. His Queen was Margaret, Daughter to Charles Archduke of Au≈øtria, who bore him eight Children, whereof three died in their Infancy. The re≈øt were,
1. Anna Maria Mauritia, married to Lewis the Thirteenth, King of France, 1615. decea≈øed July 3. 1640.
2. Mary Anne, married to the Emperour Ferdinand the Third, 1631. decea≈øed May 13. 1646.
3. Charles, a Prince of the Noble≈øt Vertues; but taken off by a too untimely Fate.
4. Ferdinand, Cardinal and Governour of the Netherlands; decea≈øed 1641. And,
5. Philip the Fourth, ≈øurnamed Dominicus Victor, ≈øucceeded his Father in 1621. and took on him the Government at the Age of ≈øixteen. He lo≈øt the American Plate-Fleet: He enter'd into a perpetual Alliance with the States of Holland: He concluded the Pyrenaean Peace with the French: And, in ≈øhort, was an unfortunate Prince, during the whole cour≈øe of his Reign. He had two Wives; Elizabeth, Daughter to Henry the Fourth, King of France, who bore him ≈øeven Children; but all of 'em either died young, or in their Infancy, except Maria There≈øia, married to Lewis the Fourteenth, the pre≈øent French King, in 1660. ≈øince decea≈øed, July 30. 1683. His ≈øecond Match was with Mary Anne, Daughter to the Emperour Ferdinand the Third; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Margaret There≈øia, married to Leopold the pre≈øent Emperour, in 1666. decea≈øed March 20. 1673. And,
2. Charles the Second, the pre≈øent King of Spain, born Nov. 6. 1661. who ≈øucceeded in that Kingdom, at the death of his Father Philip, in the Year 1665. In 1679. he took to Wife Mary Loui≈øe, Daughter of Philip Duke of Orleans; who dying without I≈ø≈øue in 1689. he, the ≈øame Year, married Mariae Anna, Daughter of Philip William Elector Palatine, the pre≈øent Queen. All which being thus fully explain'd, we now come to the German Line.

div.head: Of the German Line.
div.p:
¬ß. X. PRoceed we therefore to ≈øpeak of the other Son, of Philip the Fir≈øt, as Authose of the German Line. His Name was Ferdinand, born in Spain 1503. Crown'd King of Hungary and Bohemia in right of his Wife, 1527. Elected King of the Romans 1531. and Emperour in 1556. He had great Wars with the Turks, as al≈øo with the Prote≈øtants. He permitted the Bohemians to Communicate under both kinds. His Empre≈øs was Anne, Daughter to Uladi≈ølaus King of Hungary, Si≈øter to Lewis the Infant. The day of his death happen'd in the Year 1653. and ≈øixtieth of his Age, after he had had this following I≈ø≈øue:
1. Elizabeth, born 1526. married to Sigi≈ømund King of Poland, 1545.
2. maximilian, born Aug. 1. 1527.
3. Anne, born 1528. married to Albert the Fifth, Duke of Bavaria; decea≈øed Octob. 18. 1587.
4. Mary, born May 15. 1530. married to William Duke of Juliers, 1546. decea≈øed 1584,
5. Magdalen, profe≈øs'd a Nun.
6. Catharine, born Sept. 25. 1533. and married to Francis Duke of Mantua; and after his decea≈øe, to Sigi≈ømund Augu≈øtus King of Poland. She died 1572.
7. Ferdinand II. Archduke of Au≈øtria, born 1534.
8. Eleanor, born Nov. 2. 1534. She was married to William Duke of Mantua, and died 1604.
9. Margaret, another Nun; decea≈øed 1566.
10. John, born 1538. decea≈øed the Year after.
11. Barbara, born 1539. married to Alphon≈øo II. Duke of Ferrara, 1565. decea≈øed 1572.
12. Charles, born June 3. 1540.
13. Ur≈øula, decea≈øed an Infant.
14. Helena, who went into a Nunnery. And,
15. Joanna, born 1547. married to Francis Duke of Florence, 1565. decea≈øed 1578.

As for the three Sons, Maximilian, Ferdinand, and Charles, they had their Father's Territories divided among≈øt 'em; by which divi≈øion, Maximilian obtain'd Hungary, Bohemia, and Au≈øtria; Ferdinand had Tyrol and Al≈øace; and Charles Stiria and Carinthia. Of the≈øe we ≈øhall ≈øpeak a-part, in their proper places.

¬ß. XI. Maximilian II. was crown'd King of Bohemia Sept. 20. 1562. and of Hungary on Sept. 8. in the following Year. He was likewi≈øe
elected King of the Romans in the afore≈øaid Year 1562. and Emperour in 64. He was a pious, ju≈øt, peaceable Prince, and no great Enemy to the Prote≈øtants. He had Wars with Solyman Emperour of the Turks; brought Gunbrachius and his Complices to condign puni≈øhment; and did by no means approve of the Ma≈ø≈øacre at Paris. He departed this Life at Ratisbonne, having had fifteen Children by his Empre≈øs Mary, Daughter to Charles V. whereof ≈øix died young. The re≈øt were,
1. Anne, born 1549. married to Philip II. King of Spain, 1570. decea≈øed 1580.
2. Rudolph II. born June 18. 1552. who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Empire, Octob. 12 1576. and carried on the War with the Port. In 1595. he lo≈øt Raab; but it was recover'd three Years after, by Rudolph Count Swartzburg. In 1569. he lo≈øt Erla al≈øo Kani≈øa in 1600. and Gran in 1605. He died a Batchellor at Prague, Jan. 10. 1612 and left a va≈øt Trea≈øure behind him.
3. Erne≈øtus II. born June 15. 1553. And made Governour of the Low-Countries by the King of Spain, 1594. which Dignity he ≈øcarce enjoy'd a full Year, by rea≈øon of his death, which fell out ≈øoon after.
4. Elizabeth, born 1554 married to Charles IX King of France, 1570. decea≈øed June 2 1592.
5. Matthias, born 1557. who ≈øucceeded his Brother Rudolph in the Empire, being elected at Francfort, June 13. 1612. On Decemb. 4. 1611. he married Anne, Daughter to his Uncle Ferdinand Archduke of Au≈øtria;
neverthele≈øs, died without I≈ø≈øue 1619.
6. Maximilian III, born Octob. 12. 1558. In 1587. he was Crown'd King of Poland; but being afterwards defeated and impri≈øoned by the contrary Faction, was forced to quit his Preten≈øions to that Crown, to obtain his Liberty. In 1596. he fought a Battel with the Turks not far from Erla, where he was routed with his whole Army. He was al≈øo Grand Ma≈øter of the Teutonick Order; and died in 1620.
7. Albert VII. born Nov. 13. 1559. and created Cardinal of the Holy Cro≈øs; but quitting his Orders, was afterwards made Governour of the Netherlands by the King of Spain; and married I≈øabella Clara Eugenia, Daughter of Philip II. neverthele≈øs died without I≈ø≈øue, July 13. 1621.
8. Wence≈ølaus, Knight of Malta, born 1561. decea≈øed Nov. 7. 1578.
9. Margaret, a profe≈øs'd Nun; decea≈øed 1633. aged ≈øixty ≈øix.

¬ß. XII. The ≈øecond Son of Ferdinand I. Emperour, was Ferdinand II. as was already ob≈øerv'd; a Prince eminent for his Courage; who notwith≈øtanding he had many advantageous Matches offer'd him, refus'd 'em all, and married the Lady Philippina Wel≈øeriana, Daughter of Free Baron of Xinnenberg; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Andrew, Bi≈øhop of Bre≈øcia, and Cardinal; decea≈øed Nov. 11. 1600.
2. Charles, Marque≈øs of Burgovia, decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue 1618. notwith≈øtanding he had married the Prince≈øs Sibilla of Juliers.
3. Anne, married to the Emperour Matthias at Vienna, Decemb. 4. 1611. decea≈øed Decemb. 14. 1618.
4. Anne Catharine, a Nun. He had three Children more, but they died in their Infancy.

¬ß. XIII. Matters thus clear'd, we now proceed to ≈øpeak of Charles, third Son of the Emperour Ferdinand I. in who≈øe I≈ø≈øue the Au≈øtrian Family in Germany was pre≈øerv'd. In the divi≈øion of the Hereditary Provinces afore≈øaid, he had Stiria, Carinthia, and Carniola, for his Patrimony; and took to Wife Mary Daughter of Albert V. Duke of Bavaria, who bore him fifteen Children, who≈øe Names were as followeth:
1. Ferdinand, born and dead the ≈øame Year, viz. 1572.
2. Anne, born 1573. married to Sigi≈ømund King of Poland 1592. decea≈øed 1598.
3. Maria Chri≈øtina, born 1574. and married to Gabriel Bathor, Prince of Tran≈øylvania, 1595. but getting to be divorced from him, return'd home, became a Nun, and died 1621.
4. Catharina Renata, born 1576. decea≈øed a Maid 1595.
5. Elizabeth, born 1577. decea≈øed 1586.
6. Ferdinand III. born 1579. of whom more in the next Section.
7. Charles, born 1579. decea≈øed the Year after.
8. Gregoria Maximiliana, born 1581. contracted to Philip III. King of Spain, but died before the Marriage could be con≈øummated, 1597.
9. Eleanor, born 1582. She was profe≈øs'd a Nun, and died 1620.
10. Maximilian IV. a Prince of great Courage; born 1583. decea≈øed 1616.
11. Margaret, born 1584. married to Philip III. King of Spain, 1599, decea≈øed 1611.
12. Leopold IV. born Octob. 9. 1586. elected Bi≈øhop of Strasburg, and afterwards of Pa≈ø≈øaw, viz. 1607. But being rather of a Martial than Eccle≈øia≈øtical Temper, quitted his Orders, by a Di≈øpen≈øation' from the Pope 1626. took to Wife Claudia, Daughter of Ferdinand I. Grand Duke of Tu≈øcany, Frederick Ubald Duke of Urbin's Widow: and died 1632. leaving I≈ø≈øue,
1. I≈øabella Clara, born 1629. married to Charles III. the pre≈øent Duke of Mantua. 1640. decea≈øed 1685.
2. Ferdinand Charles, born 1628. In 1646. he married Anne, Daughter to Co≈ømus II. Duke of Florence; and died Decemb. 30. 1662. leaving I≈ø≈øue two Daughters; viz.
1. Claudia Felicitas, born May 30 1653. married to Leopold the now Emperour, Octob. 15. 1673. ≈øince dead, April 8. 1676.
2. Mary Magdalen, born 1656. decea≈øed 1669.
3. Sigi≈ømund Francis, born 1630. elected Bi≈øhop of Anopburg, 1640. promoted to a Red Hat, 1655. and Bi≈øhop of Trent four Years after. Neverthele≈øs, he quitted his Orders, by a Di≈øpen≈øation from his Holine≈øs; and de≈øign'd a Marriage with the Prince≈øs Mary Hedewig of the Palatinate; but died in 1662. before the con≈øummation thereof.
4. Maria Leopoldina, born 1632. married to the Emperour Ferdinand III. decea≈øed Aug. 9. 1649.
13. Con≈øtance, born 1588. married to Sigi≈ømund King of Poland, 1605. decea≈øed 1631.
14. Mary Magdalen, the Wife of Co≈ømus II. Great Duke of Tu≈øcany; born 1589. decea≈øed 1631. And,
15. Charles, born after his Father's decea≈øe, in the Year 1590. Elected Bi≈øhop of Bre≈ølaw in 1608. of Bre≈øcia in 1614. and a little after, Grand Ma≈øter of the Teutonick Order. He died 1625.

¬ß. XIV. We now return to Ferdinand III. according to our Promi≈øe in the la≈øt Section; Crown'd King of Bohemia, June 21. 1617. of Hungary 1618. and the Year following Elected and Crown'd Emperour (Aug. 30.) at Francfort, being the ≈øecond Emperour of this Name. In 1620. he ≈øuppre≈øs'd the Tumults then raging in Bohemia, by force of Arms: He al≈øo had Wars with the Prote≈øtants. The Year following he pro≈øcribed Frederick V. Elector Palatine, and beat him out of his Territories,
transferring at the ≈øame time the Electoral Dignity from him to Maximilian Duke of Bavaria. He was twice married; fir≈øt in 1600. to Mary Anne, Daughter of William V. Duke of Bavaria; and twenty two Years after, to Eleanor of Mantua, Duke Vincent's Daughter. By the fir≈øt he had two Daughters that lived to be of Age; viz.

list.item: 1. Mary Anne, married to Maximilian Elector of Bavaria; decea≈øed Septemb. 8. 1665. And,
2. Caecilia Renata, to Ca≈øimire King of Poland: She died March 13. 1644.

div.p: As al≈øo two Sons; viz.

list.item: 1. Ferdinand IV. born July 13. 1608. And,
2. Leopold William, born 1612. Elected Bi≈øhop of Strasburg and Pa≈ø≈øaw. In 1643. he was defeated by Tor≈øten≈øon at the Battel of Leip≈øick; and died Novemb. 10. 1661.

div.p:
¬ß. XV. Ferdinand IV. who ≈øucceeded in the Government of the Empire upon his Father's decea≈øe, was Crown'd King of Hungary in 1025. of Bohemia in 1627. of the Romans 1636. and la≈øt of all Emperour in 1637. by the Name of Ferdinand III. He carried on the War with the Swede. In 1639. he lo≈øt Bri≈øac: In 1648. he re≈øtor'd Peace to the Empire, by the In≈øtrument of the Peace of O≈ønaburg. He al≈øo made a Twenty Years Truce with the Turk; but a≈ø≈øi≈øted the Pole again≈øt the Swede. His fir≈øt Wife was Mary Anne, Daughter of Philip III. King of Spain, decea≈øed May 13. 1646. His ≈øecond, maria Leopoldina, Daughter to the Archduke Leopold V. And his third, Eleanora
Gonzaga, Daughter of Charles Duke of Mantua, whom he left a Widow, but ≈øince dead, 1686. Him≈øelf departed this Life April 2. 1657. having had I≈ø≈øue, by the Prince≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, as follows:
1. Ferdinand V. born Sept. 8. 1633. Crown'd King of Bohemia 1646. of Hungary 1647. of the Romans 1653. being the Fourth King of this Name; but died the next Year, which was the Twenty fir≈øt of his Age, to the great Grief of his Father and all good Men.
2. Mary Anne, born Octob. 12. 1634. married to Philip. IV. King of Spain, Nov. 7. 1649. The now Dowager of that Kingdom.
3. Philip Augu≈øtus, born 1637. decea≈øed 1639.
4. Maximilian Thomas, born 1638. decea≈øed the Year following.
5. Leopoldus Ignatius Franci≈øcus Baltha≈øar Jo≈øephus Felicianus, born June 9. 1640. of whom in the next Section.
6. Mary, born and dead the ≈øame Year, viz. 1646.
7. Charles Jo≈øeph Bi≈øhop of Pa≈ø≈øaw, Grand Ma≈øter of the Teutonick Order, and Bi≈øhop of Bre≈ølaw; born 1649. decea≈øed 1664.
8. Tere≈øa Maria Jo≈øepha, born 1652. decea≈øed the Year following.
9. Eleanor Mary, born May 21. 1653. In 1670. ≈øhe was married to Michael King of Poland; and after his decea≈øe, taken to Wife in 1678. by Charles late Duke of Larrain.
10. Mary Anne Jo≈øepha, born 1654. married to John William, Hereditary Prince Palatine, Octob. 15. 1678. decea≈øed April 7. 1689. And,
11. Ferdinand Aloi≈øius, born 1657. decea≈øed the Year following.

¬ß. XVI. Leopold VI. (but fir≈øt Emperour of the Name) the mo≈øt Invincible, mo≈øt Powerful, and, in one word, the mo≈øt happy Emperour of the Romans, was inaugurated King of Hungary at Presburg, June 27. 1655. Old Style; of Bohemia, at Prague, Aug. 2. 1656. and Emperour, at Francfort, July 22. 1658. having been elected on the 11th. He had War with the Turks from the Year 1661. to 64. at which time a Truce was made with 'em for Twenty Years; which not being well ob≈øerv'd by the Turks, the War broke out afre≈øh, which by the Divine A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, has prov'd (in a manner) fatal to the Ottoman Empire. He has al≈øo formerly had War with the French, before the breaking out of the pre≈øent. In 1666. he married Margaret Tere≈øa, Daughter of Philip IV. King of Spain, who died March 20. 1673. Whereupon he took to Wife Claudia Felicitas, Daughter to the Arckduke Ferdinand, Octob. 15. in the ≈øame Year: But ≈øhe likewi≈øe died, April 8. 1676. he proceeded to a third Choice; which was, Eleanora Magdalen Tere≈øa, elde≈øt Daughter of Philip William Duke of Neuburg, and Elector Palatine, married to him Jan. 6. 1677. (or Decemb. 14. 1676.) By the fir≈øt Venture he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Ferdinand Wence≈ølaus, born Sept. 28. 1667. decea≈øed Jan. 13. 1668.
2. Maria Antonia Jo≈øepha, born Jan. 18. 1669. and married to Maximilian Emanuel, Elector of Bavaria, 1686. (or 5.)
3. John, born and dead the ≈øame Year, viz. 1670. And,
4. Mariana Jo≈øepha, likewi≈øe born and decea≈øed the ≈øame Year, viz. 1672.
By the ≈øecond he had only two Daughters, both ≈øhort liv'd, viz.

list.item: 1. Anne Mary, born and dead the ≈øame Year, 1674. And,
2. Maria Jo≈øepha, born 1675. decea≈øed the Year following.

div.p:
But by the pre≈øent Empre≈øs,
1. Jo≈øeph James Ignatius John Antony Eu≈øtachius; the Joy and Hope of his Parents, born July 16. (O.S.) 1678. Crown'd King of Hungary 1688.
2. Mary Elizabeth Licia Tere≈øa Jo≈øepha, born Decemb. 13. 1680.
3. Leopold Jo≈øeph Philip William Francis Anthony Era≈ømus, born 1682. decea≈øed Aug. 4. 1684.
4. Mary Anne Jo≈øepha Antonia Regina, born Septemb. 7. 1683.
5. Mary Tere≈øa, born Aug. 22. 1684.
6. Charles Francis Jo≈øeph Wence≈ølaus Baltha≈øar John Anthony Ignatius, born Octob. 1. 1685. (O. S.)
7. Mary Jo≈øepha Collecta Antonia, born March 6. 1687. (O. S.) And,
8. Anne Jo≈øepha Antonia Magdalen Gabriele, March. 26. 1689. (O. S.)

div.head: Of the Augmentation of this Family.
div.p:
¬ß. XVII. 'TIs to be ob≈øerv'd of the Earls of Habsburg, That they were not ≈øimply ≈øuch, but Soveraign Princes al≈øo; an Argument whereof is, their having Noble men for their Ta≈øters and Cup-bearers. Moreover, about the time of Rudolph, they were po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of no le≈øs than eight ≈øeveral Counties, viz. Habsburg, Kyburg, Baden, Lentsburg, Thun, Reinsfelden, Ruppet≈øwiel, and Niddow; be≈øides the Landtgrave≈øhips (or Landtgraviates) of Al≈øace, Torgaw, and the Le≈ø≈øer Burgundy. See Spener's Oper. Herald. lib. 1. c. 9. Sect. 62. and Sigi≈ømund van Berken, &c. lib. 1. c. 5. pag. 37. Afterwards Rudolph, when he came to be Emperour in 1273. held a Dyet at Ausburg in 1282, where by the unanimous Con≈øent of the Princes of the Empire, he had Au≈øtria, Stiria, Vinidorum Marchia, and Carniola, ≈øetled on his elde≈øt Son Albert, as al≈øo Schwaben on Rudolph, as a Fee Farm of the Empire then void. In 1324. Albert II. had the County of Pfirte in Dowry with his Wife. In 1330. Lewis of Bavaria, the Emperour, mortgag'd Bri≈øac, Schaffhu≈øe, and Newenburg in Switzerland, to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, for Forty Thou≈øand Crowns; and three Years after, gave it the Dutchy of Carinthia, then without a Prince, to be held in Fee of the Empire. In 1363. this Family became po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of the County of Tyrol, by the Donation of Margaret Maulta≈øchen: And in 1366. it bought Freiburg in Brifgow for twelve thou≈øand Crowns. In 1373. Leopold II.
purcha≈øed the Earldom of Feldkirchen in Nebelgovia, for ≈øix and thirty thou≈øand Florens; as al≈øo Pludentz, Sargan, and Heiligenberg; and had the Government of Schwaben mortgag'd to him by the Emperour Wence≈ølaus. In 1456 the la≈øt Count of Cillei being ≈ølain, that County was claim'd by the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, as part of Stiria. In 1476 (or 7.) Maximilian I. by a Marriage with the Prince≈øs Mary, Daughter and ≈øole Heire≈øs of Charles the Hardy, la≈øt Duke of Burgundy, became in her right po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of the Earldom of Burgundy, (or Franche Comt√©) and the Seventeen Provinces of the Netherlands, together with a Right to the Dutchy of Burgundy. Three Years before this, Frederick his Father, the Emperour, had the County of Goritia, or Gortz, in Friuli, fell to him, together with the Cities of Grado, Ticect, and Zeng, on the Adriatick Sea, upon the death of the la≈øt Count thereof, and by right of Agreement to a mutual Succe≈ø≈øion 'twixt him and that Prince. In 1496. Philip I. married Johanna, ≈øole Daughter and Heire≈øs of Ferdinand King of Spain; and by that Match, annexed all Spain, the Kingdoms of Naples and Sicily, the I≈ølands of Sardinia, Majorca, Minorca, and Malta, to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria. In 1527. Ferdinand I. in right of his Wife, added the Kingdoms of Hungary and Bobemia, with all their Dependencies, to the ≈øame Family. In Charles V.'s Reign, there was an Acce≈ø≈øion of the Dutchy of Milan, as a Fief of the Empire then void. In 1580. Philip II. partly in pretended right of his Wife, and partly by right of Inheritance from his Mother I≈øabella but chiefty by force of Arms,
po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd him≈øelf of Portugal; as al≈øo whatever el≈øe the Portugue≈øe then held, either in the Ea≈øt-Indies, or Atlantick Sea. Ferdinand the Second Emperour of the Name, wholly reduced the Kingdom of Bohemia, together with Moravia, Sile≈øia, and Lu≈øatia. Jo≈øeph I. was made King of Hungary, by right of Inheritance on the Ninth of December, 1687. whereas 'till then that Kingdom had been Elective. But more than this, the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria has, for many Ages now pa≈øt, enjoy'd the Imperial Dignity; which (indeed) can be transferred from it to no other, without apparent danger to the whole Empire. It is al≈øo in ≈øome expectance of the Dutchy of Wirtenburg's falling to it. See Layritz Palmwald, pag. 477.

div.head: Of its Lo≈ø≈øes, or Decrea≈øe.
div.p:
¬ß. XVIII. OF the Cities and Provinces above-mention'd, many have again been lo≈øt by this Family, through the injury of Time. And indeed the fir≈øt Lo≈øs ≈øuffer'd by it, was in the Fourteenth Century; at which time, the Counties of Habsburg, Baden, and Kiburg, were taken from it, by the pro≈øperous Succe≈øs of the Arms of the Swi≈øs. In 1415. by rea≈øon of the pro≈øcription of Frederick III. (mention'd by us Sect. V. Numb. 3.) it lo≈øt the whole Dutchy of Schwaben, except ≈øome few places; namely, the Marqui≈øate of Burgow, the Counties of Hellenburg, Hochbergen, Chingen, Schelcflingen, and the Provincial Government of Schwaben; which Countries it ≈øtands ≈øtill po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of in that Dutchy. In 1472. the
Dutchy of Cro≈ø≈øen in Sile≈øia was mortgag'd to the Family of Brandenburg; and not being redeem'd in due time, Joachim I. became fully po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of it, by an indi≈øputable Title, in the Year 1538. In 1501. Schaffbu≈øe was given up to the Swi≈øs. In 1529. (or 92 rather) and the Years following, the Turks took many Places in Hungary; but mo≈øt of 'em re-taken ≈øome time after. In 1572. and in the Years following, ≈øeven Provinces of the Netherlands withdrew their Allegiance from the Crown of Spain; and ≈øince that, down to the pre≈øent times, the French have made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of great part of the re≈øt. In 1640. Portugal revolted, and ≈øet up a King of its own: Whereupon Goa likewi≈øe, and the other Provinces in the Ea≈øt-Indies, rejected the Spani≈øh Yoak. In 1648. all Al≈øace was ≈øet over to the French: See the In≈øtrument of the Treaty of Peace at O≈øenburg, concluded 'twixt the Emperour and French King. Sect. Drittens Thun, &c. In the ≈øame Year Bri≈øac and Suntgaw were put into the hands of the French. In 1659. the French obtain'd great part of the Spani≈øh Netherlands by the Pyrenaean Peace: See the 35th. and following Articles. By the Treaty of Nimeguen, 1678. Friburgh was given up to the French; as al≈øo the County of Burgundy (or Franche Comt√©) together with whatever el≈øe as yet remained in Artois. In 1684 the French, by force of Arms, made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the Dutchy of Luxenburg: as well as of the City of the ≈øame Name. In 1686. the Principality of Swibu≈øe, together with the City of that Name, was, by an amicable Accommodation, deliver'd
up to the Elector of Brandenburg. La≈øt of all, the French King breaking the Truce, took Philipsburg on the Rhine from this Family, Nov. 1. 1688. O. S.

div.head: Of its Preten≈øions.
div.p: ¬ß. XIX. THe Preten≈øions of the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, are, (1.) To the Dutchy of Burgundy, which appertain'd of right to Maximilian I. as having married Mary, Daughter and ≈øole Heire≈øs of Burgundy; but the then King of France refus'd to inve≈øt him, on pretence of the Salique Law. (2.) To Tran≈øylvania, Moldavia, Walachia, and Bulgaria, as Dependencies of the Kingdom of Hungary. (3.) To the Counties of Habsburg, Baden, and Kiburg. (4.) To the City of Schaffbu≈øe. (5.) To the Kingdom of Portugal, as having actually revolted from that of Spain. (6.) To the Dutchy of Luxenburg. And la≈øtly, To the City and Ca≈øtle of Philipsburg.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Hou≈øe of France.
div.p:
¬ß. I. TO find out the Ri≈øe of the pre≈øent Hou≈øe of France, we are to look back as far as Hugh the Great, Duke of France, Burgundy, and Aquitain, Marque≈øs of Orleans, and Earl of Paris; decea≈øed 956. His elde≈øt Son was Hugh Capet, Duke of France, Marque≈øs of Orleans, and Count of Paris, who, upon the death of Lewis the Slothful, la≈øt King of France, of the Race of Charlemaigne, was, by the unanimous Con≈øent of the Peers of France, inaugurated King of that Kingdom, An. 987. And his Son Robert being in the ≈øame Year declared his Succe≈ø≈øor, united the afore≈øaid Provinces to the Crown. His Queen was Aloi≈øia, Daughter of William Duke of Aquitain, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Robert afore≈øaid; from his great Piety ≈øurnamed The Saint, who ≈øucceeded in the Throne of France, upon the death of his Father, in the Year 998. He was al≈øo Heir to the Dutchy of Burgundy, upon his Uncle Henry's decea≈øe; and departed this Life him≈øelf in 1031. having had two Queens, viz. Bertha, Daughter of Conrade King of Burgundy; and Con≈øtance, Daughter of William Count of Arles and Provence: And by then two Sons; namely,
1. Henry, of whom more in the next Section. And,
2. Robert, Propagator of the Line of Burgundy, the which became extinct in Philip Duke of Burgundy, An. 1361. And whereas it had ≈øpread it ≈øelf into two le≈ø≈øer Branches, viz. that of Montaigue, and that of Vienne, or Dauphin√©; yet the fir≈øt fail'd in Claudius de Montaigue, An. 1468. the other in Humbert II. 1358. who ≈øeeing him≈øelf de≈øtitute of I≈ø≈øue, made over Dauphin√© to Philip of Valois, King of France, for 40000 Florins; and on condition, That for the future, the elde≈øt Son of France ≈øhould be ≈øtyled, The Dauphin.

¬ß. II. Return we now to Henry I. Crown'd King of France 1031. The beginning of who≈øe Reign was made unea≈øie by his Mother; for ≈øhe being de≈øirous to advance his Brother Robert to the Throne, ≈øtirred up many of the Nobility again≈øt him: But the Bu≈øine≈øs being decided by a Battel, the Victory fell to the ju≈øter ≈øide. His Death bears date 1060. And his I≈ø≈øue by Agnes, Daughter of Ba≈øilius King of Ru≈ø≈øia, were,
1. Philip I. And,
2. Hugh, Count de Vermandois, de Valois, de Chaumont, and d'Amiens; who≈øe Po≈øterity fail'd in Rudolph II. Count de Vermandois, &c. An. 1158.

Philip ≈øucceeded his Father at the age of nine Years, and was Crown'd King of France An. 1060. His fir≈øt Queen was Bertha, Daughter of Florence I. Earl of Holland, whom he divorc'd in 1093. and married Bertrada, Daughter
to Simon Earl of Montfort. By the fir≈øt be had,
1. Lewis VI. (but fir≈øt of this Line) ≈øurnam'd The Gro≈øs; born 1081.
2. Henry, decea≈øed an Infant.
3. Con≈øtance, married to Hugh Earl of Champaigne; and after his decea≈øe, to Boemund Prince of Antioch.

By the ≈øecond,
1. Philip, Count de Mans, who married Elizabeth, Daughter of Guy the ≈øecond Baron of Mont le Herry; but died without I≈ø≈øue.
2. Florus, Father of Elizabeth of Nantes.
3. Caecilia, married fir≈øt to Tancred Prince of Antioch; and after his decea≈øe, to Pontius of Tholou≈øe, Count of Tripoli in Syria. And,
4. Eu≈øtachia, e≈øpou≈øed to John, Count d'E≈øtampes.

Of the≈øe, Lewis ≈øucceeded his Father at his decea≈øe; and was Crown'd King of France in the Year 1108. His Queen's Name was Adelain, Daughter of Humbert II. Duke of Savoy, who bore him this following I≈ø≈øue:
1. Philip, decea≈øed ≈øixteen Years old.
2. Lewis VII. born 1119. of whom in the next Section.
3. Henry, Archbi≈øhop of Reims.
4. Robert III. Count de Dreux, who≈øe Po≈øterity became extinct in John, An. 1590.
5 Philip, Archdeacon of Paris; decea≈øed 1164.
6 Peter, Baron (or Lord) of Courtnay, who≈øe Po≈øterity fail'd in Stephen de Raviers, An. 1383.
7. Hugh, decea≈øed in his Infancy. And,
8. Con≈øtance, married to Raymund Earl of Tholou≈øe.

¬ß. III. Lewis VII. ≈øurnam'd The Younger, was born in 1119. and Crown'd King of France 1131. His fir≈øt Queen was Eleanor, Daughter and Heire≈øs of William Duke of Aquitain, whom he divorc'd in 1152. After which, ≈øhe was married to Henry Duke of Normandy; who coming afterwards to be King of England, did grievou≈øly annoy the French King. His ≈øecond was Con≈øtance, Daughter to Alphon≈øo VIII. King of Ca≈øtile, who died in 1159. And his third Alice, Daughter of Theobald Earl of Chambagne, whom he married in 1161. She died 1205. By the fir≈øt he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Mary, married to Henry Count de Champagne: She died 1179. And,
2. Alice, married to Theobald Earl of Chartres and Blois.
By the ≈øecond only a Daughter, named

Margaret, married to Henry, elde≈øt Son of Henry II. King of England, and after his decea≈øe, to Bela III. King of Hungary, whom ≈øhe likewi≈øe out-liv'd, and went in Pilgrimage to the Holy Land, in the City of Acres, An. 1198.

By by the third,
1. Philip II. ≈øurnamed Augu≈øtus, born Aug. 22. 1166.
2. Alice, married to William Count de Ponthieu. And,
3. Agnes, given in marriage to Comenius Alexius, Emperour of Con≈øtantinople, 1180. and after his death, to Theodore Branas, Lord of Adrianople.

Philip II.'s Inauguration to the Crown of France, was Nov. 1. 1179. This Prince very much enlarged both the Power and Patrimony of the Crown of France; for having overcome John ≈øans Terre (or Lack-land) King of England, he brought Normandy, Bretagne, Anjon, Touraine, Poictiers, Clermont, and part of Aquitain, under his Juri≈ødiction. His fir≈øt Queen was I≈øabella, Daughter of Baldwin IV. Earl of Haynault; after who≈øe decea≈øe, he married Ingeburg, Daughter of Waldemar King of Denmark; but being afterwards divorc'd from her, proceeded to a third Choice, which was the Lady Agnes, Daughter of Berthold Duke of ‚Äî By the fir≈øt he had I≈ø≈øue only
Lewis VIII. born 1187. of whom in the next Section.

But by the third,
1. Philip, Earl of Bologne, Clermont, &c. who by Maud, Daughter of Reginald Earl of Dammarlin, had I≈ø≈øue a Daughter named Joan: and married to Scaevola de Ch√¢tillon.
2. Mary, after the decea≈øe of her fir≈øt Husband Philip of Haynault, Earl of Namur, re-married to Henry IV. Duke of Brabant: She died 1238.

¬ß. IV. Lewis VIII. was Crown'd King of France in 1224. having before this been elected, and had Fealty ≈øolemnly ≈øworn him, as King of England, by the Nobility of that Kingdom,
at London, An. 1216. But the Engli≈øh, upon the death of King John, changed their Minds, and return'd to their Allegiance to the young King Henry III. Whereupon de≈øpi≈øing the Natural INCONSTANCY of that Nation, he return'd for France. Nor was he long to govern that Realm, being taken off by an untimely death, in the Year 1226. His Queen's Name was Blanche, Daughter of Alphon≈øo IX. King of Ca≈øtile; by whom he had nine Children, whereof five died young. The four that out-liv'd him were,
1. Lewis IX. ≈øurnam'd The Saint; born April. 25. 1215.
2. Robert Earl of Artois; which Branch of the Family, wither'd in Charles d'Artois, Count d'Eu, in the Year 1472.
3. Charles, Earl of Anjou and Main, born 1220 Crown'd King of both the Sicily's in 1266. or 63. and Titular King of Jeru≈øalem ten Years after. His Po≈øterity reign'd in the Kingdom of Naples, 'till 1435. in Hungary 'till 1325. and in Poland 'till 1400.
4. Alphon≈øo, married indeed, yet decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue. As for Queen I≈øabella their Mother, ≈øhe ended her Life in a Cloy≈øter, where ≈øhe retired after the King her Husband's death.

Lewis IX. was Crown'd King of France in the Year 1226. and very much improv'd the Deme≈ønes of the Crown. He took upon him the Croi≈øade, and made an Expedition to the Holy Land; in which War, he was taken Pri≈øoner by the Sarazens, after the City of Damieta had ≈øurrender'd to him: But being ran≈øom'd
by his Subjects, return'd home. After this, he ventur'd on a ≈øecond Expedition, but died of the Plague at the Siege of Tunis, An. 1270. His Queen was margaret, Daughter of Reimund Berengarius Earl of Provence, who departed this life 1285. having born him this following I≈ø≈øue:
1. I≈øabella, born 1241. married to Theobald II. King of Navarr, decea≈øed 1275.
2. Lewis, who took to Wife Berengaria, Daughter of Alphon≈øo X. King of Ca≈øtile; yet died without I≈ø≈øue 1275.
3. Philip III. ≈øurnam'd the Bold, born 1245. of whom in the next Section.
4. John, Earl of Nevers and Valois; decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue 1270.
5. Blanche, married to Ferdinand Prince of Ca≈øtile; decea≈øed 1320.
6. Peter, Count d'Alen√ßon and Chartres; decea≈øed I≈ø≈øuele≈øs 1283.
7. Robert V. Count de Clermont, and Lord of Bourbon, of whom more beneath in the Line of Bourbon, Sect. XII. as Ance≈øtor in a direct Line of the pre≈øent French King.

¬ß. V. Philip III. ≈øurnam'd the Bold, was Crown'd King of France in 1271. A Prince very deficient in mo≈øt of cho≈øe Vertues that ≈øhould adorn a King; given to drink, and ea≈øily led by tho≈øe that were about him. Surnam'd The Bold, not from any true Courage that was eminent in him; but becau≈øe in that fo≈øtne≈øs of Mind, he would yet bruti≈øhly expo≈øe him≈øelf to the greate≈øt Dangers in time of Action.
His fir≈øt Queen was I≈øabella, Daughter of James I. King of Arragon, who died in 1271. after which, he married Mary, Daughter to Henry III. Duke of Brabant; and departed this Life 1285. The I≈ø≈øue that ≈øurvived were,
1. Philip IV. ≈øurnam'd The Fair; born 1268.
2. Charles, Earl of Valois, Anjou, &c. of whom in the next Section, as Author and Propagator of the Line of Valois.
3. Lewis, Count d'Eureux, who≈øe Po≈øterity became extinct in Charles III. King of Navarr, An. 1416.
4. Margaret, married to Edward I. King of England, in 1300. or 1. And,
5. Blanche, to Rudolph of Au≈øtria in the ≈øame Year. She died 1305.

Of the≈øe, Philip the Fair ≈øucceeded his Father, and was Crown'd King of France in the Year 1286. He join'd the Kingdom of Navarr to that of France; which Kingdom was brought him in Marriage by his Wife Joan, together with the County of Aquitain, and Territory of Brigen. He had a ≈øharp War with the Flemings, by whom his Forces were utterly defeated, at the famous Battel of Courtray. He had al≈øo ≈øeveral Conte≈øts with the Pope, to whom he return'd the famous An≈øwer of, Sciat tua Magna Fatuitas, Nos in Temporalibus nemini ≈øube≈ø≈øe, upon his Holine≈øs's pretending to command and direct him in ≈øome ≈øecular Affairs. Moreover, the Order of Knights Templars was fir≈øt aboli≈øh'd, by his Example and Intere≈øt, throughout Chri≈øtendom, in the Year 1311. or 7. His I≈ø≈øue, nece≈ø≈øary to be here mention'd, were,
1. Lewis X. ≈øurnam'd Hutin, King of France and Navarr; born 1280. Crown'd 1315, or 14. decea≈øed (and that without I≈ø≈øue Male) 1316.
2. Philip V. ≈øurnam'd The Long, King of France and Navarr; born 1292. Crown'd 1317. or 6. decea≈øed likewi≈øe without I≈ø≈øue Male, 1321. or 2.
3. Charles IV. ≈øurnam'd The Fair, King of France and Navarr, who had the ≈øame fate with his Brethren; for he died in 1327/8. leaving his Wife with Child, which likewi≈øe prov'd a Daughter.
4. I≈øabella, married at twelve Years old, to Edward II. King of England, Jan. 28. 1307. O. S. decea≈øed 1375.

div.head: Of the Line of Valois.
div.p:
¬ß. VI. WE now return to Charles Count de Valois, d'Anjou, du Main, d'Alen√ßon, and du Perche, ≈øecond Son to Philip the Bold. He was thrice married, his fir≈øt Wife being Margaret, Daughter of Charles II. King of Sicily: His ≈øecond, Catharine de Courtney, Daughter of the Emperour of Con≈øtantinople: And his third, Maud, Daughter of Guy de Ch√¢tillon, Count de St. Paul, who died 1358. By the≈øe he had I≈ø≈øue, as followeth:
1. I≈øabella, married to John III. Duke of Bretagne; decea≈øed 1309.
2. Joan, the Wife of William the Good, Earl of Haynault, Holland, and Zealand: She died in the Year 1400.
3. Philip VI. of whom in the next Section.
4. Charles Count d'Alen√ßon and de Chartres who≈øe Po≈øterity became extinct in Charles Duke d'Alen√ßon, in the Year 1512.
5. Margarct, married to Guy de Ch√¢tillon, Earl of Blois.
6. Catharine, to Charles of Sicily, Earl of Tarento.
7. Joan, to Robert of Artois, Earl of Beaumont: She died 1363.
8. Lewis, Earl of Chartres; decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue, An. 1328.
9. I≈øabella, Lady Abbe≈øs of Fonteverard.
10. Mary, married to Charles of Sicily, Duke of Calabria.
11. Another I≈øabel, married to Peter I. Duke of Bourbon. And,
12. Blanche, to the Emperour Charles IV. She died 1345.

¬ß. VII. Wherefore after the decea≈øe of the three Brethren, Lewis Hutin, Philip the Long, and Charles the Fair, without I≈ø≈øue Male, the Government was ≈øetled on Philip de Valois, their Cou≈øin-Germain, notwith≈øtanding the Claim of Edward III. King of England, Son to I≈øabel, elde≈øt Si≈øter of the three la≈øt Kings, who≈øe Preten≈øions (as the French ≈øaid) were cut off by the Salique Law. Neverthele≈øs, it was ≈øoon after the occa≈øion of a bloody War 'twixt him and King Philip: Who≈øe two Wives, were Joan Daughter of Robert II. Duke of Burgundy; decea≈øed 1348. and Blanche, Daughter of Philip King of Navarr, who died 1398. By the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ he had I≈ø≈øue,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
1. John I. ≈øurnam'd The Good.
2. Philip, Duke of Orleans, decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue.
3. Mary, married to John of Brabant, Duke of Limburg: She died 1333.
4. Joan, a po≈øthumous Daughter, betrothed to John of Arragon, Duke of Gironda (or Girona) but died before the Marriage cou'd be con≈øummated, An. 1371.

Of the≈øe, John ≈øucceeded to the Throne, and was Crown'd in 1350. This Prince continu'd the War with the Engli≈øh; but with no better ≈øucce≈øs than his Father had done; for he was defeated, and taken Pri≈øoner by them at the Battel of Poictiers, Sept. 19. 1356. O.S. Being again ≈øet at liberty, he departed this Life in 1361/4. aged fifty ≈øix. His two Queens were Bona, Daughter of the King of Bohemia: And Joan, of William Earl of Clermont. By the fir≈øt Venture, this following I≈ø≈øue liv'd to be Men and Women:
1. Charles V. ≈øurnam'd The Wi≈øe; born Jan. 21. 1337. of whom in the next Section.
2. Lewis, Duke of Anjou and Touraine; Crown'd King of Sicily on this ≈øide the Pharus (or Watch-Tower) in 1382. who≈øe Po≈øterity fail'd in Nicholas Duke of Calabria, An. 1473.
3. Philip, Duke of Burgundy, born 1341. who≈øe Po≈øterity ended in Mary, la≈øt Heire≈øs of that Dutchy, An. 1483.
4. Joan, married to Charles III. King of Navarre; decea≈øed 1373.
5. I≈øabella, to John Galeazzo Duke of Milan, in 1360. And,
6. John, Duke of Berry; he decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue 1416.
7. Margaret, profe≈øs'd a Nun.

¬ß. VIII. Charles V. ≈øurnam'd The Wi≈øe, was Crown'd King of France, May 19. 1364. He was the fir≈øt who in his Father's Life time was ≈øtyled, The Dauphin. He re≈øtored the Commonwealth of France, and repre≈ø≈øed the Violence of its Enemies; which he brought to pa≈øs more by Coun≈øel and Delays, than force of Arms. He al≈øo put forth a Sanction, whereby the elde≈øt Sons of France, were for the future declar'd of Age at Fourteen Years old, and fit to be Crown'd and Govern. His Queen's Name was Joan, Daughter of Peter I. Duke of Bourbon; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue that out-liv'd him,
1. Charles VI. born 1368. his Succe≈ø≈øor.
2. Lewis, Duke of Orleans, Count de Valois, d'Angouleme, &c. born 1371. of whom in Sect. X. And,
3. Catharine, married to John de Berry, Count de Montpen≈øier: She died 1387.

As to what relates to Charles VI. he was Crown'd King of France, Nov. 4. 1380. 'Twas this Prince that reduc'd the Lilies in his Coat of Arms to Three, which the Kings of France, his Ance≈øtors, bore without any determinate number; and at each ≈øide, added a Stag for Supporters. In his Reign the Affairs of France were brought to the lowe≈øt ebb; e≈øpecially after the Battel of Agin-Court in Picardy with the Engli≈øh; in which, four Princes of the Blood, with all the Flower of the French Nobility, were
lo≈øt. This great Blow was given Octob. 24. 1415. After which, he would have excluded the Dauphin, and transferr'd the Kingdom to the Engli≈øh. This unfortunate Prince departed this Life 1422. having been long di≈øtracted. His Children by I≈øabella, Daughter of Stephen Duke of Bavaria, were in number twelve, whereof ≈øix died young. The re≈øt were,
1. I≈øabella, married about the age of ≈øeven or eight, Octob. 28. 1396. O. S. to Richard II. King of England; and after his decea≈øe, to Charles Duke of Orleans, An. 1402. She died 1409.
2. Charles VII. born Jan. 21. 1402. his Father's Succe≈ø≈øor.
3. Mary, ≈øhe was profe≈øs'd a Nun, and died 1438.
4. Joan, married to John VI. Duke of Bretagne; decea≈øed 1432.
5. Michaele, born 1394. married to Philip the Good Duke of Burgundy; decea≈øed 1422.
6. Catharine, born Octob. 27. 1400. married to Henry V. King of England, Feb. 24. 1420. And after his decea≈øe, to Owen ap Meridith ap Tudor, a Wel≈øh Gentleman (but de≈øcended of the ancient Briti≈øh Kings) Grandfather of King Henry VII. She died Jan. 3. 1437.

¬ß. IX. Charles VII. ≈øurnam'd The Victorious, from the Victory he obtain'd over the Engli≈øh at the Battel of Orleans, under the Conduct of the famous Joan de Arcquis, freed France from the many Mi≈øeries it had ≈øo long groan'd under, and re-e≈øtabli≈øh'd the Polity of that Kingdom.
He likewi≈øe put forth a Sanction whereby he very much curbed the pretended Juri≈ødiction of the Popes of Rome. Yet was this (otherwi≈øe happy) Prince ≈øo plagu'd by his own Son the Dauphin, that by rea≈øon thereof, he pined him≈øelf away, and died of Grief, An. 1461. The Sharer of his Bed and Fortunes, was Mary of Anjou, Daughter of Lewis II. King of Sicily; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue as followeth:
1. Lewis XI. of whom we ≈øhall ≈øoon treat.
2. Charles, Duke of Berry; born 1446. decea≈øed 1472.
3. Joland, married to Amadeus the eighth Duke of Savoy; decea≈øed 1478.
4. Radegunda, to Sigi≈ømund Duke of Au≈øtria: She died 14‚Äî.
5. Catharine, to Charles Duke of Burgundy: She died 14‚Äî.
6. Joan, to John II. Duke of Bourbon; decea≈øed 1482. And,
7. Magdalen, promi≈øed to Uladi≈ølaus King of Hungary; but married to Ga≈øton Fuxius, Prince of Vienna, decea≈øed 1486.

We now return to Lewis XI. born 1423. and Crown'd 1461. a Prince excellently skill'd in the Art of Government. 'Twas he that in≈øtituted the Order of the Knights of St. Michael, in the Year 1469. His Motto was, Qui ne≈øcit ≈øimulare, ne≈øcit imperare. He kept his De≈øigns ≈øo very clo≈øe, that the Grand Mare≈øchal of Normandy told him one day in raillery, Il faut, que v√¥tre haquen√©e ≈øoit bien fort, pui≈øque ille peut bien vos porter, vous & tout v√¥tre Con≈øeil: That his Mule mu≈øt needs be very ≈øtrong, ≈øince it cou'd ≈øo ea≈øily carry him and all his Coun≈øel. For the
re≈øt of his Character: He was an undutiful Son, a ≈øevere Father, and a di≈øloyal Husband: implacable in his Nature, in≈øomuch as he was never known to be reconciled to any he had once fallen out with. Nor had he any other e≈øteem for Religion, but as it ≈øerv'd his Intere≈øt. He departed this Life Aug. 30. 1483/4. having had two Wives, viz. Margaret, Daughter of James I. King of Scotland; and Charlotte, Daughter of Lewis Duke of Savoy; and by them a Son and two Daughters; viz.

list.item: 1. Anne, married to Peter Duke of Bourbon, 1473. decea≈øed 1522.
2. Joan, Dutche≈øs of Berry; born 1464. and married to Lewis Duke of Orleans, afterwards King; by whom ≈øhe was divorced, and died 1504.

3. Charles VIII. born 1470. and Crown'd 1484. A little Man, of no bad Di≈øpo≈øition, yet ≈ølow of Parts, and altogether ignorant of Arts and Letters: Contracted at ≈øcarce ≈øix Years old, to Elizabeth, Daughter of Edward IV. King of England; which Contract being afterwards broke, he was betrothed to Margaret, Daughter to the Emperour Maximilian, who was accordingly ≈øent into France, to have her Education there, that ≈øhe might the better be accu≈øtomed to the Manners of that Nation. Neverthele≈øs, ≈øhe was ≈øent home again by her Spou≈øe, when he came to be his own Ma≈øter; and he married, or rather ravi≈øh'd Anne, Daughter and ≈øole: Heire≈øs of the Duke of Bretagne, already married by Proxy to his de≈øign'd
Father-in-Law, Maximilian the Emperour; but had no I≈ø≈øue by her that ≈øurvived him. He came to his End in the Flower of his Age, by a very odd Accident, in the Year 1498. for going out of a Door at Amboi≈øe, where he then was, to ≈øee 'em run at Tilts, he ≈øtruck his Forehead with that violence again≈øt the top of it, as he was pre≈øently after ≈øeiz'd by an Apoplexy, and fell down dead in the place.

div.p:
¬ß. X. Wherefore we mu≈øt look back to Lewis Duke of Orleans, mention'd already by us, in Sect. VIII. Numb. 2. This Prince took to Wife Valentine, Daughter of Galeazzo Duke of Milan, who bare him this following I≈ø≈øue:
1. Charles, Duke of Orleans and Milan, born 1391.
2. Philip, decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue 1420.
3. Margaret, born 1406. She married Richard of Bretagne, Count d'E≈øtampes, and died 1464.
4. John, Count d'Angouleme; born 1404. of whom more in the next Section, as being him in who≈øe I≈ø≈øue the De≈øcent of this Line was continu'd.

Charles, the elde≈øt of the≈øe three, was taken Pri≈øoner at the Battel of Agin Court, and detain'd ≈øo in England for the ≈øpace of five and twenty Years; but in the end ran≈øom'd and ≈øet at liberty, by Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy. His death (which happened in 1465.) was ha≈øtned by the Indignation he conceiv'd, at having his Coun≈øels de≈øpi≈øed and laugh'd
at by King Lewis XI. He was thrice married, his fir≈øt Wife being I≈øabel, Daughter of Charles VI. King of France, the Relict of Richard II. King of England; his ≈øecond, Bona, Daughter of Bernhard Count d'Armanac; and his third, Mary, Daughter of Adolph Duke of Cleves. By the≈øe he had four Children:
1. Joan, married to John Duke of Alen√ßon.
2. Lewis XII. King of France.
3. Mary, married to John de Foix, Vi≈øcount Narbon; decea≈øed 1493.
4. Anne, Lady Abbe≈øs of Tonteurault.

Lewis XII. was advanc'd to the Throne, on the death of Charles VIII. without I≈ø≈øue, and Crown'd 1498. A merciful and gracious Prince; ≈øparing of the Money and Blood of his Subjects, and therefore very dear to his People, and ≈øtyled by 'em, The Father of his Country. Yet was he unfortunate through the whole cour≈øe of his Life; witne≈øs Thuanus's Hi≈øtory, lib. 1. His fir≈øt Wife was Joan, Daughter of King Lewis XI. a crooked and deform'd Per≈øon, forced on him, notwith≈øtanding his aver≈øion to her, and all the Prote≈øtations imaginable again≈øt the injury done him by the King her Father, in hopes of her proving barren. Wherefore having obtain'd the Crown, he divorc'd her. See Im. Hoff. Geneal. Gal. in Vit√¢ Ludov. XII. and ≈øub≈øtituted in her room Anne, the Relict of his Predece≈ø≈øor Charles VIII. After who≈øe decea≈øe, he married a third time, viz. Mary, Daughter of Henry VII. King of England; neverthele≈øs, all his Male I≈ø≈øue died young; ≈øo that he had only two Daughters; namely,
1. Claudia, born 1499. married to Francis I. King of France. And,
2. Renata, born 1509. married to Hercules Duke of Ferrara.

¬ß. XI. Wherefore John Count d'Angoule≈øme mu≈øt again appear; brought already on the Stage in the la≈øt Section, Numb. 4. He was left in England, by his Brother Charles, with King Henry V. as a Pledge for an Hundred thou≈øand Crowns, and not di≈ømi≈ø≈øed 'till thirty Years after. During which ≈øtay in England, he wholly applied him≈øelf to the ≈øtudy of Learning, and true Piety; in which he made ≈øo good progre≈øs, as to be held worthy, by the Council of Con≈øtance, of the Papal Chair; which Dignity he neverthele≈øs refu≈øed, that he might not incen≈øe his Prince, King Charles VII. who was a great Stickler for the depo≈øed Pope, Eugenius IV. He married Margaret, Daughter of Alan IX. Vi≈øcount Roban, who bore him a Son, named
Charles, Count d'Angoule≈øme, who took to Wife Aloi≈øia, Daughter of Philip Count de Bre≈ø≈øe, afterwards Duke of Savoy; by whom he had a Son, called Francis, born Sept. 12. 1494.

This Francis ≈øucceeded Lewis XII. upon his dying without I≈ø≈øue Male, and was Crown'd King of France 1515. He was very prone to Venery and Lewdne≈øs, which brought him into many and great Inconveniencies. He lo≈øt the Dutchy of Milan. In 1515. (the fir≈øt Year he came to the Crown) he overthrew the Swi≈øs, at the Battel of Marignan. He had great
Wars with the Emperour Charles V. by whom he was beaten at the Battel of Pavie, in the Year 1525. and being taken Pri≈øoner therein, was ≈øent to Madrid. Being again ≈øet at liberty, he began the War afre≈øh; but with no better ≈øucce≈øs; for in this ≈øecond War, he was wholly beaten out of Italy. He had likewi≈øe War with Henry VIII. King of England, which ended in the Year 1546. He was a great Lover of Learning and learned Men, whom he advanc'd and had in great e≈øteem. He was the fir≈øt that brought the Cu≈øtom of ≈øelling Offices and Preferments into France. He finally aboli≈øh'd the Pragmatick Sanction, and agreed to the Concordat. Moreover, he granted Annats to the Pope of Rome. His Queens were Claudia, Daughter to his Predece≈ø≈øor Lewis XII. and Eleanor, Daughter of Philip I. King of Spain; which la≈øt died in the Year 1558. he him≈øelf in 1547. leaving I≈ø≈øue a Son and two Daughters. The Son was

Henry II. of whom in the next Section. The Daughters,
1. Magdalen, married to James V. King of Scotland. And,
2. Margaret, married to Charles Duke of Alen√ßon; and after his decea≈øe, to Henry II King of Navarre.

¬ß. XII. Henry II. ≈øucceeded his Father, and was Crown'd King of France in 1547/8. He was of a generous Di≈øpo≈øition; a courageous and warlike Prince. He took Metz, Toul, and Verdun from the Germans, and overthrew the Emperour Charles V. in a Field Battel: He likewi≈øe
beat the Engli≈øh out of all their footing in France, by taking Calice; yet was defeated by the Spaniard, with a va≈øt ≈ølaughter of his Men, at the Battel of St. Quintin. De≈øigning to Honour his Si≈øter Margaret's Birth-Day with Fe≈øtivals, and a Tournament, in which he would run him≈øelf, he commanded the Count de Montgomery to run again≈øt him, as he did; but in the Cour≈øe the Count's Spear ≈øhiver'd in pieces, and an unlucky Splinter thereof wounded the King ≈øo grievou≈øly in the Eye, that he died within a few Days after, July 10. 1559. His Queen was Catharine de Medices, Daughter of Laurence Duke of Urbin, who bore him I≈ø≈øue, as followeth:
1. Francis II. who indeed ≈øucceeded him, but did not long ≈øurvive him; for he was Crown'd King Sept. 8. O.S. 1559. and died Decemb. 5. the Year following. He was married to Mary Stuart, Daughter of James V. King of Scotland, but left no I≈ø≈øue by her.
2. Elizabeth (or I≈øabella) born 1545. married to Philip II. King of Spain, 1559. decea≈øed 1568.
3. Claudia, married Feb. 5. 1559. to Charles II. Duke of Lorrain; decea≈øed 1575.
4. Lewis, decea≈øed an Infant.
5. Charles IX. born 1550. his Brother's Succe≈ø≈øor; Crown'd King May 15. 1561. His Reign is infamous for the many bloody Battels, for the daily Sieges and Sackings of Towns and Cities; for the Deva≈øtations of Provinces, and Slanghters of the Inhabitants, occa≈øion'd by the Civil War
that then rag'd in France; but above all, for the barbarous Ma≈ø≈øacre at Paris. This Prince had Poets in great e≈øteem, and ≈øometimes wrote Ver≈øes him≈øelf. He compo≈øed a Poem on Stag-Hunting, to which Recreation he was given to a fault. Of all his Sanctions, that is mo≈øt remarkable which he publi≈øh'd for reforming the Computation of the Year: For whereas all other Nations began their Year from the Fea≈øt of the Circumci≈øion, the French alone commenced theirs from Ea≈øter, which was alter'd by this King. He departed this Life 1574. in the flower of his Age, after a long and painful Sickne≈øs. His Queen was Elizabeth, Daughter to the Emperour Maximilian II. who bore him only a Daughter, nam'd Mary Elizabeth, born 1572. decea≈øed 1578.
6. Henry III. born Sept. 19. 1551. elected King of Poland 1573. Crown'd King of France 1574. murdered by James Clement a Dominican Friar, Aug. 2. 1589. leaving no I≈ø≈øue.
7. Francis Duke of Alen√ßon and Brabant, born 1554. decea≈øed a Batchellor 1584.
8. Margaret, married in 1572. to Henry IV. King of Navarre, and afterwards of France; divorc'd from him 1600. decea≈øed 1615.
9. Victoria, and, Twins, born and dead the ≈øame Year, viz. 1556.
10. Joan, Twins, born and dead the ≈øame Year, viz. 1556.

div.head: Of the Line of Bourbon.
div.p:
¬ß. XIII. MAtters being thus far clear'd and di≈øcu≈øs'd, we ≈øhall now bring Robert V. Son of Lewis IX. once more on the Stage, having been already mention'd in Sect. 4. Numb. 7. His elde≈øt Son's Name was Lewis, Count de Clermont, and Duke of Bourbon; and his Grand≈øon's, James de Bourbon, Count de la Marche and Ponthieu, Con≈øtable of France, who died in the Year 1362. being Father of John Count de la Marche, who ≈øucceeded him; and begat,
1. James II. Count de la Marche, King of Naples, who died 1438, having had, by Beatrix, Daughter of Charles III. King of Navarre, only a Daughter that ≈øurviv'd him; namely, Eleanor, married to Bernhard d'Armanac, Count de Pardiac.
2. Lewis de Bourbon, Count de Vend√¥me, of whom a little below.
3. Anne, married to John de Berry, Count de Montpen≈øier; and after his decea≈øe, to Lewis Barbatus, Duke of Bavaria.
4. Mary, to John de Beine, Baron de Croix.
5. Charlotte, to John King of Cyprus; ≈øhe died 1487.
6. John de Bourbon, Baron de Carency; who≈øe Po≈øterity became extinct in John de Bourbon, Baron de Carency, much about the Year 1493.

As for Lewis, the ≈øecond Son, he begat John de Bourbon, Count de Vend√¥me, who was Father
of Francis de Bourbon, Count de Vend√¥me; born 1470, and Lewis de Bourbon, Prince de la Roche ≈øur Y ‚Ä¢ n; which Branch of the Family fail'd in Henry de Bourbon, Duke of Montpellier, An. 1608. Francis the elder Brother departed this Life 1493. having begat Charles Duke de Vend√¥me, born 1489. decea≈øed 1534.
