This Charles had many Children, by Frances d'Alen√ßon, Dutche≈øs of Beaumont, Francis Duke of Longueville's Widow; whereof ten, who≈øe Names follow, liv'd to be Men and Women; viz.

list.item: 1. Margaret, born 1516. married to Francis Duke of Cleves, 1538.
2. Anthony, Duke de Vend√≤me, and King of Navarre; of whom in the next Section.
3. Francis, Count d'Enghien; born 1519. decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue 1546.
4. Magdalen, Lady Abbe≈øs of Poictiers.
5. Charles, born 1523, and promoted to the Cardinalate, in 1566. He was likewi≈øe made Bi≈øhop of Roan; and died May 9. 1590.
6. Catharine, and, Lady Abbe≈ø≈øes of Sece≈ø≈øion and Chelles,
7. Renata, Lady Abbe≈ø≈øes of Sece≈ø≈øion and Chelles,
8. John, Duke d'Enghien; born 1528. decea≈øed 1557.
9. Lewis, Prince de Conde, of who≈øe mo≈øt Noble Progeny, we ≈øhall ≈øpeak in the XV. Section of this Chapter.
10. Eleaner, born 1535. decea≈øed 1611.

div.p:
¬ß. XIV. We now return to Anthony Duke of Vend√¥me, Son of Charles Duke of Vend√¥me, as is objected ju≈øt above. He was born in the Year 1518. and performed many Noble and great
Actions, in the Service, and under the Au≈øpices of Francis I. and Henry II. Kings of France. After the death of his Father in-Law Henry II. King of Navarre, who≈øe only Daughter and Heire≈øs, Joan d'Albret, he had married; he po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd him≈øelf of that Kingdom, and the Principality of Bern, or at lea≈øt as much of ‚Ä¢ em as the Spamards had left him. He was more than once in great danger of his Life from the Gui≈øian Faction; yet died a natural death in 1562. leaving I≈ø≈øue a Son and a Daughter; namely,
1. Catharine, married to Henry Duke of Lorrain, Jan. 30. 1599. decea≈øed 1604. And,
2. Henry IV. ≈øurnam'd The Great, King of France and Navarre, born 1553. The Greatne≈øs of who≈øe Actions has totally eclip≈øed the Glory of the mo≈øt famous Monarch that ever Rul'd in France. In the Fifteenth Year of his Age he was Head of the Prote≈øtants in France. At Nineteen he went to the French Court at Paris, being invited to be pre≈øent at tho≈øe tragick Nuptials, infamous through the whole World, for the treacherous and bloody Ma≈ø≈øacre of ≈øo many thou≈øand Innocent and Noble Per≈øons. In the ≈øame Year he took on him the Title of King of Navarre, upon the death of his Mother the Queen. He thrice extorted Peace from the King's Party; and by the Battel of Courtray, 1581. (Henry III. being yet alive) di≈ø≈øolv'd the League, entered into by the Pope, the King of Spain, and the Gui≈øian Faction, for the Confu≈øion of the Prote≈øtants.
After the death of Henry III. he was Crown'd King of France, but not 'till 1594. having fir≈øt profe≈øs'd him≈øelf a Papi≈øt. On May 4. 1610. O. S. he was a≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinated and ≈øtabb'd in Paris, by that infamous Villain Francis Ravillac. His fir≈øt Queen was Margaret de Valois, Daughter of Henry II. King of France, whom he divorc'd: After which, he married Mary de Medices, Daughter of Francis Great Duke of Tu≈øcany, decea≈øed 1642. by whom he had I≈ø≈øue, as followeth:
1. Lewis XIII. of whom more in the next Section.
2. Elizabeth, married to Philip IV. King of Spain, 1615. decea≈øed 1644.
3. Chri≈øtina, to Victor Amadeus I. Duke of Savoy; ≈øhe died 1663.
4. Ga≈øton John Bapti≈øt. Duke of Orleans, born 1608. who was twice married, his fir≈øt Dutche≈øs being Mary of Bourbon, Daughter of Henry Duke of Montpen≈øier; decea≈øed 1627. His ≈øecond, Margaret of Lorrain, Daughter of Francis Count de Vaudemont; decea≈øed 1672. By the≈øe he had four Daughters; viz.
1. Anne Mary, Dutche≈øs of Montpen≈øier; born 1627. now alive, and unmarried.
2. Margaret Loui≈øe, born 1645. and married 1661. to Co≈ømus III. Great Duke of Tu≈øcany.
3. I≈øabella, born 1646. and married to Jo≈øeph Lewis Duke of Gui≈øe, in 1667. She is now a Widow.
4. Frances Magdalen, born 1648. married to Charles Emanuel Duke of Savoy, 1663. decea≈øed May 11. 1665.
5. Henrietta Maria, born 1609. married to Charles I. King of England, May 1. 1625. O. S. decea≈øed July 31. 1669. aged Sixty.

¬ß. XV. Lewis XIII. born Sept. 27. 1601. ≈øucceeded his Father, and was Crown'd King of France, Octob. 18. 1610. An excellent Prince, had he not given too much way to the Coun≈øels of tho≈øe two famous Mini≈øters of State, Richlieu and Mazarine. He never fought but where he conquer'd. In 1615. he married Anna Maria Mauritia, Daughter of Philip III. King of Spain, whom he had betrothed in 1611. And by her left I≈ø≈øue,
1. LEWIS XIV. ≈øurnamed The Great, the pre≈øent King of France, born Aug. 26. O.S. 1638. of whom below. And,
2. Philip, Duke of Orleans, Sept. 21. N.S. 1640. who≈øe fir≈øt Dutche≈øs, the Prince≈øs Henrietta Maria Stuart, Daughter of Charles I. King of England, departed this Life in June, 1670. And he, the next Year, married Charl ‚Ä¢ tte Elizabeth, Daughter of Charles Lewis Elector Palatine. By the fir≈øt Venture he had,
1. Mary Aloi≈øia (or Loui≈øe) born March 27. 1662. married Novemb. 17. 1679. to Charles II. King of Spain; decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue by him, 1689.
2. Philip, decea≈øed an Infant.
3. Another Daughter not named, 1665.
4. Anne Mary, born Aug. 27. 1669. and mo≈øt happily married, April 9. to Victor Amadeus II. Duke of Savoy.

He has al≈øo a Son and a Daughter by the pre≈øent Dutche≈øs; namely,
1. Philip, Duke of Chartres, born Aug. 2. 1674. And,
2. Elizabeth Charlotte, Madamoi≈øelle de Chartres, born Sept. 13. 1676.

As for Lewis the Great, the pre≈øent King, he ≈øucceed his Father in 1643. and was Crown'd by the Archbi≈øhop of Rheims, June 7. 1654. of who≈øe Actions I ≈øhall ≈øay little here, ≈øince the Eyes of the whole World are upon 'em. His Queen was Maria There≈øia, Daughter of Philip IV. King of Spain, who died July 30. 1683. by whom he has only a Son now living, namely,

Lewis XV. ≈øurnamed The Hardy, the pre≈øent Dauphin; born Nov. 1. 1661. In 1680. he married Maria Anna Chri≈øtina, Daughter of Ferdinand Maria, late Elector of Bavaria; by whom he has had three Sons; who≈øe Names are,
1. Lewis, Duke of Burgundy, born Aug. 6. 1682.
2. Philip, Duke of Anjou, born Novemb. 19. 1683. And,
3. Ga≈øton, Duke of Berry, born Aug. 31. 1686.

But be≈øides the Dauphin, the pre≈øent French King has ≈øeveral Natural Children; as namely, Mary Anne de Bourbon, born 1666. and married in 1680. to Lewis of Bourbon, Prince de Conti: And Lewis de Bourbon, born 1667. Supreme Intendant
of the Marine. The≈øe two were born him by Aloi≈øia Frances de la Beaume la Blanche de la Valiere, Dutche≈øs de Vaujour, and Peere≈øs of France, Daughter of Laurence de la Valiere, now a Carmelite Nun, by the Name of Si≈øter Aloi≈øia de Mi≈øericordia (or of Mercy.) As likewi≈øe Lewis Augu≈øtus de Bourbon, Duke of Main, born 1670. and made legitimate three Years after. Lewis Cae≈øar de Bourbon, Count de Vexin, born 1672. decea≈øed 1683. Aloi≈øia Frances de Bourbon, Madamoi≈øelle de Nantes, born 1673. and married in 1685. to Lewis Duke of Bourbon. Aloi≈øia Mary Anne, decea≈øed 1681. Lewis Alexander de Bourbon, Count de Toulou≈øe, born 1678. made Legitimate 1681. Intendant likewi≈øe of the Marine. And Frances Mary de Bourbon, Madamoi≈øelle de Rlois, born 1681. Which Six were born him by Frances Athana≈øia de Rochechouart, Gabriel Prince de Mortemar's Daughter, and Wife of Henry de Lewis Paidaillan, Marque≈øs of Monte≈øpan.

¬ß. XVI. It remains we now return to Lewis Prince de Conde, younge≈øt Son of Charles Duke of Vend√¥me, born 1530. whom we mentioned in the latter end of Sect. XIII. Numb. 9. He was ≈ølain at the bloody Battel of Jarnac, 1569. by one Monte≈øque, a Captain under the Duke of Anjou, notwith≈øtanding he offer'd 100000 Crowns for his Ran≈øom. The I≈ø≈øue that ≈øurvived him were,
1. Henry, Prince of Conde; born 1552.
2. Francis, Prince of Conti; born 1558. who had only Natural I≈ø≈øue, though twice married.
3. Charles, Archbi≈øhop of Roan, and Cardinal; decea≈øed 1594.
4. Charles, Count de Soi≈ø≈øons, Peer and Grand Ma≈øter of France; born 1566. decea≈øed 1614. leaving I≈ø≈øue,
1. Aloi≈øia, married to Henry Duke of Longueville; decea≈øed 1637.
2. Lewis, born 1604. decea≈øed 1641. And,
3. Mary, born 1606. and married to Thomas of Savoy, Prince of Carignan.

Henry, the elde≈øt Brother, was a Prince of great Courage, and hath his Life finely written by Thuanus, in his Hi≈øtory, Lib. 90. His fir≈øt Prince≈øs was Mary of Cleve, Daughter of Francis Duke of Nevers: But ≈øhe dying in 1574. he afterwards married Charlotte Catharine de Tremolle, Daughter of Lewis Duke of Thovars; and departed this Life 1588. leaving I≈ø≈øue by the la≈øt Lady, as followeth; namely,
1. Eleanora, born 1587. married in 1606. to Philip William of Na≈ø≈øau, Prince of Orange; decea≈øed 1619. And,
2. Henry II. Prince of Conde; born after his Father's decea≈øe, Sept. 1. 1588. His Prince≈øs was Charlotte Margaret, Daughter of Henry II. Duke of Montmorency, who bore him,
1. Anne, married in 1642. to Henry Duke of Longueville; decea≈øed 1679.
2. Lewis II. Prince of Conde. And,
3. Armand, Prince of Conti; of which two apart. And fir≈øt for Lewis:

He was born in 1621. and ju≈øtly to be ranked among the greate≈øt Hero's of the Age. He took to Wife Clara Clementia, Daughter of
Urban Marque≈øs of Breze; and departed this Life 1685. to the great Grief of all good Men. His only Son

Henry Julius de Bourbon, is now living; born July 29. 1643. formerly ≈øtyled Duke d'Enghien; but now, ≈øince his Father's death, Prince of Conde. His Prince≈øs is Anne, Daughter of Edward Prince Palatine of the Rhine; who has born him this following I≈ø≈øue now living:
1. Mary There≈øia, Madamoi≈øelle de Bourbon; born 1666.
2. Lewis, Duke of Bourbon; born 1668. and married 1685. to Aloi≈øia Frances, Natural Daughter of the pre≈øent French King.
3. Mary Anne, Madamoi≈øelle de Montmorency; born 1675.
4. Anne Mary Victoria, Madamoi≈øelle d'Enghien; born 1676. And,
5. Aloi≈øia Benedicta, Madamoi≈øelle de Conde; born 1678.

As for Armand, Prince de Conti, the other Brother; he was born 1629. married to Anne Mary of Montmorency, Cardinal Mazarine's Neice by the Si≈øter, 1654. decea≈øed 1666. leaving two Sons:
1. Lewis de Bourbon, Prince of Conti; born 1661. In 1680. he took to Wife Mary Anne de Bourbon, the King's Natural Daughter, made legitimate; yet died without I≈ø≈øue in 1685. And,
2. Francis Lewis de Bourbon, the now Prince of Conti; born 1668.

div.head: Of the Augmentation of the Hou≈øe of France.
div.p:
¬ß. XVII. IN the Year 861. Robert Earl of Orleans was created Duke and Marque≈øs of the Franks, by Charles the Bald, King of France; to who≈øe Son Eudo, the County of Paris was likewi≈øe added, by Charles the Gro≈øs. King of France. After this, Hugh Capet came to be King, An. 987. who≈øe Brother Otho having married Leutgarde, Daughter and Heire≈øs to the la≈øt Duke of Burgundy, in her Right po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of that Dutchy. Philip II. having defeated John (≈øans Terre) King of England, brought Normandy, Bretagne, Anjou, Touraine, Poictou, and Clermont, with part of Aquitain, under his Obedience, and incorporated the ≈øame with the Crown. Charles Duke of Anjou was Crown'd King of both the Sicily's, An. 1266. He likewi≈øe became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of Provence in Right of his Wife; as al≈øo of a Title to the Kingdom of Jeru≈øalem, by the Donation of Mary Prince≈øs of Antioch. Charles Martel, his Grand≈øon, was Crown'd King of Hungary, in 1290. in right of his Mother Mary, Daughter of Stephen King of Hungary. Lewis his Son became King of Poland, by a Marriage with Elizabeth, Daughter of Ladi≈ølaus King of that Country. And Philip, Charles Martel's Brother, took upon him the Title of Emperour of Con≈øtantinople, in his Wife's Right. Lewis IX. obtain'd Clermont, Tholou≈øe, and Provence, by the ≈øame Right; Beaumont by Gift, and Ma≈øcon for Money. Philip the Fair bought the County of Canny; and joyn'd the Kingdom of Navarre
to that of France, by a Marriage with Joan la≈øt Heire≈øs thereof; with whom he had Champagne al≈øo, and the Territory of Bruges. Philip VI. ≈øurnamed de Valois, had Dauphine given him: but bought the Lord≈øhip of Mompellier in Languedoc, of Sanchius King of Majorca. Charles V. did the ≈øame by Auxerre; Picena, part of Dreux, Creil, and Mouzon; all which Places he annexed to the Crown. In 1345. Philip Duke of Burgundy, third Son of King John, added the Counties of Artois, Burgundy, and Flanders, as al≈øo the Dutchy of Brabant, to this Family; partly as his Mother's Inheritance, and partly as his Wife's. After this, Charles the Bold ≈øucceeded to the Dutchy of Burgundy as next Heir, and ≈øo became Lord of all the Netherlands. In 1389. Lewis II. Son of Charles V. became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Dutchy of Milan, in right of his Wife Valentina, Daughter and Heire≈øs of John Galeazo Duke thereof. In 1535. Francis I. annexed the Dutchy of Bretagne to the Crown. Henry IV. gave the Kingdom of Navarre once more to the Crown, together with the Principality of Bern, the Dutchies of Vend√¥me, Beaumont, and Albret; the Counties of Foix and Armanac, Perigord, and Bre≈ø≈øe, with many other Places: So that all France became incorporated in the Crown. La≈øt of all, Lewis XIV. the pre≈øent King, has made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of the Bi≈øhopricks of Metz, Tulles, and Verdun; Pignerol, Bri≈øac, all Al≈øace, and Bri≈øgow. By the Pyrenaean Treaty he had the County of Rou≈øillon, with part of that of Cerdagne, made over to him: See Artic. 42. and 43. Moreover, he has bought Ca≈øal, the
Capital City of Montferrat. By the Treaty of Peace at Nimeguen, he was put in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Freiburg. Two Years after, he made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of Strasburg by force of Arms, viz. Septemb. 29. 1681. as he had done ≈øeven Years before, of the Dutchies of Barre and Lorrain; which two la≈øt he has united to the Crown for ever. He has likewi≈øe taken the Palatinate of Deux Pents from its Natural Prince, under pretence of its being an Appendant of Al≈øace. Nor have the Dukes of Wirtenberg e≈øcaped him, from whom he forced Mompelgart; as al≈øo Orange from the Prince of that Name. In ≈øhort, the Fronch of late years have extended their Power as far as America, where they ≈øtand po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of New-France, and I≈øles of St. Chri≈øtopher and Martinique; as al≈øo that of St. Laurence near Africk. Moreover, they ≈øeem of late to have gotten footing in Siam in the Ea≈øt-India's.

div.head: Of its Decrea≈øe.
div.p:
¬ß. XVIII. THe greate≈øt Diminution ≈øuffered by the Family of Capet, has been from the Engli≈øh; who beginning a War with the Line of Valois, under the Conduct of King Edward III. about the Year 1338. ≈øubdued (in a manner) all France. Neverthele≈øs, in proce≈øs of time all was regain'd by the French; ≈øo that now the Engli≈øh have not ≈øo much as a Foot of Land in France. In 1477. Mary, the only Daughter and Heire≈øs of Charles the Bold (la≈øt Duke of Burgundy of this Family) being married to Maximilian I transferred
the Franche Comt√©, together with all the Netherlands; and indeed all other her Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, except the Dutchy of Burgundy, to the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria. Neverthele≈øs, the French by degrees have recovered many of the≈øe Places, and ≈øtill are gaining more, as, namely, Artois, with great part of Haynault and Flanders, by the Pyrenaean Treaty of Peace: See the 35th. and following Articles: By the Peace of Nimeguen, the Franche Comt√©; and ≈øince that, the Dutchy of Luxenburg. They have al≈øo made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of ≈øome Cities belonging to the United Provinces; and bought Dunkirk of the Engli≈øh. But then again for its Decrea≈øe: In 1281. this Family lo≈øt the Kingdom of Sicily, witne≈øs the famous Sicilian Ve≈øpers; at which time it lo≈øt Malta al≈øo. Joan, the la≈øt Queen of Naples, of the Family of Capet, transferred that Kingdom to Alphon≈øo King of Arragon. Hedewig de≈øcended of the ≈øame Race, la≈øt Heire≈øs of the Kingdom of Poland, brought in Marriage that Kingdom to Jagello, Duke of Lithuania. In 1512. the Kingdom of Navarre was torn from it by the Spaniard; and the Dutchy of Milan lo≈øt about ten Years after, to Charles V. who inve≈øted his Son Philip therein. La≈øt of all, the pre≈øent French King has again freely ≈øurrendred the County of Avignon, to his Holine≈øs, Pope Alexander VIII. (alias Ottoboni.) By all which it appears what Regions and Provinces are at pre≈øent ≈øubject to the French King; yet con≈øult at lei≈øure the famous John Chri≈øt. Beckman's Hi≈øt. Civ. c. 3. ¬ß. 2.

div.head: Of its Preten≈øions.
div.p: ¬ß. XIX. THe Hou≈øe of France ≈øeems, in the fir≈øt place, to have a ju≈øt Title to the Upper Kingdom of Navarre, as taken from King John of Albret, by Ferdinand the Catholick, King of Spain, at the In≈øtigation of Pope Julius II. whereas the Right and Title thereunto, was by Joan of Albret's being married to Anthony of Bourbon, Father of King Henry the Great, transferred into that Family; and the Claim ≈øu≈øpended 'till this day.
2. To the Commonwealth of Genoua, by rea≈øon of a voluntary and formal Surrender of its Soveraignty, in 1396. to Charles VI. King of France; which has been ≈øince often claim'd.
3. To the Kingdom of Naples; which neverthele≈øs ≈øeems to be but weak, and is wholly rejected by the Spaniards.
4. To the Dutchy of Milan; Valentina, the Heire≈øs of that Dutchy, being married by Lewis Duke of Orleans, ≈øecond Son of Charles V. And,

La≈øtly, The pre≈øent King, in name of his Brother Philip, Duke of Orleans, lays claim to great part of the Palatinate of the Rhine: And this has been the occa≈øion of the pre≈øent bloody and expen≈øive War.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Lineage of the Kings of England.
div.p: ¬ß. I. WHat the fir≈øt State or Form of England was, how conquer'd by the Romans, and afterwards by the Saxons, makes ≈øo little to the pre≈øent Undertaking, that we purpo≈øely leave it; it being as much as we ≈øhall have occa≈øion for, That about the Year 1016. Canutus (or Knute) King of Denmark, invaded this Kingdom; and having treacherou≈øly ≈ølain the Saxon King, Edmond Iron≈øide, 1018. married Emma, the Widow of King Ethelred, Father of the ≈øaid Edmond; and was the fir≈øt Dani≈øh King of England, and died 1038.

His I≈ø≈øue were,
1. Harold, ≈øurnamed Harefoot, by a former Wife.
2. Hardicanute, by the ≈øaid Emma.
Harold ≈øucceeded his Father, and died without I≈ø≈øue 1041. and left the Succe≈ø≈øion to his ≈øaid Brother, by the Father's ≈øide,

Hardicanute, who by means of his Luxury, became odious to the People; and in the mid≈øt of a Debauch, died ≈øuddenly, 1042. le≈øt no I≈ø≈øue; and with him ended the Government of the Danes in England. To him ≈øucceeded his Brother, by the Mother's ≈øide,

Edward, ≈øurnamed The Confe≈ø≈øor, the Son of Ethelred, by Emma the Mother of Hardicanute, as before. He had been pre≈øerv'd from Canute, by Richard II. Duke of Normandy, his Uncle; and upon the death of Hardicanute, was recall'd from Normandy, and Crown'd King in the Year 1042 and Fortieth of his Age. He fir≈øt brought into the Royal Family the Gift of curing The King's Evil: Reigned Twenty four Years, and died without I≈ø≈øue 1065. Upon this,

Harold II. Son of Earl Godwin, by Guitha, Sifter of Swaine King of Denmark, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Edwin and Morcar, Earls of York and Che≈øter, was preferred to the Crown; but enjoy'd it not long, for he was ≈ølain in Battel, Octob. 14. 1066. by

¬ß. II. William I. Duke of Normandy, ≈øurnamed The Conquerour; fir≈øt of the Normans that was King of England; Natural Son of Robert II. Duke of Normandy, by Arletta, an ob≈øcure Woman; who under pretence that Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor had, by his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament, transferred the Kingdom to him, made a De≈øcent into England; and having ≈ølain Harold, as before, was, by the unanimous Con≈øent of the Peerage of England, Crown'd King, 1067. He had a ≈øharp War with Philip I. King of France; and after Twenty one Years Reign, died at Roan in Normandy, Septemb. 9. 1087. He had to Wife Maud, Daughter of Baldwin V. Earl of Flanders; by whom he had ≈øix Daughters and four Sons
1. Cecilie, Abbe≈øs of Caen in Normandy.
2. Con≈øtance, married to the Earl of Britain.
3. Adela, to Stephen Earl of Blois, Father of King Stephen; of whom in his turn.
4. Gundred, to William Warren, fir≈øt Earl of Surry.
5. Ela, both died young.
6. Margaret, both died young.

His Sons were,
1. Robert, to whom he bequeathed the Dutchy of Normandy.
2. Richard, kill'd by a Stagg in New Fore≈øt, in his Father's Life-time.
3. William ≈øurnamed Rufus, who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Kingdom.
4. Henry I. ≈øurnamed Beauclerk, to whom he left his Trea≈øure, and a yearly Pen≈øion; of whom more in the next Section.

II. William II. born in Normandy 1057. his Brother Robert being in Normandy, at the time of his Father's death, what by pretext of his Father's Will, and the contrivance of Lanfranc Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, was Crown'd, Octob. 5. following. He had War with the Scots; brought Wales under his Obedience; but what with that, and to ≈øecure his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion again≈øt the Claim and Arms of his elder Brother Robert, he was nece≈ø≈øitated to many a di≈øhonourable Shift whereby to get Money; and at la≈øt ≈øtrook dead with an Arrow, ≈øhot by Sir Walter Tyrel, a Norman, his Bow-Bearer, as they were Hunting in New Fore≈øt (but whether by accident, or otherwi≈øe, is uncertain,) Aug. 2. 1100. being the Eleventh Year of his Reign, and Forty third of his Age; but never married.

III. Henry. I. younge≈øt Son of the Conqueror, born in England 1070. his elde≈øt Brother Robert ≈øtill living (but in favour of Henry, given out to be cho≈øen King of Jeru≈øalem) ≈øucceeded his Brother William, and was Crown'd in four Days after his death. He had long Wars with his Brother Robert, upon his return from the Holy War; 'till at la≈øt having taken him Pri≈øoner, he put out his Eyes, and threw him in Pri≈øon, where he died; but left no I≈ø≈øue. He call'd the fir≈øt Parliament, after the Conque≈øt, at Salisbury, in 1115. and died of a Surfeit in Normandy, Decemb. 2. 1136. in the Sixty ≈øeventh Year of his Age, and Thirty fifth of his Reign. His fir≈øt Wife was Matilda, or Maud, Daughter of Malcolm III. King of Scotland, by Margaret the Si≈øter of Edgar Atheling, right Heir of Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, as being de≈øcended from Edmond Iron≈øide, of whom before; by which means the Saxon Line was re≈øtor'd in her I≈ø≈øue,
1. William, born 1102. he married Matilda (or Maud) Daughter of Foulk Earl of Anjon; who with ≈øeveral others were ca≈øt away, Nov. 26. 1119.
2. Maud, the only legitimate I≈ø≈øue that ≈øurviv'd him, born 1104. ≈øhe was fir≈øt married to the Emper our Henry IV. 1110. and after his death, to Jeoffry Plantaganet Earl of Anjou, 1124. (≈øo called from a Sprig of Broom which he wore in his Cap, or Bonnet) by whom ≈øhe had King Henry II.
His ≈øecond Wife was Adeliza, Daughter of Jeoffry Duke of Lorrain, by whom he had no I≈ø≈øue.

He had ≈øeven Natural Sons:
1. Robert, Earl of Glouce≈øter; a Per≈øon of great Direction, and indefatigable Indu≈øtry, as appear'd by the valiant A≈ø≈øi≈øtance he gave his ≈øaid Si≈øter Maud, again≈øt King Stephen.
2. Richard, drown'd with his Brother William, 1117.
3. Reinald, Earl of Cornwal, and Baron of Castle-Combe. Nor is there any particular mention of the other Four.
And as many Natural Daughters,
Of whom it is only ≈øaid, they were all of them honourably be≈øtowed in Marriage.

¬ß. III. William, only Son of Henry I. being lo≈øt (as before) and him≈øelf not having I≈ø≈øue by his ≈øecond Wife, he now began to think of ≈øetling the Succe≈ø≈øion; and to that purpo≈øe call'd another Paaliament, 1133. in which, all the Lords of the Land took an Oath to be true to his Daughter Maud the Empre≈øs, and her Heirs, and acknowledge them as right Inheritors of the Crown: And among≈øt them,

IV. Stephen, born 1107. Earl of Belogne and Montague, Son of Stephen Earl of Blois, by Adela, third Daughter of the Conquerour, was one; yet by the working of Henry (his Brother) Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, the Pope's Legate, a Man acceptable to the Nobility, at that time altogether govern'd by the Clergy, he was ≈øet up to the Crown, again≈øt the undoubted Right of the ≈øaid Empre≈øs, and Crown'd on St. Stephen's Day, 1135. His fir≈øt War was with the Scots; but during mo≈øt of his Reign, under various
Fortune with the ≈øaid Empre≈øs, 'till (his Children being dead) he ≈øecur'd the Succe≈ø≈øion to her Son Henry. He died Octob. 25. 1154. in the Forty ninth Year of his Age, and Nineteenth of his Reign; and had to Wife Maud, Daughter and Heir of Eu≈øtace Earl of Bologne; by whom he had,
1. Eu≈øtace, who died in the Eighteenth Year of his Age.
2. William, who died younger.
His Natural I≈ø≈øue.

list.item: 1. William, Earl of Norfolk.
2. Gervais, Abbot of We≈øtmin≈øter, who died 1160.

div.p:
V. ¬ß. IV. To him ≈øucceeded Henry II. ≈øurnamed Fitz Empre≈øs, fir≈øt of the Line of Plantagenet; born at Mentz in Normandy, 1131. Crown'd King Decemb. 7. 1155. He ≈øought to abate the Power of the Clergy, the Effects of which he had felt in the Exclu≈øion of his Mother, and advancement of King Stephen; but it wrought him great Troubles, particularly with Thomas Becket Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury (touching the Exemption of Clerks from the Secular Power) and the Con≈øequence of it ≈øtuck to his Family for Sixty Years after. He Crown'd his Son Henry King, June 14. 1170. in the Seventeenth Year of his Age: Sent Strongbow Earl of Chcap≈øtow into Ireland in the ≈øame Year, who planted the fir≈øt Colony of Engli≈øh in Wexford: went over thither in 1172. Conquer'd it, and wrote him≈øelf LORD thereof. He ≈øuffered much by his Sons Henry and Richard: The former broke with him 1173. and
died 1183. his Father living. The other combin'd with the King of France again≈øt him, 1188. in which al≈øo he engag'd his Brother John; which ≈øo ≈øtruck to his Heart, that he died of Grief in Normandy, and rather bur≈øt than bow'd to Fortune, July 9. 1189. in the Sixty fir≈øt Year of his Age, and Thirty fourth of his Reign. His Wife was Eleanor, Daughter of William Duke of Acquitain, divorc'd from Lewis VII. King of France; by whom he had three Daughters:
1. Maud, married to Henry Duke of Saxony.
2. Eleanor, to Alphon≈øo VIII. King of Ca≈øtile.
3. Joan, to William King of Sicily.
And ≈øix Sons.

list.item: 1. William, who died young.
2. Henry, of whom before; married to Margaret, Daughter of Lewis VII. King of France; but died without I≈ø≈øue.
3. Richard, who ≈øucceeded his Father; born 1155.
4. Jeoffry, Earl of Britain; married to Con≈øtance, Daughter of Conan Earl of Richmond; by whom he had Arthur, Earl of Britain, Angiers, and Richmond.
5. Philip, who died young.
6. John, who ≈øucceeded his Brother Richard.

div.p:
His Natural Sons:
1. William, ≈øurnam'd Longe≈øpee, or Long-≈øword, Earl of Salisbury, in right of his Wife Ela, Daughter and Heir of William Earl of that Place.
2. Jeoffry Archbi≈øhop of York; who after a five Years bani≈øhment by his Brother King John, died 1213. Both by Ro≈øamond.
3. Morgan, Provo≈øt of Beverly, Bi≈øhop Elect of Durham. By the Lady Blewet.

VI. Richard I. born at Oxford, 1155. ≈øurnam'd Coeur de Lycn, ≈øucceeded his Father, and was Crown'd Septemb. 3. 1189. He made an Expedition into the Holy Land the ≈øame Year; and in his return through Au≈øtria, was impri≈øon'd by the Emperour Henry VI. to whom he re≈øign'd his Crown; nor yet di≈øcharged, without the payment of 100000 Marks; which was accepted, notwith≈øtanding the large Profers of the King of France, and his Brother John, to have him detain'd. Upon his coming home, he was Crown'd a ≈øecond time, and made War with France, where he was ≈ølain with a barbed Arrow, by one Bertram, at the Siege of Chalons in Limo≈øin, April 6. 1199. in the Forty fourth Year of his Age, and Ninth of his Reign. He had to Wife Beringuel, Daughter of the King of Navarre; but died without I≈ø≈øue. After him,

VII. John, ≈øurnamed Sans Terre; born 1166. younge≈øt Son of Henry II. notwith≈øtanding the ju≈øt Right of Arthur his elder Brother's Son, by the means of Hubert Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, obtain'd the Crown; and was Crown'd by him upon A≈øcen≈øion day, 1199. On this, Arthur made War upon him in Anjou; be≈øieged Mirabel, defended by Eleanor, Mother of King John, who rai≈øed the Siege, defeated Arthur, took him Pri≈øoner, and had him murdered in Pri≈øon, 1202. He lo≈øt at that time Normandy to the King of France (who took part with Arthur) after a Three hundred Years po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by his Ance≈øtors. Upon the death of Hubert,
Stephen Langton, a Cardinal, being impos'd on him for Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, is refus'd by him, 1207. The Monks of Canterbury accept him; the King expels them as Traitors: The Kingdom is interdicted, 1208. him≈øelf excommunicated, 1210. and his Kingdom given to the King of France, 1213. He ≈øubmits, and ≈øurrenders his Kingdoms of England and Ireland to Pope Innocent III. and became his Feudatory for them at the yearly Tribure of a thou≈øand Marks, payable to the ≈øaid Pope and his Succe≈ø≈øors; does Homage and Fealty for them to Pandulphus his Legate, gives up his Crown to him, and receives it again two days after. This Charter bore date May 15. 1213. and was ca≈øually lo≈øt by fire, at the Council of Lyons; but never were any Monies paid upon it, or ever demanded, ≈øince 1366. 40th. Edward III. at what time al≈øo it was refu≈øed. He was ab≈øolv'd from his Excommunication the ≈øame Year; and the King of France, upon pain of like Excommunication, forbidden to proceed further again≈øt him, as having ≈øubmitted him≈øelf to the Church; and the Juri≈ødiction, which had now la≈øted ≈øix Years, or better, releas'd: Yet his Barons cea≈øe not to infe≈øt him, and force two Charters from him; to wit, Magna Charta, and Charta de Fore≈øta, 1214, which the Pope nulls, and excommunicates the Barons. They, on the other hand, bring in Lewis, the King of France his Son, who landed May 1. 1216, whom Guallo, the Pope's Legate, excommunicates. In 1210. he erected the Mayoralty of London, and further granted to them to have two Sheriffs and a Common Council. And notwith≈øtanding
all Turmoils at home, ≈øetled Ireland, and brought the Engli≈øh Laws and Coin into that Kingdom; and died Octob. 19. 1216. in the Fifty fir≈øt Year of his Age, and Seventeenth of his Reign; and (as ≈øome have ≈øaid) by Poi≈øon. He had three Wives; his fir≈øt was Alice, Daughter of Hubert Earl of Morton. He was divorc'd from his ≈øecond, the Daughter of Robert Earl of Glouce≈øter, upon the ≈øcore of Con≈øanguinity; and married I≈øabel, Daughter and Heir of Ailmer Earl of Angole≈øme; by whom only he had I≈ø≈øue three Daughters and two Sons.

His Daughters:
1. Joan, married to Alexander II. King of Scots.
2. Eleanor, to William Earl of Pembroke; and afterwards to Simon de Montford Earl of Leice≈øter.
3. I≈øabella, to the Emperour Frederick II.

His Sons:
1. Henry, who ≈øucceeded him in the Kingdom.
2. Richard, Earl of Cornwal; Crown'd King of the Romans 1257. died 1274.

As al≈øo three Natural Children:
1 Joan, married to Llewellin Prince of Wales.
2. Jeoffry Fitz-Roy, who ≈øerv'd in France.
3. Richard, who married the Daughter and Heir of Fulbert de Dover.

VIII. To him ≈øucceeded Henry III. born 1208. Crown'd in nine days after the death of his Father, and committed to the Tutelage of William Earl of Pembroke, Great Mar≈øhal of England; by who≈øe prudent Management, ≈øeveral
of the mo≈øt eminent Barons for ≈øook Lewis, and return'd to their Allegiance; and with the re≈øt of the Kingdom that ≈øtood firm to their young King, drove him from place to place, and at la≈øt gave him a total Rout; upon which, he came to an Accord, and quitted the Kingdom. In the Ninth of his Reign, he confirm'd the Charters granted by his Father; which afterwards he endeavour'd to re≈øcind, as done in his minority, The mo≈øt of his Reign was full of Troubles with his Barons, headed by the late mention'd Simon de Montfort, a French Exile; but got into that favour, that he was made Earl of Leice≈øter, and married the King's Si≈øter (as before;) yet with the Earl of Glouce≈øter and others, he fights the King at a place call'd Lewis, where they made him and Prince Edward his Son, Pri≈øoners, 1264. They quarrel about the Dividend: The Prince makes his e≈øcape, 1265. Glouce≈øter joyns him, and gives Leice≈øter Battel, in which the latter is ≈ølain. After which, the King liv'd ≈øeven Years, approv'd him≈øelf a wi≈øe Prince, and died Nov 16. 1272. in the Sixty fifth Year of his Age, and Fifty ≈øixth of his Reign. He had to Wife Eleanor, ≈øecond Daughter of Raymond Earl of Provence; by whom he had two Daughters and ≈øix Sons.

His Daughters:
1. Margaret, married to Alexander III. King of Scots.
2. Beatrice. to John I. Duke of Bretain.

Of his Sons, two only ≈øurviv'd him:
1. Edward I. who ≈øucceeded his Father.
2. Edmond, ≈øurnamed Crouch back, Earl of Lanca≈øter, Father of Thomas, who had I≈ø≈øue Henry Earl of Lanca≈øter, who≈øe Daughter Blanche was married to John of Gaune, fourth Son of King Edward III. of whom more hereafter.

IX. ¬ß. V. Edward I. born 1240. ≈øurnamed Long≈øhanks, had under taken the Cro≈øs, and was in the Holy Land when his Father died: However, he is proclaim'd King, and Fealty ≈øworn to him, tho' it were not known whether he were living or dead. Upon his return, he was Crown'd Aug. 15. 1274. He had found by Experience the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Power too ≈øtrong for the Soveraignty, whenever they combin'd with the Lay-Nobility; and therefore retrench'd them of their Privileges, whil≈øt he was in the Opinion and E≈øtimation of the World; and in 1275. got the Statute of Mortmain to be enacted, whereby to hinder the encrea≈øe of their Temporal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions; and not long after, clipp'd the Juri≈ødiction of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Judges. He ≈ølew Leoline, the la≈øt of the Wel≈øh Princes, in Battel, and united Wales to the Crown of England, 1283. He bani≈øh'd the Jews, and vacated all their Sureties, 1293. He was made Umpire between John Baliol and Robert Bruce, for the Crown of Scotland; and determined for Baliol, who did him Homage, 1294. which he afterwards renounc'd; but upon the King's entry into Scotland, ≈øubmits, and is ≈øent Pri≈øoner into England. However, the Scots being gotten together under Wallace their Head, the King pur≈øued his Enterprize; gave them a total Rout at a place
call'd Fenkirk; and having aboli≈øh'd their ancient Laws, return'd, and brought all their Records, and other Evidences of Antiquity with him, 1299. On this, Robert Bruce, Son of Robert the Competitor, gets into Scotland, where he is received and Crown'd, 1306. Is defeated by the Earl of Pembroke, 1307. Bruce recovers new Forces; the King re-enters Scotland, and dies of a Flux, July 7. the ≈øame Year, being the Sixty eighth of his Age, and Thirty fifth of his Reign. His fir≈øt Wife was Eleanor, Daughter of Ferdinand III. King of Ca≈øtile, by whom he had nine Daughters:
1. Eleanor, married to John Earl of Bar.
2. Joan, to Gilbert Earl of Glouce≈øter,
3. Margaret, to John Duke of Brabant.
4. Mary, a Nun of Amsbury.
5. Elizabeth, to John Earl of Holland; and after him, to Humphrey Bohun Earl of Hereford. The re≈øt died young.
Of his Four Sons,

Only Edward ≈øurviv'd him, and was the fir≈øt Prince of Wales. His ≈øecond Wife was Margaret, elde≈øt Daughter of Philip the Bold, King of France; by whom he had two Sons:
1. Thomas of Brotherton, Lord Mar≈øhal of England, and Earl of Norfolk.
2. Edmond, Earl of Kent; beheaded 1328. for endeavouring the Re≈øtauration of his depo≈øed Brother King Edward II.

X. Edward II. born at Carnarvan 1285. created Prince of Wales, March 15. 1304. Crowned Feb. 24. 1307. In 1308. he cau≈øed all the Knights Templars throughout England and Ireland, to be apprehended, and their Order
to be di≈ø≈øolv'd; as afterwards were the Knights of Rhodes by King Henry VIII. 1540. and thei ‚Ä¢ Lands and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions ≈øeiz'd. He ≈øeems to have come in with much Expectation, but ≈øoon lo≈øt it, by means of a Favourite of his, Pierce Gave≈øton, bani≈øh'd by his Father, but re call'd by him, and made Earl of Cornwal, Lord of Man, and High Chamberlain; which ≈øo incen≈øed the Nobility, that the King is forc'd to bani≈øh him more than once; but as often re-calling him. They take Arms under Thomas Earl of Lanca≈øter their Leader, Son of Edmond, ≈øecond Son of King Henry III. (whom the Mobb call'd King Arthur) and having taken him at Scarborough Ca≈øtle, ≈øtrike off his Head, 1312. During this Di≈øorder at home, Bruce was become powerful in Scotland; the King enters upon him with a va≈øt Army, and is totally routed by him, at a place call'd Bannock-Bourn, 1314. This (and his making Hugh Spencer Earl of Glouce≈øter, Son of Hugh Spencer Earl of Winche≈øter, Succe≈ø≈øor in the Office and Favour of the ≈øaid Gave≈øton) ≈øo heightned the former Di≈øcontent, which was in a manner allay'd, that both ≈øides arm anew: But the King gets the better, takes the Earl of Lanca≈øter, and beheads him before his own Ca≈øtle of Pomfret, 1322. Yet this la≈øted not long; for having ≈øent the Queen and his Son the Prince into France, in≈øtead of accommodating Matters, ≈øhe contracts her Son to Philippa, Daughter of William III. Earl of Hainault, by who≈øe and the Earl of Holland's a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, ≈øhe returns with an Army, and with her the Prince, and Roger Mortimer Lord of Wigmore, lately e≈øcaped out
of the Tower of London; but afterwards made Earl of the Marches of Wales, by King Edward III. And having taken Bri≈øtol, with Hugh Spencer the Father in it, ≈øhe cau≈øed him to be hanged and quartered (without Trial) 1326. The King, Spencer the Son, and others, had put to Sea for Ireland; but were beaten upon the Coa≈øt of Wales, where they lay hid for a while in the Abbey of Neth; but being di≈øcovered. Spencer had the ≈øame fate with his Father. The King was impri≈øon'd, and a Parliament call'd to meet at London; where (upon ≈øeveral Articles exhibited again≈øt him) it is agreed to depo≈øe him as unfit to Govern, and elect the Prince his Son. Upon which, he voluntarily re≈øign'd his Crown to him, 1327. in the Nineteenth Year of his Reign. About eight Months after which, he was mo≈øt barbarou≈øly murdered in Berkley Ca≈øtle, in the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ty third Year of his Age. His Wife was „Äà‚óä„Äâ , Laughter of Philip the Fair; by whom ‚Ä¢ he had,
1. Joan, married to David Prince of Scotland.
2. Eleanor, to the Dake of Gelders.
And two Sons.

list.item: 1. Edward, born at Wind≈øor, 1313. ≈øet up to the Crown, his Father yet living.
2. John of Eltham, created Earl of Cornwal, 1315. and died in the flower of his Youth in Scotland.

div.p:
XI. Upon the Re≈øignation of Edward II. his Son Edward III. of the Age of Fourteen Years, began his Reign Jan. 20. 1327, and was Crown'd the 25th. following. The Queen
≈øeems heavy at it; but being pacified by a ‚Ä¢ Augmentation of Joynture, the management of A≈ø≈øairs is committed to five Bi≈øhops, and ≈øeven Temporal Lords, 'till the King were or Years to Govern; but the Queen and Mortimer act all. The Scots enter England, and are ≈øuffer'd to e≈øcape; and in 1328. a di≈øhone≈øt rable Peace is made with them: To confirm which, Joan, the King's Si≈øter, is married to David Pruce Prince of Scotland; and among≈øt other things, the Ragman Roll, and Black-Cro≈ø ‚Ä¢
of Scotland, are given back to them; and the King, by the working of the Queen and M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
timer, ≈øurrenders his Title to the Soveraignty of Scotland, and all Evidences relating thereunto: For which, Mortimer is impeach'd is Parliament, and hang'd at Tyburn. Nor la≈øter the Peace long; for Edward Baliol, Son of the afore≈øaid John Baliol, ≈øets up for that Crown and by King Edward's A≈ø≈øi≈øtance recovers it and does him Homage, and ≈øwears Fealty for it, 1333. And now there happening ≈øome di≈øgu≈øt between him and Philip de Valois King of France, he bethinks him≈øelf of his Title to th ‚Ä¢ Crown, in right of I≈øabel his Mother; „Äà‚óä„Äâ which, the Bani≈øhment of Robert de Artois by King Philip his Brother, who fled for ≈øafety to him, gave him a fair Opportunity. Nor was he wanting to it; for he not only receiv'd him joy ‚Ä¢ ully, but made him Earl of Richmend and of his Council, 1336. which he liv'd not long to enjoy, for after ≈øix years ≈øerving him in France, he was wounded at the Siege of Vanner, and brought to England, where he died, 1342. The Year following he in≈øtituted the Order of
the Garter, and created his elde≈øt Son Edward Prince of Wales. In July, 1346. he enters Normandy with a mighty Army, and takes the Prince with him, who (not full Sixteen) fought the Battel of Cre≈ø≈øy in Picardy, on St. Bartholomew's Day, the ≈øame Year; and obtain'd ≈øo great a Victory, that Callice was forthwith be≈øieg'd, and ≈øurrender'd Aug. 3. 1347. On which, the King took the Title and Arms of France, and return'd for England, where the Prince; Electors ≈øignifie to him, That they had cho≈øen him King of the Romans; which he refu≈øed. In the Year 1356. the Prince goes over again, fights the Battel of Poictiers in Poictou, and takes John the French King Pri≈øoner, Septemb. 19. the ≈øame Year: Returns for England, brings the ≈øaid King with him; whence he was not deliver'd 'till 1360. at what time, an Accord had been made on his behalf at Britigny near Chartres. During this Ce≈ø≈øation with France, the Prince of Wales, accompanied with his Brother John of Gaunt, Duke of Lanca≈øter, relieves Peter King of Ca≈øtile and Leon, expuls'd by his Ba≈øtard-Brother Henry, and re≈øtor'd him, 1367. But little of the Accord with France being perform'd, the King (upon his return) ≈øends the Prince into Acquitain, and in a ≈øhort time the ≈øaid Duke John, and his younger Brother, Edmond Earl of Cambridge, to aid him; to whom (his Health failing him) he left the profecution of the War, and return'd him≈øelf, 1371. Nor did his Brother John much after him, ≈øave that coming for England, he (by rea≈øon of the Prince's ≈øickne≈øs) wholly manag'd his aged Father; which being taken notice
of by ≈øome of the Prince's Friends, he is ban ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ 'd the Court. Not long after which, the Prince died, 1375 being the Forty ninth of his Father's Reign, and Forty ≈øixth of his Age. His Wi≈øe was Joan, Daughter of Edmond Earl of Kent, his Father's Brother; by whom he had,
1. Edward, born at Angoule≈øm, and died young.
2. Richard, born at Bourdeaux, who ≈øucceeded his Grandfather.

As al≈øo two Natural Sons:
1. Sir John Sounder.
2. Sir Reger Clarendon, put to death by Henry IV. for endeavouring the Re≈øtauration of his ≈øaid Brother Richard, 1402.

And now after the Prince's death, the Duke of Lanca≈øter came in play again, and openly favour'd John Wickliffe, to the great di≈øturbance of the State; and therefore le≈øt he might do by Richard of B ‚Ä¢ urdeaux, as Earl John had done by his Nephew Arthur, the King providently ≈øetled the Succe≈ø≈øion, in Parliament, upon the ≈øaid Richard, creating him fir≈øt Earl of Che≈øte and C ‚Ä¢ rnwal, and then Prince of Wales; and died June 21. 1377. in the Sixty fourth Year of his Age, and Fiftieth of his Reign. He had to Wi≈øe Philippa of Haynault, who bore him

Have Daughters:
1. I≈øabel, married to Ingelram, Lord of Coue ‚Ä¢ . Earl of S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ns and Bedford; afterwards, Archduke of Au≈øtria.
2. Joan, to Alphon≈øo II. of Ca≈øtile, by Proxy, but die before it was con≈øummated.
3. Mary, to John Men≈øerd Duke of Bretagne
4. Margaret, to John Ha≈øtings Earl of Pembr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; but died without I≈ø≈øae.
5. Al≈øo another Daughter Blanch, who died young.
And ≈øeven Sons.

list.item: 1. Edward, ≈øurnamed The Black Prince, of whom before.
2. William, ≈øurnamed Of Hatfield, the Place of his Birth. He died young.

3. Lionel, born at Antwerp, 1338. made Earl of Ul≈øter in Ireland, in right of his Wi≈øe Elizabeth, Daughter of William Burgh Earl of Ul≈øter; with whom al≈øo he had the Honour of Clare in the County of Thoumond, in that Kingdom, and thence created Dake of Clarence. She brought him one Daughter only,

div.p: Philippa, married to Edmond Mortimer Eail of March, Mother of Reger Earl of March, Father of Anne Counte≈øs of Cambridge, Grandmother of King Edward IV.

4 John, ≈øurnamed Of Gaunt, where he was hom, 1342. Created Duke of Lanca≈øter, 1352. He had three Wives: 1. Blanch, Daughter and Heir of Henry Earl of Lanca≈øter, Son of Edmond Crouch back, younge≈øt Son of King Henry III. as before; by whom he had
Henry of Bullenbrook, Earl of Derby, who u≈øurp'd upon Richard II. and was the fir≈øt of the Lanca≈øtrian Kings.

His ≈øecond Wi≈øe was Con≈øtance, elde≈øt Daughter of Peter King of Ca≈øtile and
Leon, in who≈øe Right he bore the ≈øame Title, and had by her
Catharine, who≈øe Po≈øterity became Kings of Spain in her Right.

His third Wife was Catharine, Widow of Sir Hugh Swinford, an Engli≈øh Knight, elde≈øt Daughter and Co heir of Pain Red (Guien King at Arms); her younger Sifter married Sir Jeoffry Chaucer, the Engli≈øh Laureat. He had by her, before Marriage, ≈øeveral Children, ≈øurnamed De Beaufort, from a Ca≈øtle of his in France of that Name, where they were born: In regard of which, they gave a Portcullis for their Cogni≈øance, and were all of them legitimated in Parliament, 1397. with this Clau≈øe neverthele≈øs, Excepting the Reg Dignity. As,
1. John, fir≈øt Knighted, and afterwards created Earl of Somer≈øet, 1398.
2. Henry, afterwards Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, Cardinal of St. Eu≈øebius, and Chancellor of England.
3. Thomas, fir≈øt created Earl of Dor≈øet, 1398. and afterwards Duke of Exeter, 1414.
4. And one Daughter Joan; fir≈øt married to Ralph Nevil Baron of Wemm; created afterwards the fir≈øt Earl of We≈øt m ‚Ä¢ rland: And after him, to Robert Ferrers Lord of Ow≈øeley.

5. Edmond of Langley; born 1342. created Earl of Cambridge, 1362. Duke of York, 1386. He was the fir≈øt that gave the White Ro≈øe; and died 1402. His Wife
was I≈øabella, younge≈øt Daughter of the ≈øaid Peter King of Ca≈øtile; by whom he had
Richard Plantagenet, Earl of Cambridge; married to Anne Mortimer, Daughter of Roger Earl of March; by whom he had

Richard Duke of York, ≈ølain at the Battel of Wakefield, 1460. Father of,
1. Edward, Duke of York, who recover'd the Crown from King Henry VI.
2. George Duke of Clarence.
3. Richard Duke of Glouce≈øter, afterwards King.
6. William of Wind≈øor, who died young.

7. Thomas of Wood≈øtock; a Man valiant and wi≈øe. He was created Earl of Buckingham, 1376. then Duke of Glouce≈øter, by Richard II. and at la≈øt treacherou≈øly made away (≈øome ≈øay ≈øtrangled) at Callice, 1397.

XII. Richard II. born at Bourdeaux, 1367. ≈øucceeded his Grandfather, and was Crown'd July 16. 1377. in the 11th Year of his Age. The Care of him was fir≈øt committed to certain Bi≈øhops and Earls, and la≈øtly to Thomas Beauchamp Earl of Warwick, 1379. In the Year 1382. John Ball, a Prie≈øt, and Di≈øciple of Wickliffe, with one Watt Tyler a Taylor, and others, work the Common People into a Rebellion; murder Simon de Sudbury Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, and ≈øeveral of the Nobility; and with a numerous Rabble come at la≈øt to Smithfield by Landon, where Sir VVilliam VVallw ‚Ä¢ rth. then Lord Mayor, upon ≈øome rude Language given
the King by the ≈øaid Tyler, ≈øtabb'd him dead, and therewith di≈øpers'd the Rabble: In memory of which, the King gave the City the Augmentation of a Bloody Dagger to their Co ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ n the Year 1366. Henry
„Äà‚óä„Äâ of Derby, Son of John of Gaunt, was created Duke of Hereferd; and being accus'd by
„Äà‚óä„Äâ M ‚Ä¢ ubrey Duke of Norfolk, of ≈øome dangerous Words by him „Äà‚óä„Äâ , demanded a Trial by Battel, which was accepted; and both being in the Li≈øts ready in combat, Hereford was ban ‚Ä¢ th'd for ten Years (of which the King ≈øtruck oft four) and went „Äà‚óä„Äâ
France: And the Year following Johne Gaunt died. In 1399, the King went into Ireland; and in his ab≈øence, Thomas Arundel Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, and others, contrive to depo≈øe him, and ≈øet up Henry, now Duke of Lanca≈øter; who upon their Invitation, return'd, and met the King in VVales, from whence he was convey'd to the Tower of London; where a Parliament being in the mean time call'd in King Richard's Name, the King re≈øign'd his Crown to the ≈øaid Henry, and made the Bi≈øhops of York and Hereford his Procurators, to declare his Re≈øignation to the Parliament; which was accepted: And (to colour the matter) Articles were pre≈øer ‚Ä¢ ed again≈øt him, on which he was depo≈øed, Septemb. 9. 1399. and afterwards trait „Äà‚óä„Äâ murdered in Pomfret Ca≈øtle, 1401. by Sir Pierce Exten, and eight others (as he was at D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er) of whom yet he ≈ølew four; in the Thirty third Year of his Age, and Twenty ≈øec ‚Ä¢ nd of his Reign. His fir≈øt Wife was Anne, Daughter of Charles IV. Emperour. His ≈øecond, I≈øabel, Daughter of Charles VI. King
of France; but had no I≈ø≈øue by either of them.

XIII. ¬ß. VI. Upon this Depo≈øition, Henry
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ke of Lanca≈øter, elde≈øt Son of John of Gaunt, tourth Son of Edward III. Born 1368. was Crown'd King Octch. 13. 1399. by the Name of King Henry IV. albeit Edmond Mortimer Earl of March, Son of Roger Mortimer Earl of March, Son and Heir of Philippa, Daughter and Heir of
‚Ä¢ iond, third Son of King Edward III. was then living: and the ≈øaid Earl R ‚Ä¢ ger his Father, upon King Richard's going into Ireland, in the Year 1385. had been declared in Parliament Heir Apparent to the Crown, if the ≈øaid Richard died without I≈ø≈øue. This occa≈øioned tho≈øe bloody Wars between the Hou≈øes of York and Lanca≈øter, in which there were Twelve pitch'd Battels fought between them, in the compa≈øs of Thirty ≈øix Years. The beginning of his Reign was ≈øull of Troubles; for Thomas Merks Bi≈øhop of Carli≈øle, made a Speech in Parliament in favour of Richard the depo≈øed King; for which, albeit he was impri≈øon'd, yet it ≈øo ≈øtuck with the Nobility, that ≈øix of the Chief of them combine to ≈øeize King Henry, and re≈øtore King Richard; and to that purpo≈øe, undertook a ≈øolemn Ju≈øting to he held at Oxford, in the Chri≈ømas 1401. and invited the King to it; which he accepted. but the Plot being accidentally di≈øcovered by one of the Con≈øpirators, it was ≈øea≈øonably prevented and cru≈øh'd. Nor was it long are Owen Glendour ro≈øe in VVales, 1400. and declared for Edmond Mortimer. The like did the Earls of Northumberland and Worce≈øter
in the North; who before they could join Forces, were beaten by the exemplary Courage of Prince Henry his Son, 1403. The King at la≈øt having wrought through every thing that oppos'd him, died of an Apoplexy, March 20. 1413. in the Forty ≈øixth Year of his Age and Fourteenth of his Reign. His fir≈øt Wife was Mary, one of the Daughters and Co-heirs of Humphrey de Bohun Earl of Hereford, E≈ø≈øex, and Northampton; ≈øhe died before he came to the Crown, 1394. but left him four Sons:
1. Henry V. who ≈øucceeded him.
2. Thomas Duke of Clarence, ≈ølain at Beaufort in France; but left no I≈ø≈øue.

The Parliament on this openly declar'd for his Title; but in regard Henry had been taken as King for Thirty eight Years, it was conde≈øcended, That he ≈øhould hold the Title and Name of King, and have the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Realm during his natural Life; but if he either died, re≈øign'd, or forfeited the ≈øame, by breaking or going again≈øt any Point of that Accord; that then the ≈øaid Crown and Regal Authority, ≈øhould be immediately devolved, and come to the Duke of York, if he were then living: Or in ca≈øe he died, to the next Heir of his Lineage: And that the Duke of York ≈øhould from thenceforth be Protector and Regent of the Land. XVII. Edward V. ≈øucceeded his Father in Title, though not in the Crown; for being not above Thirteen Years of Age at the death of his Father, Sir Anthony VVoodvile, Lord Rivers, his Mother's Brother, was appointed Governour to him, and (with Richard Gray Marque≈øs of Dor≈øet, his Half-brother by the Mother) ≈øent to conduct him from Ludlow (where he then was) to London: And on this, the Duke of Glouce≈øter his Uncle, lays the Foundation of his de≈øign'd U≈øurpation; and in order to it, there having been ≈øome ≈øecret Grudge between Edward Duke of Buckingham his Creature, and VVilliam Lord Ha≈øtings, then Lord Chamberlain, both Enemies of the Queen's; he fir≈øt reconciles them, and then rells them how unrea≈øonable it was that the young King their Ma≈øter, ≈øhould be in the hands of his Mother's Kinred (a new Nobility) a thing neither Honourable to his Maje≈øty, nor them. Whereupon it is agreed, That they be remov'd, as Enemies. On this, Glouce≈øter and Buckingham meet the King (with all Obedience) at Stony Stratford, and having
≈øecur'd the Lord Rivers and Dor≈øet (whom they ≈øhortly after beheaded at Powfret) bring him to London, May 4. 1483. the Queen (upon hearing what had pa≈øs'd) having, with her younger Son and Daughters, taken ≈øanctuary at We≈øtmin≈øter. However, at la≈øt, what with the A≈ø≈øurance of ≈øeveral of the Privy Council for his ≈øafety, and Threats of forcing the Sanctuary for him, he is deliver'd to the Protector; who with all ≈øeeming joy, brings him to the King his Brother, into the Bi≈øhop of London's Palace at St. Paul's; and thence honourably through the City (for the King's ≈øecurity, as was given out) until his Coronation. The Protector all along had made his re≈øidence near the Tower; and having ≈øo tangled Buckingham that he could not ≈øafely get off, he comes to the point with him; on which it is agreed between them, That the Protector ≈øhould have the Duke's aid to make him King; and that the Protector's Son ≈øhould marry the Duke's Daughter, with a Grant to him≈øelf of the Earldom of Hereford, which he claimed as his Inheritance; but could never obtain it in King Edward's time. Whereupon, Buckingham undertakes for the City, with whom he was not the lea≈øt popular. The King now having his Court in the Tower, the Council meet there for ordering the Solemnity of his Coronation; which was carried on with ≈øuch forwardne≈øs, and the Day appointed for it ≈øo near at hand,
that all Mi≈øtru≈øt was (vi≈øibly) ≈øet a≈øide; 'till the Protector (having pump'd the Lord Chamberlain by his Friend Catesby, and finding no good to be done on him) came into the Council, June 13. and knitting his Brows, arre≈øted him as a Traitor; for that he, with his Brother's Wife the Queen, had attempted his Life by Sorcery. And therewith giving a knock, a Guard came in, who by the Protector's Command, forthwith carried him out, and ≈øtruck off his Head; and ≈øeverally ≈øecur'd the re≈øt of the Council. Whereupon, ≈øending for ≈øome of the Chief of the City, he made them a fair Tale, How him≈øelf and the Duke of Buckingham were to have been de≈øtroy'd in Council, by a Con≈øpiracy of the Lord Chamberlain's: And returns them with an Herauld, and a Proclamation in the King's Name to ≈øatisfie the People. There was at that time one Sir Edmond Shaw, Lord Mayor of London, who (upon promi≈øe of advancement) had been made to their Party; as al≈øo one Doctor John Shaw, Brother to the Mayor, and Doctor John Penker, Provincial of the Augu≈øtine Friars; both noted Preachers, but of more Fame, than either Vertue or Learning: And the≈øe are the Men mu≈øt make that Go≈øpel to the People, which Catesby had undertaken for Law to the Kingdom. And having receiv'd their In≈øtructions accordingly, Shaw begins at St. Paul's Cro≈øs the Sunday after, where upon that Text (Spuria Vitulamina, &c) The Ba≈øtard-Slips ≈øhall not take root; he ≈øignify'd to the People, That not only King Edward IV. and his Brother George Duke of Clarence, were not the very Sons of Richard Duke of York, but begotten
in Adultery on the Dutche≈øs their Mother: But that the now King Edward, and his Brother Richard Duke of York, were both Ba≈øtards, ina≈ømuch as their Father King Edward IV. at the time that he married the Lady Elizabeth Gray their Mother, was precontracted to the Lady Elizabeth Lucy, who was his lawful Wife before God. Then turning his Di≈øcour≈øe to the Protector and his Title, render'd him the expre≈øs Image of the Noble Duke his Father, and the very Right Heir of his Body begotten. Yet all this took ≈øo little with the People, that Penker was re≈øerv'd 'till after the Coronation; at which time he ≈øo lo≈øt his Voice, that he was forc't to come down in the mid≈øt of his Sermon. The Tue≈øday following, the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commoners being a≈ø≈øembled in the Guild-Hall, the Duke of Buckingham came among them; and having rak'd together whatever could be thought of again≈øt King Edward IV. and his Government, he recapitulated Shaw's Sermon, magnified the Protector and his Title, to them; and concluded from the whole (Vae Regno, &c.) Wo to that Realm that hath a Child to its King. Neither had this al≈øo any effect upon them, 'till a pack'd Company at the other end of the Hall, throwing up their Bonnets, and crying King Richard! King Richard! the Mayor took it by the end, and ≈øaid it was ≈øo goodly and joyful to hear ≈øo full a Cry, and no one gain≈øaying it, that he would repre≈øent it to the Protector the next Morning; which (accompanied with all the Aldermen and Chief Commoners of the City in their Formalities, and conducted by the Duke of Buckingham) he accordingly
did: And the Protector (Good Man) ≈øo utterly refus'd, that they began to be afraid he was in earne≈øt; 'till at la≈øt Good Nature prevail'd, and he enclin'd to their Petition, and took upon him the King≈øhip, June 22. 1483. which is the ≈øum of the three Months and nineteen Days Reign of King Edward V. XVIII. After this Mock-Election, Richard III. now no longer Protector, was Crown'd King, July 6. following, with the ≈øelf-≈øame Provi≈øion that was appointed for the Coronation of his Nephew; with this addition only, That his Queen was Crown'd with him. The

(whereof 26 had Place and Voice among the Peers) Colleges
90. Chauntries and Free-Chappels 2374. Ho≈øpitals 110. But having (by the leave of Queen Elizabeth) gotten Henry Lord Darnly, Son of Matthew Stuart Earl of Lenox, by Margaret Douglas, Niece of Henry VIII. by his elde≈øt Si≈øter, out of England (upon pretence of re≈øtoring him to the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of his Father, who had been in England as an Exile now twenty years, made him Lord Armanack, Earl of Ro≈øs, and Duke of Roth≈øey, a Dukedom by Birth appertaining to the elde≈øt Sons of the Kings of Scotland, married him in five Months after, and with the Con≈øent of mo≈øt of the Peers of Scotland, declar'd him King, about June 1565. A Per≈øon of a Princely Pre≈øence, and not above Nineteen Years of Age.

The Prior of St. Andrew's, the Queen's ba≈øe Brother, but one, that more affecting a Temporal Honour, than a Spiritual Title, had been made Earl of Murray, had under-hand dealt with Queen Elizabeth, to have prevented this Marriage; in excu≈øe of which, the Queen was let know, She had no rea≈øon to be di≈øplea≈øed with it, ina≈ømuch as ≈øhe had follow'd her Advice, Not to marry a Stranger, but an Engli≈øhman
born. Nor (perhaps) was Queen Elizabeth much troubled at it, as knowing the mild Di≈øpo≈øition of the Lord Darnly, and how little of Strength it added to the Queen of Scots; but, on the contrary, fore≈øeeing it would beget Troubles in Scotland, which was the Security of England. However it were, the Queen of Scots being brought to Bed of a Son, June 19. 1566. ≈øhe ≈øent Queen Elizabeth notice of it, who congratulated her ≈øafe Deliverance, and her Son, and was his Godmother; and by her, and the re≈øpective Amba≈ø≈øadours of Charles King of France, and Philibert Duke of Savoy, gave him the Name of Charles James, in whom afterwards, in Right of his ≈øaid Mother, the Crowns of England and Scotland came to be united.

Murray thus di≈øappointed where he lea≈øt expected, complies with the pre≈øent, and ≈øtrikes in with the yet Inadvertency of the young King, and makes a Divi≈øion between the Queen and him; which his In≈øtruments ≈øo improv'd with her, that whereas before in publick Acts ≈øhe had u≈øed to place her Husband's Name fir≈øt, ≈øhe now cau≈øed it to be placed la≈øt; and in her Coin, began to leave it out quite. Nor was the Breach yet ≈øo wide, but it might have been clos'd again, had not Murray created a Jealou
‚Ä¢ ie in him concerning one David Rizie (an Italian) the Queen's Secretary and told him plainly it ≈øtood not with his Honour to ≈øuffer him to live; which ≈øo netled the King, that ru≈øhing one Evening into the Queen's Chamber when ≈øhe was at Supper, he cau≈øed the ≈øaid Rizie to be dragg'd out of her pre≈øence, and murder'd,
of which afterwards the King grew ≈øo ≈øen≈øible, that he threatned a Revenge upon Murray, who had coun≈øell'd him to it; which the other prevented in ≈øtriking the fir≈øt Blow, by procuring the King to be ≈øtrangled in his Bed, his Body thrown into the Garden, and the Hou≈øe immediately blown up; the Queen, whatever the Rumour of the People were, lea≈øt doubitng her Brother Murray. And here comes his Ma≈øter-piece.

The Earls of Bothwell and Morton, had been his Confederates in the Murder; and when the Days of Mourning were a little over, Murray, by him≈øelf and his In≈øtruments, in≈øinuates to her the danger of the Kingdom by her being thus left alone, and advi≈øes her to marry ≈øome one that might be able to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her again≈øt all her Oppo≈øers; and after ≈øome time, recommends Bothwell to her, a Per≈øon in favour with her, and of great Eminence for his Valour: To which, being de≈øtitute of Friends, ≈øhe at la≈øt con≈øents, provided due re≈øpect might be had to her young Son, and that Bothwell legally acquit him≈øelf of her Husband's Murder. Whereupon Bothwell ≈øtands his Trial, and is acquitted by his Judges: On which, the Queen makes him Duke of Orkney, and by Con≈øent of many of the Nobility, marries him, 1567. And now Murray is where he would be; for having, during Queen Mary's abode in France, by his Patriarch Knox, and his Chaplain Buchannan, (under PRETENCE of Reformation) embroil'd the Kingdom, by affirming, That Royalty was not tied to any Stock or Kindred, but Vertue only, whether the Parties were legitimate
or not; thereby making way to the Kingdom for him≈øelf; and not being able to have hindred the Queen's ≈øecond Marriage, made a Di≈øcord between her and him, whom he afterwards murder'd; this Murray, the ≈øame Man that had acquitted Bothwell, and not only advis'd, but promoted his Marriage with the Queen, now takes Arms again≈øt her, as privy to Bothwell's Murder of her Husband. On this, Bothwell finding him≈øelf out-witted, flies into Denmark; and Murray ≈øeizes the Queen, and vilely threw her into Pri≈øon in Loch-levyn, under the Cu≈øtody of his Mother, the Concubine of James V. but now boa≈øting her≈øelf to have been his Wife, and her Son his lawful I≈ø≈øue. During which time, Knox and his Di≈øciples thunder again≈øt her from the Pulpits: Buchannan, with his De Jure Regni apud Scotos, and Murray with his armed Logick ≈øo terrifie her, that ≈øhe re≈øign'd her Kingdom to her Son, ≈øcarce Thirteen Months old, and made Murray Regent of Scotland during his Minority; alledging to Queen Elizabeth for her ≈øo doing, That ≈øhe had done it through the Coun≈øel of her-Amba≈ø≈øadour Throckmorton, who told her, That a Grant extorted from one in Pri≈øon (which is a ju≈øt Fear) is actually void, and of none effect. However, on this the young King was Crown'd, and Murray proclaim'd Regent; but the Queen ≈øtill kept in Pri≈øon; from whence (after Eleven Months impri≈øonment) by the help of one of the Douglas's, ≈øhe makes an e≈øcape to Hamilton-Ca≈øtle, where, in a meeting of a great part of the Nobility, this extorted Re≈øignation of the Queen's, is declar'd actually void from the beginning.
Whereupon Multitudes flock in to her; but being undi≈øciplin'd, they are defeated by Murray; Her≈øelf neverthele≈øs making an e≈øcape into England, landed at Wickington in Cumberland, May 17. 1568. having fir≈øt ≈øent her Servant Beaton to Queen Elizabeth, to intimate her Intention; with a Diamond Ring al≈øo, which ≈øhe had formerly receiv'd from her, as a Pledge of mutual Amity. Nor was ≈øhe ≈øooner landed than ≈øhe wrote her a Letter, thereby declaring her Condition; and withal de≈øiring ≈øhe might be conducted to her Pre≈øence. To which, Queen Elizabeth, by a Letter ≈øent by Sir Francis Knolles, return'd her a comfortable An≈øwer, and promi≈øed her Aid and Defence, according to the Equity of her Cau≈øe; but deny'd her acce≈øs, for that ≈øhe was held guilty of many Crimes; and therefore order'd her to be brought to Carli≈øle. From thence ≈øhe ≈øeconded her fir≈øt Letter, further praying, That ≈øhe might have leave to unfold the Injuries ≈øhe had receiv'd, and an≈øwer the Crimes objected in her pre≈øence; withal alledging, It was but rea≈øonable that the Queen ≈øhould hear her, and re≈øtore her to her Kingdom, again≈øt tho≈øe, whom when they liv'd in exile for their Offences again≈øt her, ≈øhe had fully re≈øtor'd at the Queen's Interce≈ø≈øion, but to her own undoing, if not prevented in time. La≈øtly, be≈øeeching her, That ≈øhe might have admittance to her, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from her, or depart out of the Kingdom with her leave, to crave aid el≈øewhere, fora≈ømuch as ≈øhe came into it of her own accord, as relying upon her Love, ≈øo often honourably promis'd, by Letters,
Me≈ø≈øages, and Tokens. Upon this, the Queen commi≈øerating her Condition, could have found in her Heart to have re≈øtor'd her, had the Council thought it ≈øtood with the Queen's ≈øecurity: And therefore the Que≈øtion was, What ≈øhould be done with her? To detain her in England, it was to be fear'd tho≈øe that favour'd her Title to the Crown, would leave nothing unattempted to ≈øet it on her Head: And moreover, the Tru≈øt of Keepers was very uncertain: To ≈øend her for France, the Gui≈øes (her Kindred) were too powerful; and to return her into Scotland, tho≈øe that favour'd the Engli≈øh would be put from their Places; the French advanc'd; the young King expos'd to danger; the Religion chang'd; Ireland invaded by the Highlanders; and Queen Elizabeth in hazard at home: And therefore it was thought be≈øt to detain her, 'till ≈øhe had given ≈øatisfaction for u≈øurping the Title and Arms of England, and an≈øer'd for the Death of the Lord Darnly, a Native Subject of the Queen's. Yet it had this effect, That the Queen ≈øent to Murray and his Confederates, to come and an≈øwer the Queen of Scots's Complaints, and give ≈øufficient Rea≈øons why they had depriv'd her, or that ≈øhe would re≈øtore her. On which, Murray with ≈øeven others came to York (the Place appointed) and were the ≈øame Day met by the Duke of Norfolk, and two others, Commi≈ø≈øioners for Queen Elizabeth: But the Queen of Scots di≈ødaining to be heard by her Subjects, or any thing le≈øs than the Queen her ≈øelf, nothing came of it but Words: And Murray return'd to his Regency;
but riding through Lithquo, was ≈øhot dead by a Hamilton, 1569. In who≈øe room was elected, by the Lords of Scotland, the before-mention'd Matthew Earl of Lenox, the young King's Grandfather. And now frequent applications having been made to Queen Elizabeth, by the Amba≈ø≈øadours of France and Spain, for the Delivery of the Queen of Scots, but without effect, ≈øhe was Excommunicated by Pope Pius V. Feb. 24. the ≈øame Year; which occa≈øion'd her many Troubles, and at la≈øt the death of the Queen of Scots; who after an Eighteen Years impri≈øonment, was arraign'd, tried, and ≈øentenc'd (by '≈øpecial Commi≈ø≈øion) at Fotheringham-Ca≈øtle; for that pretending a Title to the Crown of England, ≈øhe was privy and con≈øenting to ≈øeveral Trea≈øons, tending to the Inva≈øion of England, and the Hurt, Death, and De≈øtruction of the Queen, Octob. 25. 1586. And thereupon, Infe≈øto Regibus Exemplo (as ≈øays her Epitaph) ≈øecuri percutitur, Feb. 8. following, and Forty ≈øixth Year of her Age; albeit the King of France, and more particularly the King of Scots her Son, and ≈øeveral others, made ≈øtrong Interce≈ø≈øions to have ≈øav'd her. However, the Queen ≈øeems troubled at her Death, and lays it to the Incon≈øideratene≈øs of her Secretary Davy≈øon; and to that purpo≈øe ≈øent a Letter in excu≈øe of it (written with her own Hand) by Sir Robert Cary, whom the King refus'd to ≈øet foot in Scotland; and with much ado receiving his Letter, re call'd his Amba≈ø≈øadour, and breath'd nothing but Revenge. And yet the Queen gave not over; but ≈øending him the Sentence of the Star Chamber again≈øt Davy≈øon, and an
In≈øtrument ≈øigned by all the Judges; in which they averr, That the Sentence again≈øt the Queen of Scott, could in no wi≈øe prejudice his Right in the Succe≈ø≈øion; it ≈øo mollified, that he made a Vertue of Nece≈ø≈øity; and cho≈øe rather to wait with Patience th ‚Ä¢ n hazard all by an uncertain War with England.

And now come that Climacterical Year of the World (as A≈øtrologers call'd it) to wit, 1588, at what time (there being an actual Treaty then on foot between the Crowns of England and Spain, and Commi≈ø≈øioners on both ≈øides then ≈øitting upon it near O≈øtend, but made u≈øe of by the Prince of Parma, only to trifle away time, 'till the Spani≈øh Armada came upon the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt) Philip II. After which, the King of Scots, by her Amba≈ø≈øidour (Sir Robert Sidney) let the Queen know, That he had over-pa≈øs'd all Injuries, and de≈øired a ≈øincere and perfect Amity with her: And as an in≈øtance of it, not only married Anne, Daughter of Frederick II. upon the Queen's Reque≈øt, deliver'd back into Ireland, 1590. Nor was there after that any Solemnity of an Emba≈ø≈øie ever pa≈øs'd between them, but as occa≈øion offer'd, it was con≈øtantly di≈øpatch'd by a private Me≈ø≈øenger, 'till the day of her death; which the Scots had a long time impatiently expected, but believ'd never would be, while there was an Old Woman alive in England; tho' at la≈øt it came to pa≈øs, March 24. 1602. in the 69th. year of her Age, and 45th. of her Reign. But never married.

XXIV. ¬ß. VIII. To her ≈øucceeded James VI. Kiug of Scotland, Grandchild of James IV. King of Scotland, by Margaret, elde≈øt Daughter of Henry VII. King of England; who (the Male Line being extinct) had the indi≈øputable Title to the Crowns of England and Ireland; and was thereupon proclaim'd King of England, Scotland, and Ireland, the ≈øame Day that the Queen died: Of which he had fir≈øt notice by an un≈øent Me≈ø≈øenger, the before-mention'd Sir Robert Cary, whom (upon his coming into England) he ≈øome Years after made Baron Leppington: And upon a more ≈øolemn Addre≈øs from the Lords of the Council, came for England, and was (together with his Queen) Crown'd, July 25. 1603. being St. James's Day: A little before which, there having been ≈øeveral Emba≈ø≈øies made to Congratulate their Acce≈øs to the Crown, the King created a Standing Officer for the Reception and Introduction of Amba≈ø≈øadours, by the Name of Ma≈øter of the Ceremonies, with the yearly Fee of 200 l. of whom the fir≈øt was Sir Lewis Lakenor.
Nor had the King been ≈øcarce warm in his Throne, when the Lord Cobham, and others, were arraign'd and convicted of High-Trea≈øon, for a Con≈øpiracy to kill the King, rai≈øe a Rebellion, alter Religion, ≈øubvert the State, and procure an Inva≈øion; of which Sir Walter Raleigh (a mortal Enemy to Spain, and no Friend of the Scots) was one; and after a Fourteen Years reprieval (by the means of the Spani≈øh Lieger Gundomar) had his Head taken off upon the former Judgment, though there wanted not tho≈øe that thought it was Jure & Injuria. And now came on the Bu≈øine≈øs of Spain: As King of Scotland, the King was in Amity with Spain; as King of England, at War with it: And therefore finding him≈øelf under that double Circum≈øtance, he fir≈øt call'd in all Letters of Mart again≈øt the Spaniard, and not long after, concluded a Peace with them; to the Confirmation of which, Albertus and I≈øabella, Archdukes of Au≈øtria, were ≈øworn. And thus in Peace with all Chri≈øtendom, the King created his Second Son Charles Duke of Albany (then Four Years old) Duke of York, Jan. 2. 1604. with the yearly Fee of 40 l. payable by the Sheriff of York out of the I≈ø≈øues, &c. of that County.

The Year following was di≈øcover'd the Gun-Powder Trea≈øon Plot, which ended in the Attainder and Death of the Con≈øpirators; and was particularly congratulated by the King of Spain, and Archdukes of Au≈øtria. In the Year 1610. the King (having had an Aid of his Subjects to make his Son a Knight) created Prince Henry (now Seventeen Years of Age)
Prince of Wales; but he liv'd not long to enjoy it; for during the Treaty of a Marriage between Frederick Prince Palatine of the Rhine, with the Lady Elizabeth, the King's only Daughter, he ≈øell ≈øick, and died, Novemb. 6. 1612. However, the Marriage took effect, and was con≈øummated on St. Valentine's Day following: And Prince Charles created Prince of Wales, 1615. But hear the time the King had created his Son Henry Prince of Wales, he created a new Patent-Honour of de≈øcendible Knighthood, by the Name of Knights Baronets. The occa≈øion thus:

In the beginning of the King's Reign, Charles Lord Montjoy, Lord Deputy of Ireland, return'd for England, and brought over with him Hugh O Neal, Earl of Tyrone, who (Queen Elizabeth yet living) had ≈øubmitted him≈øelf to the Queen's Mercy, and whom the King pardon'd; and made proclamation, That he ≈øhould be treated with Re≈øpect and Honour. And yet in 1609. he goes off into Ireland; and with Tyrconnel and others, gets beyond-Sea, and ≈øollicites a new A≈ø≈øi≈øtance from foreign Princes; but having left ≈øeveral forfeited Lands behind them, in the Counties of Colerain, Tyrone, and Donegal, the King comes to Articles with the City of London for the planting and building the ≈øame: Which being accepted, the King by his Charter, 1611. erects the Ville of Derry into a City, and the Town of Colerain into a Mayor-Town; and, together with the ≈øaid forfeited Lands, con≈øolidates the whole into one County; by the Name of the County of London-Derry: And having by the ≈øame
Charter created a Body Politick of Twenty four Per≈øons (Twelve of them to be annually elected out of the Twelve Fir≈øt Companies of London) for the Government of the ≈øame, by the Name of The Society of the Governour and A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, London, of the New Plantation of Ul≈øter in the Realm of Ireland, grants the ≈øaid City, Town, County, and forfeited Lands, to the ≈øaid Society, and their Succe≈ø≈øors in perpetuity, under the yearly Rent of 205 l. And now to give Countenance to it, and put 200000 l. in his Pocket, without being beholden to his Subjects, he erected this new Honour; and for him, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, covenanted with each of them re≈øpectively, That they, and the Heirs Males of their Body, ≈øhould take Place next the younge≈øt Sons of Barons: That (by way of augmentation to their own Arms) they ≈øhould bear a part of O Neal's Arms; viz. in a Canton, or E≈øcutcheon Argent, a hand Dextre couped, Gules: And la≈øtly, ≈øtinted their Number to Two hundred Per≈øons; who≈øe I≈ø≈øue, as they chanc'd to fail, ≈øhould not be ≈øupplied with new Per≈øons, but the Order to run out. In which la≈øt Clau≈øe yet, the King covenanted for him≈øelf only, and left out his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors; tho' (if the printed Li≈øts be true) Him≈øelf made Two hundred and One. The King al≈øo, ≈øome time after, erected a like Order of Baronets of Nova Scotia; who in≈øtead of the ≈øaid Hand dextre couped, ≈øhould wear an Orange-colour'd Ribbon athwart their Shoulders (as Knights of the Bath their Red Ribbon) with a Medal, on which the Arms of Scotland were enamell'd, and a Pear-Pearl at the end of it; with this Motto: Faxment is hone≈øtae Gloria. But whether (be≈øides the advantage of another Plantation) he got as much by the one, as he did by the other, does not appear: Though this may be ≈øaid of both, All Parties were well ≈øatisfied. Nor happen'd there, during this time, any thing much remarkable, ≈øaving the breaking one Favourites Neck, to make way for another; the placing and di≈øplacing of Great Officers; the frequent Creations of Nobility; which though it added to their Number, may (perhaps) be thought to have taken from their Grandeur, and the Death of Queen Anne, which happen'd March 2. 1619.

The Pal≈øgrave Frederick thus ≈øtrengthen'd with the Alliance of England, was, in the Year 1621. elected King of Bohemia: Nor was he ≈øooner inve≈øted in the Crown, than the Imperial Bann i≈ø≈øued again≈øt him; which was ≈øo ≈øeconded with a longer Sword, that having lo≈øt the Battel of Prague, and with it his New Crown, and his own Patrimony of the Upper and Lower Palatinate, he was forc' to retire into Holland. to ≈øollicite the Re≈øtitution of the Palatinate; which returning without ≈øucce≈øs, he con≈øults Gundomar what to do in the matter; who advi≈øes him to make a Marriage with the Prince his Son, and the Infanta of Spain, Which (≈øaid he) would be ea≈øily effected, if the Prince might have leave to make a Journey into Spain. Which was accordingly done, and the Prince receiv'd with all the Kindne≈øs and Magnificence imaginable: Where having been ≈øpun out for eight Months together to no purpo≈øe (contrary to the Expectation of mo≈øt Men) he return'd ≈øafe into England. King of France; which took effect, but was not con≈øummated 'till after the Death of King James, which happen'd March 27. 1625. in the Fifty eighth Year of his Age, and of his Reign of England the Twenty ≈øecond, and of Scotland the Fifty ≈øixth. He had but one Wife, viz. Queen Anne, of whom before; and by her,
1. Henry Friderick Stuart, Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwal and Roth≈øey, and Earl of Che≈øter; born (in Scotland) Feb. 19. 1593. died Nov. 6. 1612.

XXV. To his Father (his elder Brother being dead) ≈øucceeded Charles, the Fir≈øt of that Name, about the Age of Twenty five Years, and was proclaim'd King the ≈øame Day his Father died: The Solemnity of who≈øe Funerals being over, the fir≈øt thing he did was to ha≈øten the coming over of the Queen, to whom he was married by Proxy at Paris, May 1. and con≈øummated at Canterbury, June 13. following. Of this Prince it may be truly ≈øaid, He was a Man of Sorrows: And yet, if there be any thing in Hi≈øtory to be named before him, it is not that He was le≈øs able, but their Times better.
