There had follow'd his Father, out of Scotland, Two Sorts of People; the One purely for the Loaves; the Other, to double the Intere≈øt of that Doctrine, that had forc'd his Mother out of Her Kingdom, who kept him≈øelf
≈øo long in Pupillage, and to which England was not ≈øo altogether a Stranger, but that they found the Lump leven'd to their hand. Some (like them) calling al≈øo them≈øelves the Lord's Amba≈ø≈øadours, and pretending a Right from God, to Govern every one his Pari≈øh, and their A≈ø≈øembly the whole Nation: Others (and tho≈øe different in Opinions among them≈øelves) that would have all Congregations free, and independent upon one another: Others, That held Chri≈øt's Per≈øonal Reign was at this time to begin upon Earth, and therefore would have no other King but King Je≈øus: Be≈øides ≈øeveral others (from the fir≈øt Litter) yet every of them de≈øending its Sect by Scripture, according to the narrow ≈øcantling of their own Interpretations. The≈øe again meeting with a Pur≈øe-proud City, a poor Crown, and a Gentry that no le≈øs affected a Popular Government in the State, than them≈øelves did in the Church; Both cry up Liberty, and inveigh again≈øt Tyranny (that is) whatever they were not them≈øelves. And ≈øo, what wonder of tho≈øe Con≈øequents that embroil'd the King's Reign! The ill Effects of which too many have ≈øeen, and may (perhaps) be felt the next Century.

However, the King having ≈øummon'd his Parliament to meet at We≈øtmin≈øter, June 18. afore≈øaid, he told them, That at their earne≈øt Entreaty, in March, 1623. his Father had taken Arms for the recovery of the Palatinate, which, with the Crown, was now devolv'd upon Him≈øelf: That the Supplies already given, held no
proportion with the Charge of the Enterprize: That the Eyes of all Europe were upon him; and a Failure in this his fir≈øt Attempt, would be a Blemi≈øh to his futare Honour: And therefore de≈øired them (if not for His, for their Own Reputation) to deliver him fairly out of that War, wherewith them≈øelves had incumbred him, by an expeditious Supply. On which, the Commons gave Two Sub≈øidies, and the Clergy Three; and the Parliament (by rea≈øon of the Plague) was adjourn'd to Oxford, to be held there Aug. 1. following; where the King briefly acquaints them with his Wants, in order to the de≈øign's Expedition. So that not agreeing who ≈øhould be fir≈øt tru≈øted, the King or Them≈øelves, the Parliament was di≈ø≈øolv'd, and another ≈øummon'd to meet at We≈øtmin≈øter the next 6th. of February. The Candlemas Day before which, the King was ≈øolemnly Crown'd.

But here al≈øo the King met no better ≈øucce≈øs than he had in his fir≈øt: For the Commons began, where they left at Oxford, with Religion and Grievances: And to add to it, it fell unfortunately, that the Earl of Bri≈øtal being under re≈øtraint, the King had ≈øent him no Writ of Summons to the Parliament; whereupon he petitions the Peers, That being a Peer of the Realm, he had not receiv'd a
Writ of Summons; and therefore pray'd the Benefit of his Peerage; and that if any Charge were again≈øt him, he might be Tried in Parliament. Upon which (and the Reque≈øt of the Peers) his Writ was ≈øent him, with a Letter from the Lord Keeper, That though his Maje≈øty had awarded him the Writ, yet „Äà‚óä„Äâ was his Plea≈øure that his Per≈øonal Attendance ≈øhould be forborn. This Letter the Earl ≈øent to the Lords, with a ≈øecond Petition, be≈øeeching to be heard, both as to his wrongful Re≈øtraint, and what he had to ≈øay Again≈øt the Duke of Buckingham. This alarm'd the Duke, whom the Commons already beheld with no good Eye; and therefore to begin with him fir≈øt, the Duke prevails with the King, to command the Attorney-General to Common him to the Lord's Barr, as a Delinquent; where he appear'd, May 1. and was by Mr. Attorney charg'd with Eleven Articles of High-Trea≈øon: But before they were read, the Earl ≈øaid, My Lords, I am a Free-man, and a Peer of the Realm unattainted: I have ≈øomewhat of high Con≈øequence to his Maje≈øty's Service, and be≈øeech your Lord≈øhips to give me leave to ≈øpeak. The Lords bade him go on. Then (≈øaid he) I accu≈øe that Man, the Duke of Buckingham. of High-Trea≈øon. And immediately pre≈øented Twelve Articles again≈øt him: After which, the Articles again≈øt the Earl being read, and him≈øelf committed to the Black-Rod, the Hou≈øe order'd, That the King's Charge again≈øt the Earl ≈øhould be fir≈øt proceeded on, before that of the Earl again≈øt the Duke.
And now the Ice thus broken, the Common (by eight of their own Members) ≈øent up Thirteen Articles of high Offences and Mi≈ødemeanours again≈øt the Duke; which he an≈øwer'd with ≈øo much mode≈øty, that it much abated the Heat that many had again≈øt him: And in regard the matters charged had been tran≈øcted in King James's time, he claim'd the Benefit of the Pardon of the Twenty fir≈øt of King James, and the pre≈øent King's Coronation Pardon. On which, the Commons thus d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
appointed, having prepared a Declaration of the ≈øame nature with their Impeachment, the Parliament was di≈ø≈øolv'd by Commi≈ø≈øion, June 14. 1626. and no Supply given: By which means, the Relief then ≈øetting forth for Rochel ≈øtaid ≈øo late in the Year, that they were di≈øpers'd with ill Weather, and forc'd to return without doing any thing. The King of Denmark, to whom the King had ≈øent born Men and Monies for the recovery of the Polatinate, was routed by Tilly (the Emperour's General;) and without a pre≈øent Supply, the Sound was in danger to be lo≈øt, and the Engli≈øh Ea≈øt-land Trade and Staple at Hamburgh almo≈øt given up for gone. And now what wonder if the King's extraordinary Wants, put him upon extraordinary Cour≈øes? He borrows 120000 l. of the City of London, for which they had Lands of 21000 l. yearly value a≈ø≈øur'd to them; and 30000 l. of the Ea≈øt-India Company: And for the re≈øt made u≈øe of Privy-Seals, Loans, as ≈øuch other ways as might enforce a le≈øs nece≈ø≈øitated Prince to.
However, that a la≈øt Extremity might not run him beyond his Natural Inclination, he calls a Parliament, which open'd March 17. 1627. where he ≈øo pathetically laid before them the cau≈øe of their meeting; which was, The Common Danger; a Supply proportionable to it; The Exigence of Time; the ju≈øt De≈øence of Friends and Allies: And, la≈øtly, clos'd all with his Hopes of their following that Advice, of maintaining the Unity of the Spirit, in the Band of Peace; that the Commons unanimou≈øly voted him Five Sub≈øidies. On which, the King (by his Secretary) let them know, He would deny them nothing of their Liberties, which any of his Predece≈ø≈øors had granted.

But while the Bill for the≈øe Sub≈øidies was preparing, the old Leven fermented anew: Loans, Privy Seals, Billeting of Soldiers even in ca≈øes of Nece≈ø≈øity, and Martial Law for keeping them in order, was que≈øtion'd, as contrary to Magna Charta; which terminated in this, That the King gave his Royal A≈ø≈øent to that ≈øo-much-talk'd of Petition of Right (wherein yet he granted no New Liberties, but confirmed the Old) with this Declaration concerning the true Intent thereof, That the Profe≈ø≈øion of both Hou≈øes in the hammering of the Petition, was no ways to entrench upon his Prerogative, ≈øaying, They had neither Intention nor Power to hurt it. Of which Intent and Meaning of his, in granting the ≈øaid Petition, he commanded all to take notice; E≈øpecially (≈øaid the King) you my Lords the Judges; for
to you only under Me, belongs the Interpretation of the Laws: For none of the Hou≈øes of Parlement (joint or ≈øeparate) whatever New Doctrine may be rais'd, have any Power to make or declare a Law without My Con≈øent. And yet this did not ≈øo quiet ≈øome turbulent Heads of the Commons (who would be ≈øatisfed with nothing but the Kingdom al≈øo) bet that they yet remon≈øtrated again≈øt ≈øeveral late Mi≈øcarriages in Government; and concluded with the Duke of Buckingham, as the Common Grievance of the Kingdom, and tack'd it to the Bill of Sub≈øidies; which the King took notice of; and withal hearing they were preparing another, again≈øt Tonnage and Poundage, prorogu'd them from June 26. to Octob. 20. 1628. Between which, and the ≈øaid next Meeting, the Duke was ≈ølain at Port≈ømouth (in the Thirty ≈øixth Year of his Age) as he was fetting fail for the Relief of Rochel, by one John Felton, a di≈øcontented Officer of the la≈øt Year's Army; and the Parliament put of to the 20th. of January. At what time the Debates running ≈øo high again≈øt the pretended encrea≈øe of Popery and Arminiani≈øm, and the levying Tonnage and Poundage, not yet granted by Parliament. The King (by Warrant of the Privy-Council) ≈øent for ≈øeveral of the Principal Authors of tho≈øe Di≈øorders; Four of which appearing; and refu≈øing to an≈øwer out of Parliament, what they had ≈øaid and done in Parliament, they were committed to the Tower, the Parliament di≈ø≈øolv'd, March to and ≈øuch as had not appear'd, were apprehended,
and committed to ≈øeveral other Pri
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ns; and an Information preferr'd again≈øt ‚Ä¢ hem in the Star-Chamber; to which they de
‚Ä¢ urr'd: And in Michaelmas, 1629. brought their Habeas Corpus's in the King's Bench, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ov'd to be Bail'd; which the Judges allow'd; with this, That they ought to find Sureties for ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Good Behaviour, in that it is a prevention of Damages to the Commonwealth, and an Act of Government and Juri≈ødiction, not ‚Ä¢ f Law. Which being refus'd by them, they were remanded: And the King waving his Proceedings in the Star-Chamber, an Information was exhibited in the King's Bench again≈øt Three of them, for Words ≈øpoken by them in ‚Ä¢ he foregoing Parliament, fal≈øly, maliciou≈øly, ‚Ä¢ nd ≈øeditiou≈øly, as well again≈øt the King, the Peers of the Realm, &c. as to rai≈øe a Tumult and Sedition, ≈øubvert the Government, and to the intent all the King's Loving Subjects ‚Ä¢ hould withdraw their Affections from Him. To this the Defendants pleaded, That fora≈ømuch as the Offences are ≈øuppo≈øed to have been done in Parliament, they ought not to be puni≈øh'd in any other Court but in Parliament; and demurr'd to the Juri≈ødiction of the Court: Which after full Argument on both ≈øides, was over-rul'd by the Court, and a Day given them to plead further; which they not doing, Judgment was given again≈øt them upon a Nihil dicit, That they ≈øhould be impri≈øon'd during the King's Plea≈øure; not to be de
‚Ä¢ iver'd 'till Security given in Court for the Good-Behaviour, and acknowledgment of the
Offence; and each of them re≈øpectively final according to his Condition; it being further ≈øaid by the Judges, That Plowden in Queen Mary's time was fined for Words ≈øpoken in Parliament again≈øt the Dignity of the Queen; And it was the Opinion of the Ju≈øtices i ‚Ä¢ 8. Eliz. That Offences committed in Parliament, are puni≈øhable out of Parliament.

The Scots during this time were not idle at home, but blew tho≈øe Coals of Di≈øcontent among the People, which afterwards fired the three Kingdoms; nor wanted there an opportunity at pre≈øent. The Lands of Cathedrals and Religious Hou≈øes, with the Superiorities and Tithes belonging to them, had been by Act of Parliament ≈øetled on the Crown; but by the Contrivance of Murray, and other Regents during the Minority of King James, parcell'd among the Lords and Great Men of the Kingdom, thereby to make a Party to them≈øeves: And King Charles coming to the Crown engag'd in a War, and having no Aid from them, took a legal cour≈øe to re≈øume them. On which tho≈øe Occupants that well knew they had no other Title than the U≈øurpation of their Ance≈øtors, combine together to oppo≈øe the King in every thing that ≈øhould be offer'd in Parliament relating to Church-Affairs; and becau≈øe Religion was the be≈øt Bait to hook in the People, and conceal them≈øelves, they centre on that, and only wait the Occa≈øion; which fell thus: King James, from his fir≈øt coming to the Crown of England (though he
fail'd in his De≈øign of making the Engli≈øh and them into one People) had proceeded ≈øo far „Äà‚óä„Äâ bringing the Kirk of Scotland to an Uniformity to the Church of England, that he not only ≈øetled Epi≈øcopacy among them, but in the General A≈ø≈øembly of Aberdeen, 1616. procured ‚Ä¢ n Act for compo≈øing a Liturgy, or Common-Prayer; to be fir≈øt pre≈øented to the King, and after his Approbation, univer≈øally receiv'd through the Kingdom: And a Book of Canons, which al≈øo was further improv'd by that other of Perth, 1618. and both ratified by an Act of Parliament of that Kingdom: But what by rea≈øon of the Palatinate War, and his own Death, it went no further in his time. And King Charles was ≈øo taken up at home, that he was forc'd to deferr the fini≈øhing it 'till he came into Scotland, where he was Crown'd, May 18. 1632. And in a Parliament which fate ≈øoon after, he caus'd an Act of Ratification of all that had been done by his Father to be propos'd, which (not without ≈øtrong oppo≈øition) was carried by the far greater Number: And after his return for England, he order'd the Dean of his Chapel-Royal at Edinburgh, That the Engli≈øh Liturgy, with its u≈øual Ceremonies, ≈øhould be u≈øed in his ≈øaid Chapel. On this, the Presbyterian Scots in≈øinuate to the People, That this was a De≈øign to ≈øubject the pure Kirk of Scotland, to the Super≈øtitions of the Church of England: And the Lords and Gentry (who fear'd nothing more than that they ≈øhould be forc'd to ≈øurrender) po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd them, That Scotland was to be
reduc'd into a Province, and Govern'd by a Lord Lieutenant, as was Ireland. And th ‚Ä¢
doz'd into a Belief that their All was at ≈øtake, what was there on which their Drivers might not run a heedle≈øs Multitude.

And now the Dutch ≈øeeing the King's hand ‚Ä¢ full, not only encroach'd upon the Brit ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Seas, by their frequent Fi≈øhings, but began „Äà‚óä„Äâ di≈øpute the Right of the Dominion, in 1634 which the King being re≈øolv'd to maintain and having ≈øeveral Precedents for Ievying a Naval Aid upon the Subjects, by the ≈øole Anthority of the King, by a Writ under the Great Seal, when the Good and Safety of the Kingdom is in danger; the King (by Letter under his Signet, Feb. 12. 1636.) con≈øults the Judges in it; who all of them (Twelve in number) return'd their Opinions under their Hands, That theKing might do it; and in ca≈øe of refu≈øal, compel the doing it by Law; And that the King is ≈øole Judge, both of the Danger, and when and how the ≈øame is to be prevented and avoided. However, Two of them (Hutton and Crook) afterwards retracted what they had ≈øo formally given under their Hands; which was the cau≈øe of no little Trouble in the Kingdom, the Sound of which was not long ere it reach'd Scotland; albeit, upon the ≈øolemn Arguments of all the Judges in the Exchequer-Chamber touching this matter, Judgment was given for the King.

The King (as has been ≈øaid) had order'd ‚Ä¢ he Engli≈øh Liturgy to be us'd in his Chapel-Royal at Edinburgh, which (at the Reque≈øt of ‚Ä¢ he Scots Bi≈øhops) having been amended to their ‚Ä¢ wn Model, was agreed to by the King, and ‚Ä¢ ent back into Scotland; and by the Bi≈øhops ‚Ä¢ nd Lords of the Council of that Kingdom, ‚Ä¢ rder'd to be read in the Great Church, July 23. 1637. Upon the very opening of which, there ‚Ä¢ ro≈øe ≈øuch a Tumult of Stools and Cudgels thrown at the Dean (the Reader's Head) that ‚Ä¢ he Provo≈øt and Bailiffs of the City, had much ‚Ä¢ do to ≈øuppre≈øs. Nor fared it better in ≈øeveral other Churches, where (by the like Command) it was al≈øo read; and from one thing to another ran to that heighth, that Prote≈øtations being grown too ≈øtrong for Proclamations, they enter into a Confederacy, and bind it with a Covenant, for Maintenance of the King's Per≈øon and Authority, (but how?) in Defence of the Go≈øpel of Chri≈øt, and Liberties of the Kingdom (of which them≈øelves were Judges) and the mutual Defence of each other, again≈øt all Per≈øons what≈øoever. Whereupon the Marqui≈øs Hamilton is fent thither to compo≈øe the Differences; but with no effect: For (notwith≈øtanding all the King's Conde≈øcentions) they could neither be brought to acknowledge they had parted from their Obedience, nor renounce their Covenant; than the lea≈øt Tittle of which, they declar'd they would fooner renounce their Bapti≈øm. And thereupon took upon them a Power of convoking
a General A≈ø≈øembly; in which, they fir≈øt depriv'd all the Bi≈øhops, and ≈øoon after aboli≈øh'd the Order it ≈øelf, ≈øeiz'd the King's Ca≈øtles, and ran into Arms; but finding the King upon the Borders with a powerful Army, and them≈øelves better prepar'd for a Treaty than a Battel, a Pacification is made, July 17. 1639. And upon promi≈øe of future Loyalty, the King pardons them.

But (alas!) the Core was not got out, and the Ulcer rather skinn'd over than heal'd; for the King had ≈øcarce come to London, ere they broke all their Articles, and apply to the King of France to favour their Proceedings, and give them his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance. On which, the King calls another Parliament, which open'd April 13. 1640. and in≈øtead of taking the King's Bu≈øine≈øs in hand, or the lea≈øt notice of this In≈øolence of the Scots, ran to that heighth again≈øt Ship-Money, Knighthoods, and the Actions of divers Mini≈øters of State, though done by the King's Warrant, that they were di≈ø≈øolv'd May 5. following.

And now the Scots, who had form'd an Intelligence with ≈øome of the Engli≈øh Nobility and Gentry, and con≈øequently a≈ø≈øur'd of being favour'd by them when it came to a Point, take Arms again; and publi≈øh a Declaration, Not to lay them down, 'till Religion was ≈øetled in both Nations; and the Cau≈øers and Abettors of their pre≈øent Troubles (the Prelates and their Adherents, but more particularly
the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, and the Earl of Strafford) were brought to publick Ju≈øtice in Parliament, which al≈øo they de≈øire may be call'd: And thereupon march into England; where notwith≈øtanding their giving out, That they would take nothing without ready Money, they charge tho≈øe adjacent Parts with Eight hundred and fifty Pounds a Day. Nor had the King been ≈øo negligent all this while, but that by the help of his better-affected Subjects, he met them with an Army ≈øufficient to have reduc'd them, had it come to a Battel; or had he not been overper≈øuaded out of it, into a Treaty at Rippon, he had probably prevented tho≈øe ill Con≈øequences that follow'd the ≈ølipping that Opportunity. However, it ended in a patch'd Agreement for the pre≈øent, and gave the King the advantage of being a≈ø≈øur'd of the Earl of Montro≈øs's Fidelity to him, and readine≈øs to ≈øerve him. On which, the King calls a Parliament, which met at We≈øtmin≈øter, Novemb. 3. the ≈øame Year: And hitherto was but the beginning of Sorrows.

The Parliament thus met, the King declar'd his earne≈øt De≈øires for the Welfare of the Kingdom; de≈øired them (as he promis'd he would) to lay by all Prejudice, and he would freely put him≈øelf upon the Love of his Subjects: Will'd them to con≈øider of the be≈øt way for the Safety and Security of England: Fir≈øt, in cha≈øing out tho≈øe Rebels who had invaded it; and next, for ≈øatisfaction of Ju≈øt Grievances.
And as freely leaving it to them where to begin, clos'd with this, That it ≈øhould not be „Äà‚óä„Äâ Fault, if this were not a good and happy Parliament.

And truly, great might have been the Hopes concerning this Parliament, had they not begun a Note too high, to make any Confort: For fir≈øt, an Impeachment was ≈øent up from the Commons again≈øt the Earl of Strafford (who had been the late General again≈øt the Scots) Novemb. 12. On which, he was forthwith taken into Cu≈øtody, and committed to the Tower, Novemb. 22. brought to his Trial, March 22. which la≈øted 'till April 13. And la≈øtly attainted by Act of Parliament, and thereupon beheaded, May 12 following: And the ≈øame 10th. of May that the King gave his Royal A≈ø≈øent to that Bill of Attainder, he gave the like to another, That this Parliament ≈øhould not be Di≈ø≈øolv'd, or Prorogu'd, but by Act of Parliament.

And now having gotten this firmer footing, to what they had begun before, in enlarging ≈øuch as had been fined and impri≈øoned by the Star-Chamber for Libelling; voting Ship-Money unlawful, and the Lord Keeper a Traitor; impeaching the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, whom (after a Four Years impri≈øonment) they beheaded by an Ordinance of Lords and Commons, at which Seven Lords only were pre≈øent; They proceed to Acts of Parliament for vacating Ship-Money; taking off the ≈øeveral
Courts of Star-Chamber, High-Commi≈ø≈øion, the Pre≈øidencies of Wales, and the North; the Bi≈øhops outed the Hou≈øe of Peers: And having ≈øingled out the King, as it were, by Him≈øelf, they pray a Guard out of the City of London, to be Commanded by the Earl of E≈ø≈øex: Which the King refu≈øing, he is ≈øo hara≈øs'd with Tumults, that he is fore'd to remove from London: And (which fell fortunately to their Game) a Rebellion in Ireland having broke out the 23d. of October before, the King had given his A≈ø≈øent to two Bills; the one, for the borrowing 400000 l. for the nece≈ø≈øary Defence of England and Ireland; the other (which brought in little le≈øs) for the Encouragement of Adventurers for the reducing of Ireland. And ≈øo having gotten ≈øuch a Fund, they not long after further petition, That the Tower of London, all other Forts, and the whole Militia of the Kingdom, might be put into ≈øuch hands, as ≈øhould be recommended to him by both Hou≈øes. But being refus'd by the King, they publi≈øh a Declaration,

p.hi: That what≈øoever They declare to be Law, ought not to be que≈øtion'd by the King:
That They, without the King, are Judges of the Publick Good:
That the Soveraign Power re≈øides in both Hou≈øes; and that the King ought to have no Negative Voice:
That Trea≈øon cannot be committed again≈øt his Per≈øon, otherwi≈øe than as he is intru≈øted with the Kingdom, and di≈øcharges that Tru≈øt; of which they are Judges.

div.p: And thereupon rai≈øe an Army, and make the Earl of E≈ø≈øex General thereof, and the Earl of Warwick Admiral at Sea, notwith≈øtanding the King had appointed another. On which, many of the Hou≈øe of Commons, and mo≈øt of the Peers, repair to the King at York; the King proclaims E≈ø≈øex and his Adherents Traitors, and ≈øets up his Standard at Nottingham, Aug. 20. 1642. In return of which, they (in 1643.) voted the Queen a Traiter, for helping her Husband with Ammunition, and ≈øome Engli≈øh Forces out of Holland: And actually brought in an Army of Scots to fight again≈øt the King; when yet they had made it an Article of High-Trea≈øon again≈øt the Earl of Strafford, for that he ≈øhould have ≈øaid at Council-Board, If his Maje≈øty pleas'd to employ Forces, he had ≈øome in Ireland, which might ≈øerve to reduce the Kingdom: The Que≈øtion al≈øo at that time being touching Scotland.

However, the King, without other Supplies than the voluntary A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Loyal Nobility and Gentry, made a ≈øhift to bring the We≈øt, the North, and ≈øeveral other parts of the Kingdom, under his Obedience; 'till at la≈øt, oppre≈øs'd by tho≈øe inexhau≈øtible Banks (as the Weekly A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øments, which for the Year came to above 1700000 l. the Plate, ready Monies, and Jewels borrow'd upon the Publick Faith, which in London and Middle≈øex, came to upwards of Ten Millions, be≈øides the Profits of their new Exci≈øe, Seque≈øtrations of King's, Queen's, Prince's, Bi≈øhops, and Delinquents
Lands; Tonnage, Poundage, and what≈øoever was in any wi≈øe due to the King) which, contrary to the known Laws, they had raked to them≈øelves; and not being able to recover that fatal Battel of Na≈øeby, June 14. 1645. He ≈øunk by degrees; and at la≈øt threw him≈øelf upon (his Country-men) the Scots, who Delivered him up to the Parliament for 200000 l. and they kept Him under a Guard at Holmby.

The Parliament now in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the King, came to be divided into two Parties, Presbyterian and Independant; and the Army, which was every of them a Sect by it ≈øelf, thinking they had as much Right to Him as the others, ≈øeize Him, and bring Him to Hampton Court, about the middle of Augu≈øt, 1647. from whence (without bettering His Condition) He e≈øcapes into the I≈øle of Wight, and by Letter to the Parliament, de≈øires a Per≈øonal Treaty at London: They, on the other hand, vote Him 5000 l. for His pre≈øent Accommodation, and ≈øend Him Four Preliminary Bills to ≈øign; but tho≈øe ≈øo Unrea≈øonable, that the King refu≈øing them, they (among≈øt other things) vote no more Addre≈ø≈øes ≈øhould be made to Him; and the Army declares to ≈øtand by them in tho≈øe Votes, and what ≈øhall be further nece≈ø≈øary for the pro≈øecution thereof.

On this, ≈øeveral Parties in London, Wales, E≈ø≈øex, Kent, &c. ri≈øe for the King; a part of the Navy go off to the Prince; and the Scots (under Duke Hamilton) enter England. To ≈øuppre≈øs
the≈øe, the Army is ≈øent abroad, and Cromwel makes again≈øt Hamilton, takes him Pri≈øoner, and pur≈øues the re≈øt to Edinburgh. During this ab≈øence of his, the Parliament revoke their Votes of Non Addre≈ø≈øes, and appoint Five Lords and Ten Commoners to treat with the King at Newport in the I≈øle of Wight, with Honour, Freedom, and Safety. But (alas!) they dodg'd ≈øo long about Tri≈øles, that upon Cromwel's return before any thing was concluded, the Army remon≈øtrate, and require, That the King be brought to Ju≈øtice, as the Capital Cau≈øe of the Civil War: And thereupon having garbled the Commons of Forty odd Members, and required that Ninety more, and all others, that by their Votes, Decemb. 5. before, had approved the King's Conce≈ø≈øions for a Peace, at the I≈øle of Wight, ≈øhould be excluded the Hou≈øe, 'till they had enter'd their Di≈ø≈øents to tho≈øe Votes; that Fagg-end of them that was left, re≈øtor'd the Votes of Non-Addre≈ø≈øes, voted a Charge of High-Trea≈øon again≈øt the King, and drew up an Ordinance for his Trial: Which being rejected by the Lords, they made it an Act of their own; and on Saturday, Jan. 20. 1648. brought Him before a Mock-High-Court of Iu≈øtice, con≈øi≈øting of one Brad≈øhew their Pre≈øident, Cromwel, his Son-in-Law Ireton, and Seventy two others, that appear'd and ≈øate; and with ignominious Expre≈ø≈øions charg'd Him, That as a Publick Enemy of the Commonwealth, he had traiterou≈øly and maliciou≈øly levied War again≈øt the pre≈øent Parliament, and the People therein repre≈øented. And after four Days, not
allowing Him to be heard, unle≈øs he fir≈øt acknowledg'd the Authority of their Court, He was as Infamou≈øly ≈øentenc'd to have his Head ≈øever'd from his Body; which was accordingly executed in the open Street, before his Royal Palace of Whitehal, Jan. 30. 1648. in the Forty eighth Year of his Age, and Twenty fourth of his Reign. And thus fell this oppre≈øs'd King; than whom, many have worn a Crown longer, no one left it with ≈øo much Re≈øolution.
His Queen and Relict was Henrietta Maria, as hath been before ≈øaid; by whom he had Four Sons, and as many Daughters.

list.item: 1. Charles Stuart, born, Chri≈øten'd, and died the ≈øame Day, March 18. 1628.
2. Charles Stuart, Prince of Wales, born May 29. 1630. who after a Twelve Years ≈øubver≈øion of the Government, was re≈øtor'd, 1660.
3. James Stuart, Duke of York, born Octob. 14. 1633. who (his Brother dying without I≈ø≈øue) ≈øucceeded him in the Crown.
4. Henry Stuart, Duke of Glouce≈øter, born July 8. 1640. died after the Re≈øtauration, Septemb. 13. 1660.

div.p:
His Daughters:
1. Mary Stuart, born Novemb. 4. 1631. married to William of Na≈ø≈øau, Prince of Orange, May 2. 1641. by whom ≈øhe had one Son, Henry William, born nine Days after the Death of his Father; Crown'd King of England, April 11. 1689. She died Decemb. 24. 1660.
2. Elizabeth Stuart, born Decemb. 28. 1635. died Septemb. 8. 1650.
3. Anne Stuart, born March 17. 1636. died Decemb. 8. 1640.
4. Henrietta Maria Stuart, born June 16. 1644 at Exeter, from whence ≈øhe was convey'd into France, and married to Philip Duke of Orleans, Brother to Lewis XIV. the pre≈øent King of France. She died 1670.

King Charles I. being thus dead, and that whatever it were of a Parliament (according to the known Laws of England) thereby di≈ø≈øolv'd, they that had kill'd the Father, knew they could not be ≈øecure 'till they had done as much by the Son; and therefore immediately aboli≈øh the Monarchy, and turn the Name, Style, Title, and Te≈øt of the King, into that of The Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament; and make it High-Trea≈øon to proclaim, or any ways to promote Charles Stuart, commonly call'd Prince of Wales, or any other Per≈øon to be King, &c. Yet this hindred not but that ≈øeveral printed Declarations, in the Name of the Nobility, Judges, Gentry, and other the Freemen of England, were ≈øcattered about London, thereby recognizing the Prince's Hereditary Birth-right to the Crown, &c. and their Re≈øolutions of defending it, to the la≈øt Man; Dated Feb. 1. in the Fir≈øt Year of the Reign of King Charles II.

XXVI. The Hou≈øe of Lords was yet ≈øitting, and ≈øent to the Commons for a Conference touching the≈øe matters; who in≈øtead of vouch≈øafing them an An≈øwer (by their Votes Feb. 6.) declare the Kingly Office to be unnece≈ø≈øary and burthen≈øome, and the Lords Hou≈øe dangerous and u≈øele≈øs, and therefore to be laid a≈øide.
Again≈øt the≈øe Proceedings the Lords prote≈øt; and the Army ≈øet a Guard upon their Hou≈øe to prevent their a≈ø≈øembling: And the Commons wholly took it away, and their Privilege of Peerage with it, unle≈øs (being duly Qualified) they ≈øhall be elected to ≈øit in Parliament: And thereupon enacted them≈øelves The Supreme Authority of the Nation; A Commonwealth, and Free State, without any King, or Hou≈øe of Lords: And committed the Executive Part of the Government to A Council of State erected by them: of whom, Forty were principal Officers in the Army. And having obliterated the very Prints of Monarchy, they proceeded to the Sale of King's, Queen's, Prince's, Bi≈øhops, Dean and Chapters, and Delinquents Lands; of which, them≈øelves were (for the mo≈øt part) Purcha≈øers, and that at ea≈øie Rates.

During this time, the Parliament of Scotland (that they might at lea≈øt ≈øeem not wanting to their Duty) recognize the King's undoubted Right of Succe≈ø≈øion to the Crowns of the≈øe Kingdoms: But with this Clau≈øe in it, That he be not admitted to the Exerci≈øe of it, 'till he had given Satisfaction to the Kingdom, touching the Security of Religion, and the Unity betwixt the Kingdoms, according to the National Covenant, and the Solemn League and Covenant. Middleton, on the other hand, and ≈øeveral of the Scots Nobility, that were for having the King admitted without previous Conditions, take Arms in the Highlands; but were di≈øpers'd, before the Marque≈øs of Montro≈øs who (with Men and Arms) was ju≈øt landed in the I≈øles of Orkney, could come up to join them: However, this nothing daunted
his Magnanimity, but that, with the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øome few that came in to him, he ≈øucce≈øsfully made good the King's Intere≈øt again≈øt the Covenanters, as he had formerly done his Royal Father's, in 1645.

And now they at home finding no great danger to be yet fear'd from Scotland, ca≈øt an eye upon Ireland, where the Iri≈øh had generally ≈øubmitted to the King's Authority; and with the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øeveral of the Engli≈øh that had ≈øerv'd his Father, had, in a manner reduc'd the whole Kingdom, excepting Dublin, and the more remote parts of Ul≈øter. And having laid a new Tax of 90000 l. a Month, for the maintenance of the Army, they order Seven Regiments of Foot, Four of Hor≈øe, and One of Dragoons, to be ≈øent thither; and appoint Cromwel General, and his Son Ireton Lieutenant-General, for the Expedition; who with all the ha≈øte that could be, tran≈øported their Forces, and landed in Dublin, Aug. 5. 1649. whence after a little refre≈øhment, Cromwel marches them for Drogedah; and after ≈øeveral repul≈øes, takes it by ≈øtorm, puts all to the ≈øword, with out re≈øpecting either Age, Sex, or Condition; and in le≈øs than a Year, ≈øubdues the mo≈øt part of the Kingdom to the Power of the New Commonwealth, and returns for England, leaving Iretan to fini≈øh the re≈øt; which he liv'd not to effect, but died of the Plague at Limerick, and was ≈øucceeded by Ludiour.

While things went thus in Ireland, the E≈øtates of Scotland had ≈øpun out a lingering Treaty with the King at Breda; during which, the Kirk-Party having ≈øurpriz'd Mentro≈øa, defeated
his Forces; and gotten him≈øelf betray'd into their hands, they bring him to Edinburgh, hang him on a Gallows Thirty Foot high, and quarter him, May 21. 1650. at what time yet his Re≈øolution was ≈øo great, and his Deportment ≈øo winning, that he won more from them by his manner of Dying, than he could have vanqui≈øh'd in the Field by Arms. However, the Treaty took effect at la≈øt; and the King lands in Scotland, and was proclaim'd at Edinburgh, July 15.

And now the Men at We≈øtmin≈øter (better known by the Name of The Rump) think it high time to look about them, and form an Army to be ≈øent thither; Fairfax ≈øhould have commanded it, but (whether it were that the Covenant had bewitch'd him, or Cromwel out-witted him) he declin'd the Charge; and Cromwel is made Generali≈ø≈øimo; and with 16000 effective Men, enters Scotland, and has a Fleet on the Coa≈øts to attend his motions. Nor was it long ere he engag'd the Scots Army, and gave them (6000 Hor≈øe and Dragoons, and 15000 Foot) a Defeat at Mu≈øleburgh, and a total Rout at Dunbar, Septemb. 3. the ≈øame Year. On which, they quit Edinburgh; and retiring to St. John≈øteun for new Recruits, Crown the King at Scoon, Jan. 1. following.

Nor was Cromwel idle all this time, but having Edinburgh-Ca≈øtle ≈øurrender'd to him, de≈øeated a ≈øtrong Party under the Command of Sir John Browne, and from one ≈øtep to another, at la≈øt takes St. John≈øtoun: He was now about laying a Siege to Sterlin-Ca≈øtle, when the King, taking the Opportuity, march'd his Army into England by the way of Carli≈øte, Aug. 6.
1651. where he was forthwith proclaim'd King, and met no oppo≈øition 'till he came to Warrington Bridge, where Lambert got up with his Reer, and was wor≈øted: But the King's wearied Army being not able to reach London, he came to Worce≈øter, Aug. 22. 1651. where probably he might have expected Supplies, though few came in to him, ≈øaving Sir Cecil Howel (Son of the Lord Howard of E≈øcrick) who met him by the way with about 60 Hor≈øe of his own rai≈øing; and the Earl of Darby, with 250 Foot, and about 70 Hor≈øe, at Worce≈øter; from whence, going into Lanca≈øhire with a con≈øiderable number of Officers that had ≈øerv'd King Charles I. he form'd a rea≈øonable Army; but ere he could get back to the King, was intercepted, and with the ≈ølaughter of mo≈øt of them, taken Pri≈øoner him≈øelf, and not long after beheaded, notwith≈øtanding the Quarter that had been given him.

On this, Cromwel ≈øurrounds Worce≈øter, where (whether it were by Fate or Treachery) he gave the King a total Rout, the ≈øaid Septemb. 3. was a Year, with the ≈ølaughter of 2000, and 8000 taken Pri≈øoners, be≈øides 76 Cornets of Hor≈øe, and 99 Colours of Foot, with the King's Standard. However, the King (leaving Colonel Carlo≈ø≈øe in his Reer) got off in the dark, to a Hou≈øe of the Earl of Darby's, about Twenty five Miles from Worce≈øter; where, by the Diligence of the ≈øaid Colonel, and the Fidelity of the Pendrils (Men of an ordinary Condition) he was fir≈øt pre≈øerv'd in an Oak, and from one Di≈øgui≈øe to another, at la≈øt ≈øafely landed in France, by a ≈ømall Cole-Bark, of which one Tetter≈øhal was Ma≈øter, Octob. 22. following.

And now Cromwel returns triumphantly thro' London, with his Trophies, and Pri≈øoners driven before him; the former of which, he hung up in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall; and ≈øo dieted the latter in Tuttle-Fields, that there being ≈øcarce 500 of them left alive, he ≈øold them Slaves to the Barbadoes: But ere he came out of Scotland, he had left the Chief Command of the Engli≈øh Forces there, to General Monck, a Gentleman of an ancient Family in Devon, bred a Soldier in the Low-Country Wars, and who had honourably ≈øerv'd King Charles I. both in England and Ireland; but being taken Pri≈øoner by the Parliament, and under ≈øome ≈øtraits in the Tower, Cromwel (who could not engage him to draw his Sword for them in England) prevails yet with him to go with him into Scotland again≈øt the Covenanters: Where having left him, Sterlin-Ca≈øtle was in a ≈øhort time deliver'd to him, Dundee taken by ≈øtorm, and the re≈øt of the Kingdom generally ≈øubdu'd or ≈øubmitted to the New Lords at We≈øtmin≈øter. On which, they enacted the Union of the two Nations, and the Abolition of Monarchy in Scotland.

And yet ere matters came to this heighth, there fell an occa≈øion of Quarrel between the Dutch and them: Dori≈ølaus (who drew the Charge again≈øt King Charles I.) had been ≈øent by them Amba≈ø≈øadour to the Hague, where about a dozen Cavaliers, headed by one Whitford, enter'd his Chamber as he was at Supper, with ≈øome of the States, kill'd him, and got away: As not long after ran the ≈øame fate A≈øcham, their Envoy at Madrid. However, this Infant-State thought it not fit to make a downright
Quarrel, 'till they could go by them≈øelves, but ≈øent other Amba≈ø≈øadours (St. Johns and Strickland) to offer a League with the United Provinces; which was entertain'd with ≈øo little forwardne≈øs, that within a Month after the Battel of Worce≈øter, they pa≈ø≈øed an Act again≈øt the importing of Merchandize, in other than Engli≈øh Bottoms; di≈øturb'd their Fi≈øhing on the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt, ≈øearch'd their Ships, as carrying Provi≈øions to France, and made ≈øome of them Prize. And now the Dutch ≈øend their Amba≈ø≈øadours to de≈øire that Friend≈øhip they before ≈ølighted; and the Rump, on the other hand, ≈øo ≈øtood on Terms never likely to be granted, that it came to Blows; and the Dutch wi≈øely made the Flag the ≈øtate of the Quarrel: Whereupon en≈øued ≈øeveral Naval Engagements.

The fir≈øt of the≈øe was May 17. 1652. where with 23 Ships again≈øt 42 of the Dutch (of which one was taken, another ≈øunk, and no one of the Engli≈øh ≈øo much as di≈øabled) Blake fir≈øt a≈ø≈øerted the Dominion, and carried it for that time; and the States excus'd it, as a ra≈øh Action done by Trump, without their Privity or Con≈øent: But the Men at We≈øtmin≈øter requiring Satisfaction for their Charge and Damages, before they would hear further,
It came to a ≈øecond, between Sir George Askew and De Ruyter, Aug. 16. and may be call'd a Drawn-Battel, though the Dutch outnumber'd him by Ten Ships.

During this time, Blake had ≈øpoil'd and di≈øpers'd their Herring-Fi≈øhing, and taken Twelve Men of War that guarded them: On which follow'd a third Engagement, Octob. 28. between
Blake, Monck, and Deane joint Admirals for the Engli≈øh, and Witt Wittens and De Ruyter for the Dutch; in which, the Reer-Admiral of the Dutch was boarded and taken, Two others ≈øunk, and One blown up; be≈øides Five of their We≈øt India Ships, and Six Streights-Men, which Blake had taken in his coming up to it.

The fourth was Novemb. 29. with 80 Dutch Ships, again≈øt 40 Engli≈øh, then riding in the Downs, not expecting an Engagement; in which, Blake lo≈øt the Garland taken, the Bonadventure burnt, and three others ≈øunk, and by the favour of the Night got off with the re≈øt: On which, Trump ≈øtuck a Broom in his Maintop.

The fifth was, Feb. 8. off of Portland, which la≈øted three Days, and in which the Engli≈øh lo≈øt one Ship (The Samp≈øon) and Blake receiv'd a de≈øperate Wound on his Hip, the Lamene≈øs of which he never recover'd; but took Eleven of their Ships of War, be≈øides Thirty Merchant-Men. On which, the Rump laid a Tax of 120000 l. a Month for the maintaining the War.

The ≈øixth was June 2. 1653. at what time Trump coming upon our Coa≈øts with 104 Ships of War, 12 Galleots, and 9 Fire-≈øhips, was encountred by Monck and Deane, with 100 of all ≈øorts. The Fight was de≈øperate, and la≈øted two Days; during which, without any one Ship lo≈øt or di≈øabled, and ≈øaving his Colleagne Deane (who was taken off by the Wa≈øte by a Great≈øhot) but one Captain kill'd, Monck ≈øunk ≈øix of their be≈øt Ships, ≈øaw two others blown up, and took eleven (of which three were Flag-≈øhips)
when at la≈øt Blake coming in with 18 fre≈øh Ships, the Dutch got off upon their Flatts.

The ≈øeventh and la≈øt Engagement was July 29. when Trump coming up with 95 Ships, was met by Monck (who by rea≈øon of Blake's Indi≈øpo≈øition, now commanded ≈øingly) with 106 Ships, and fought it 'till Night parted them: But by the next Morning, Trump being re-enforc'd with 25 Ships by Wittens, and Monck having given Orders through his Fleet, neither to give nor take Quarter 'till the point were decided, it came to a more bloody Trial, in which (be≈øides their Admiral Van Trump ≈ølain) they lo≈øt Vice-Admiral Evert≈øon, and Thirty two others ≈øunk; him≈øelf, and four Captains, and twelve hundred common Men taken up after the Fight, and made what ≈øail they could for the Texel: Nor did Monck think it fit to pur≈øue them, as having bought the Victory with the lo≈øs of eight Captains, and about five hundred common Men ≈ølain; five other Captains, and ≈øeven thou≈øand private Men wounded; and one Ship (The Oak) ≈øunk.

While matters were thus at Sea, the Army, as well as the Nation, were become ≈øo ≈øick of our New Commonwealth on Shoar, that they urge them to di≈ø≈øolve them≈øelves; which they not daring to refu≈øe, nor yet willing to yield, determine it to Nov. 5. 1654. but trifled ≈øo much time about Qualifications for their Succe≈ø≈øors, that Cromwel (not meaning to ≈øtay ≈øo long, and the Army declaring again≈øt them, as a Party of Carnal Men, and not to be tru≈øted with the Choice of their Repre≈øentatives) turn'd them out of the Hou≈øe, and ≈øet a Guard upon it, April 23. 1653.

This done, Cromwel and his Officers con≈øtitute A Council of State, made up of them≈øelves and their Confederates of the late Hou≈øe, and place the Supreme Authority in them, 'till a Repre≈øentative could be cho≈øen; which not long after was patch'd together of an hundred forty two known Per≈øons (as the Cant was) Men fearing God, and of approv'd Integrity; but ≈øo ridiculous as to Man, that it was thought Cromwel got them together to no other end, than to bring Parliaments into contempt.

However, they met July 4. and having declar'd them≈øelves a Parliament, the Council of State re≈øign their Supremacy to them; and they appoint a New Council of State, con≈øi≈øting of Cromwel and his Officers, with Power to tran≈øact all Publick Affairs, treat with Amba≈ø≈øadours, &c. But in that five Months time that they ≈øate, they had ≈øo unhing'd every thing, and done nothing, but to the wor≈øe, that even their Ma≈øters who brought them together, were a≈øham'd of them; and mo≈øt of them≈øelves ≈øo ≈øen≈øible of it, that their Speaker Rous, with the Mace before him, and a major part of them following him, came to Whitehall, and ≈øurrender'd to Cromwel the In≈øtrument he had deliver'd to them at their fir≈øt ≈øitting; and in four Days after, the Officers of the Army having form'd a New In≈øtrument of Government, they entreat him to accept it, under the Name of Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland; which at fir≈øt he ≈øeemingly refus'd, 'till at la≈øt per≈øuaded into what he had ≈øo long de≈øign'd, he ≈øubmits to the Exigence of Time and Affairs, and was the ≈øame
Afternoon, viz. Decemb. 16. 1653. accordingly inaugurated in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall.

The Dutch by this time had made a truer E≈øtimate of the Engli≈øh Force, than they did when they began the War; and having underhand tamper'd with Cromwel for a Peace, and finding they might have ea≈øier Terms from him than the Rump would even hear of, they ≈øent over Amba≈ø≈øadours to him: Nor was he ≈øo well ≈øetled as to refu≈øe a fair Proffer, and Money to boot; whereupon a Peace was concluded between them, and proclaim'd April 5. 1654. in which the King of Denmark was included: And near the ≈øame time he made another, with Queen Chri≈øtina of Sweden. Spain al≈øo, France, and Portugal, ≈øeek his Friend≈øhip; but Spain could not obtain it: And ≈øo this fir≈øt jobb being over, he return'd Monck back into Scotland, (though with all his Art he could never get him back again) and ≈øent his ≈øecond Son Henry, Lord Deputy into Ireland, and call'd a Parliament, which met Septemb. 3. 1654.

Nor had they ≈øearce taken their Seats, ere they fell to di≈øputing the Power by which they were call'd; whereupon a Recognition of the Government, as it was then ≈øetled in a ≈øingle Per≈øon, was ≈øent them to ≈øub≈øcribe, with an Inhibition to any one of their entring the Hou≈øe 'till he had done it: In which, though mo≈øt of them complied, the whole was di≈ø≈øolv'd, within the fir≈øt five Months; which was contrary to the ≈øaid New In≈øtrument.

In 1655. he made an attempt upon Hi≈øpaniola, but mi≈øcarried in it, and took Jamaica with little or no oppo≈øition: And to cover, at
lea≈øt ≈øecure, again≈øt the Slurr at home, he decimated all the Royali≈øts, i. e. took a Tenth part of their E≈øtates, and ≈øet up Eleven Major-Generals to Tax it, and keep them in awe.

The Year following he call'd another Parliament, which met Septemb. 3. and they (perhaps) gue≈ø≈øing what he would be at, pre≈øent him an Humble Petition and Advice, to take the Title of KING; which he refus'd twice; but being pre≈øs'd to a more po≈øitive An≈øwer, he had, the very Morning that he made the Third Denial, re≈øolv'd to accept it: But whatever it was that made him change his Mind, does not appear; though, if his Secretary Thurloe may be believ'd, it was not that he fear'd the General Officers, for there were New Commi≈ø≈øions actually drawn for others, who had accepted their Commands: Where upon the Word King, in the ≈øaid Petition and Advice, was expung'd, and he in a more ≈øolemn manner inve≈øted with all the Regal Ornaments (the Crown only excepted) June 26. 1657. and proclaim'd by the Name of Oliver Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland. After which, the Parliament being adjourn'd to Jan. 20. he in the mean time (in Imitation of the old Con≈øtitution) created a New Hou≈øe of Lords, by the Name of The Other Hou≈øe: Of which the Commons taking no more notice than to ridicule it, and then falling to di≈øpute the Government, he thought it high time to put an end to their ≈øitting, and di≈ø≈øolv'd them. Not
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
long after which, having e≈øcap'd ≈øeveral Attempts, of as well Commonwealths Men, Fifth-Monarchy-Men, as Royali≈øts, he at la≈øt (to the wonder of Mankind) died in his Bed, on his twice-Au≈øpicious Third of September, 1658. having (according to the Power given him by the ≈øaid Humble Petition and Advice) fir≈øt declar'd his elde≈øt Son Richard his Succe≈ø≈øor; who, contrary to the expectation of Fleetwood and Lambert (whom Cromwel had ≈øeverally cajol'd with the Promi≈øe of the Succe≈ø≈øion) was the next Morning ≈øolemnly proclaim'd Lord Protector, &c. But he la≈øted not above three Quarters of a Year; and in him ended the Protector≈øhip.

And yet before we come to the Re≈øtauration, it may not be ami≈øs to remark the ≈øeveral Turns of Government, that from the 30th. of January, 1648. befel the Nation, 'till that happen'd: For,
1. The Monarchy was ≈øubverted, and turn'd to a Republick, under the Name of The Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, or for brevity ≈øake The Rump; and they la≈øted 'till April, 1653.
2. Cromwel turn'd them out, and plac'd the Supreme Power in A Council of State con≈øtituted by him≈øelf; and they held it 'till July the ≈øame Year.
3. From them, he turn'd it into the hands of his Men of Integrity, and made them a Parliament; which, in contempt of one of its Members, was call'd Prai≈øe God Barebone's Parliament; and they held it 'till December the ≈øame Year.
4. From that time it was in the hands of Cromwel, with the Title of Lord Protector, 'till September, 1658.
5. After him, his Son Richard had it, as Succe≈ø≈øor to his Father, 'till he was turn'd out by the Army in April, 1659. and then for a Fortnight together it lay no-where.
6. The May following, the Rump got it again, and held it 'till they were turn'd out by Lambert, the ≈øame Year: And here al≈øo for ≈øome time together it lay no-where, 'till,
7. The Council of Officers erected A Committee of Safety, with like Supremacy; and they held it, 'till General Monck having declar'd for re≈øtoring the Rump, Lambert march'd again≈øt him; but being de≈øerted by his Army, Fleetwood writes to the Speaker Lenthal, to de≈øire him, and the re≈øt of the Members, to return to the Exerci≈øe of their Tru≈øt: And the General, on the other hand, having put his, into ≈øuch hands as favour'd his De≈øign, march'd towards London.
8. On this, the Rump re≈øumes the Government, Decemb. 26. and by a Letter of Thanks
to Monck, acknowledge the Re≈øtitution to their Authority, was to be acknowledged to his Fidelity, Ca≈øe, and Courage. And yet he had not been long in Town, ere they began to grow jealous of him; and therefore for fear he might joyn with the City, who had now declar'd they would pay no more Taxes 'till the Parliament were fill'd up, they ≈øent him into the City to break down their Gate, &c. which he accordingly did, return'd his Army to their Quarters about We≈øtmin≈øter, and receiv'd the Thanks of the Hou≈øe. Yet this did not ≈øo ≈øatisfie the Jealou≈øie of a Commonwealth, but that they pre≈øs'd the Oath of Abjaration of the Royal Family to him, which he took time to con≈øider of: But the next Morning march'd his Army into the City, and joyn'd with them for having the Hou≈øe fill'd up.
9. On this, the Members that had been ≈øecluded the Hou≈øe in 1648. were re≈øtor'd Feb. 21. 1659. and they having con≈øtituted General Monck, Captain General of all the Forces in the Three Kingdoms, annull'd the former Council of State, and appointed another, and abrogated the Engagement, and Oath of Abjuration; di≈ø≈øolv'd them≈øelves, March 17. But before their ri≈øing, ≈øent out Writs for New Elections to meet April 25. 1660. In the mean time, the Rumpers ply the General with their la≈øt effort, and proffer him the Supreme Command of the Kingdoms, as a ≈øingle Per≈øon: Which he an≈øwered to this purpo≈øe; That
for that matter, it was ≈øubmitted to the coming-Parliament; nor ≈øhould it be ≈øaid of him, That ‚Ä¢ e bad run foul of that Rock, on which Cromwel
‚Ä¢ ad ≈øo lately ≈øplit him≈øelf.

The Day being come, the Lords as well as ‚Ä¢ he Commons, met in their re≈øpective Hou≈øes, when having each of them received a Letter from his Maje≈øty, with a Declaration inclos'd, the Lords re≈øolv'd by Vote, That they declare, That according to the ancient and fundamental Con≈øtitution of this Kingdom, the Government is, and ought to be by King, Lords, and Commons: To which the Commons agreed; and each of them di≈øpatch'd their ≈øeveral An≈øwers ‚Ä¢ o the ≈øaid Letters, ≈øuper≈øcribed, To the King's mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. And having caus'd Him to be ≈øolemnly proclaim'd, May 8. they ≈øent ≈øix Lords, and twelve of the Commons, to attend his Maje≈øty, and de≈øire his return to the Exerci≈øe of his Kingly Office. Which ‚Ä¢ he accordingly did, and landed at Dover the 25th. and rode through London to Whitebal the 29th. being his Birth Day, and Thirtieth Year of his Age.

Thus by the Conduct of one Man, with a raw Army of not above Six Thou≈øand, was the Monarchy delivered from a Twelve Years U≈øurpation, defended by at lea≈øt Sixty Thou≈øand Veterans, ≈øtrengthened with mo≈øt of the Alliances of Europe, and (which adds to ‚Ä¢ it) without Blood; a Stratagem (perhaps) not yet extant in Hi≈øtory. He was the Great
Grand≈øon of Sir Thomas Monck of Potheridge, in the County of Devon, by Frances, one of the Daughters and Coheirs of Arthur Plantegenet, Vi≈øcount Li≈øle, of whom before; in memory of which, the King created him Duke of Albemarle, Earl of Torrington, Baron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchamp, and Teyes.

And ≈øo being come to our own Times, is may ≈øeem needle≈øs to add further, ≈øaving that the King was Crown'd April 23. 1661. and died of an Apoplexy, Feb. 6. 1684. His only Wife and Relict, was Catharine, Daughter of John IV. King of Portugal, now living, by whom he had no I≈ø≈øue.

XXVII. To King Charles II. ≈øucceeded his Brother, James Duke of York, &c. who upon his fir≈øt coming to the Crown, profe≈øs'd Him≈øelf a Catholick; with this Di≈øplea≈øure neverthele≈øs, That he could not alter the Religion as it was by Law e≈øtabli≈øh'd. He, together with his Queen, were Crown'd April 23. 1685. Nor was that ≈øcarce over, when Two Rebellions, the one in Scotland, the other in the We≈øt of England, broke out upon him, and were defeated. In the Year 1688. he publi≈øh'd A Declaration for Liberty of Con≈øcience, ≈øo far as it di≈øturb'd not the Peace of the Kingdom: Which ≈øo heated the People (who yet had all along CONTENDED for it) that having ≈øent his Queen, and young SON into France, he follow'd Them not long after. His fir≈øt Wife was Anne, Daughter of Sir Edward Hide, Earl
of Clarendon, &c. Lord Chancellor of England, who died before he came to the Crown; by whom he had

Four Sons:
1. Charles Stuart, Duke of Cambridge; born Octob. 22. 1660. died May 5. 1661.
2. James Stuart, Duke of Cambridge; born July 12. 1663. died June 20. 1667.
3. Charles Stuart, Duke of Kendal; born July 4. 1666. died May 22. 1667.
4. Edgar, Duke of Cambridge; born Sept 14. 1667. died June 8. 1671.

And as many Daughters:
1. Marie; born April 30. 1662. married to William Henry Prince of Orange, who were both Crown'd King and Queen April 11. 1689. The Executive Power in Him.
2. Anne; born Feb. 6. 1664. married to Prince George of Denmark, Augu≈øt 7. 1683.
3. Henrietta; born January 13. 1668. died Nov. 15. 1669.
4. Catharine; born Feb. 9. 1670. died Decemb. 5. 1671.
His Second Wife, Mary d'E≈øte, Daughter of Alphon≈øo d'E≈øte III. Duke of Modena; Crown'd as before; and had I≈ø≈øue by her,

Two Daughters:
1. Catharine; born Novemb. 7. 1674. died Octob. 3. 1675.
2. I≈øabel; born Aug. 28. 1676. liv'd not long.
AND ‚Äî
1. Charles, Duke of Cambridge; born Nov. 7. 1667. died Decemb. 12. following. &c.

div.head: Of the Augmentations of the Family of ENGLAND.
div.p:
¬ß. VIII. ITS Fir≈øt was, when William the Conquerour joyn'd Normandy to the Crown of England, 1066. Henry II. Conquer'd Ireland, and in like manner united it, 1172. Edward I. Wales, 1283. Edward II. in Right of his Wife I≈øabel, Daughter of Philip the Fair, King of France, brought in Aquitain and Ponticu: And in the ≈øame Right, Edward III. took upon him the Title of King of France; and was the fir≈øt of the Engli≈øh Kings that Quarter'd the Arms thereof. Henry V. Conquer'd mo≈øt of the Kingdom. Henry VI. was Crown'd King of France in Paris, 1432. James VI. King of Scotland, made an Acce≈øion of that Crown to England, 1603. and fir≈øt Quarter'd the Arms of England and Ireland,
‚Ä¢ ith tho≈øe of Scotland.

Be≈øide, which, the Engli≈øh have ≈øuperadded ≈øeveral Plantations in America; as Virginia, 1584. the Bermudaes, 1591. Barbadoes, Nowingland, 1606. Mary-land, about 1632. Jamaica, 1656. Be≈øides Nova Scotia, one half of „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Chri≈øtopher's, Hud≈øon's Bay, Now-York, Carclina, Pen≈øylvania. Several other Places of Trade al≈øo in the Ea≈øt-India's; and Tangier in Africa, 1668. but demoli≈øh'd in‚Äîas not worth the charge „Äà‚óä„Äâ keeping it.

div.head: Of its Decrea≈øings.
div.p: ¬ß. IX. THe greate≈øt Lo≈øs it receiv'd has been from France; for whereas about the Year 1432. what by Hereditary Right, what by Marriages, what by Conque≈øt and Submi≈ø≈øion of the People, it had in a manner the whole Kingdom. It lo≈øt in 1450. not only its New Acque≈øts, but Hereditary Provinces to Charles VII. King of France, who by means of the Civil Wars between the Hou≈øes of York and Lanca≈øter, ≈øo forc'd the Engli≈øh out of France, that they retain'd only Callice, which al≈øo was lo≈øt by Queen Mary, 1558. However, it yet continues the Title and Arms of France; other than which, it makes no Preten≈øions; nor have tho≈øe been ≈øet on foot, for near 150 Years la≈øt pa≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Hou≈øe of Denmark.
div.p:
¬ß. I. THere is nothing more certain, than that the Danes have had their peculiar Kings for many Ages pa≈øt, whom Hi≈øtorians generally di≈øtingui≈øh by eight Periods; See Pontanus's Dani≈øh Hi≈øtory, lib. 7. and Beckman's Civil Hi≈øtory, c. 5 Sect. 6. The Seventh of the≈øe Periods, is that of the Suenonidae, or Engli≈øh-Danes, ≈øo called from Sueno (or Swain-Ethrick.) who≈øe Ance≈øtors, according to Saxo, the Grammarian, in the 10th. Book of his Dani≈øh Hi≈øtory, had a Bear for their fir≈øt Progenitors: For he ≈øays, That Ul≈øo, who was Sueno's Father, had one Ur≈øus, or Biorno, for his Grandfather, begot by the mon≈øtrous Copulation of a Wild Bea≈øt, with a young Virgin. About the Year 1346. Woldemar the Third, de≈øcended of this Family was King of Denmark, who, after a Peace made with Schmeek Magnus, King of Sueden, brought the Country of Scandinavia under his Juri≈ødiction, in the Year 1360. afterwards in 1363. he obtained Gotland al≈øo, upon another Peace then concluded with King Albert. He had al≈øo Wars with the Hans-Town, and dyed, 1375. leaving only a Daughter, named Margaret, whom he gave in Marriage to Haquin, ≈øecond Son of Erick, King of Sweden, by whom ≈øhe had I≈ø≈øue Olaus, the Sixth; who, upon his Father Haquin's Decea≈øe
(which happened in 1380.) ≈øucceeded both to Denmark and Sweden, as well as Norway, but dyed an untimely Death ≈øeven Years after, viz. 1387. Whereupon the Government, by the con≈øent of the Nobility of Denmark and Norway, return'd to Queen Margaret; but the Swedes elected Albertus, Duke of Mecklenburgh, to be their King; with whom Queen Margaret was ≈øoon engag'd in a War, being provoked thereunto by him, wherein proving Victorious, and taking him Pri≈øoner, cau≈øed her ≈øelf to be elected Queen, An. 1396. She adopted for her Succe≈ø≈øor, Prince Erick, Son of Urati≈ølaus, Duke of Pomerania, and Grand≈øon of her Si≈øter Ingeburg, Wife of Henry the Second, Duke of Mecklenburg, by her Daughter Mary, who, at a Convention of the States, held at Calmar in 1397. was elected King of the Three Northern Crowns, an Hereditary Union being then made, by which it was Enacted, that for the future, the Three Northern Kingdoms ≈øhould be Govern'd by one and the ≈øame Scepter. As for Queen Margaret, the Dani≈øh Semiramis, (for ≈øo ≈øhe is often ≈øtiled) ≈øhe departed this Life in the Year, 1412. After which King Erick, not ≈øo well acquainted with the Arts of Governing, as ≈øhe had been, ≈øoon drew upon him≈øelf the Odium of his People; in≈øomuch, that in the Year 1439. he was depos'd by 'em, and had his Crowns taken from him, chiefly on pretence that he had not ob≈øerv'd his Promi≈øes, nor kept his Coronation Oath, but rather on the contrary, oppo≈øed a Free Election, by naming Bogi≈ølaus Duke of Pomerania to ≈øucceed him. In his room they
≈øub≈øtituted Prince Chri≈øtopher, his Si≈øter Sophia's Son, by her Husband John Count Palatine of the Rhine, and Duke of Bavaria; which Chri≈øtopher died without I≈ø≈øue, 1448. notwith≈øtanding he had Married Dorothy, Daughter of John Marque≈øs of Brandenburg; and by this means put an end to the ancient Royal Family of Denmark.

¬ß. II. In this ≈øtate of Affairs, they Elected Adolph, Earl of Hol≈øtein to be King, but he mode≈øtly declined the Crown, when offered, either out of a con≈øideration of the Infirmity of his great Age, or el≈øe doubtful what might be the ≈øucce≈øs of the Dani≈øh Affairs: But withal, earne≈øtly recommended to their choice, Chri≈øtian Count Oldenburg, his Si≈øter's Son; who was thereupon Elected and Crowned King, by the unanimous con≈øent of all the Nobility, as we ≈øhall ≈øhow more at large in the following ¬ß. 'Twill here be expected, we ≈øhould give ≈øome account of the Original of this Family of Oldenburg; but indeed, it is ≈øo hid in the Clouds (if we may ≈øo ≈øay) by rea≈øon of its great Antiquity, that little of certainty can be picked out. For altho' it be the common Tradition, that it is deriv'd from the Po≈øterity of Witikin the Saxon, and namely, from the Counts of Ringelheim, yet Reinerus, Renneccius, and others, think it mo≈øt advi≈øable to leave things as they find 'em, and affirm nothing in ≈øo doubtful a matter. However they ≈øay, that towards the end of the Tenth Century, one Otho was Earl of Oldenburg; who had a certain wonderful Horn given him by a Spirit or Apparition, which is to be ≈øeen to this day in the Ca≈øtle of
Oldenburg; and that he was Father of John, Conrade and Rixa: That John begat Huno the Glorious, Father of Frederick, who, in the end, became a Monk, and left a Will, by which he made his Cozen Elimar his Heir, (which Elimar was Son to his great Aunt Rixa, by her Husband Hoio, Lord of Friezland in Pottenburg and Memmenburg, who≈øe Pedigree they al≈øo derive from the above-named Witikin) That Elimar, by Virtue of this Will, po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd him≈øelf of the Earldom, notwith≈øtanding all the oppo≈øition of Milo Count Alven≈øleb, Grand-≈øon of the above-named Conrade, and ≈øo became the fir≈øt Count of Oldenburg, of his Line. Among≈øt this Prince≈øs's Children, we find mention made of Elimar the Second, who begat Chri≈øtian the Warlike, Father of Maurice, by his Wife Cunigund, Counte≈øs of Locken; which Maurice, after manife≈øt proofs of his Courage on all occa≈øions, retired to a Mona≈øtery; and was ≈øucceeded in the County by his Son, Chri≈øtian the Second.

Chri≈øtian the Second had I≈ø≈øue,
1. John the Fir≈øt, of whom by and by again.
2. Otho the Third, who by his Charter erected the Town of Delmenhor≈øtan into a City, and Founded the Cathedral there, An. 1265.
3. Theodorick (or Diderick) Elected Grand Ma≈øter of the Teutonick Order in Pru≈ø≈øia, An. 1335. in the 80th. Year of his Age.
John, the Elde≈øt of the≈øe Three, had two Sons.

list.item: I. Chri≈øtian the Third, who, in the Divi≈øion of his Father's Inheritance, 'twixt him and his Brother, had the County of Delmenher≈øtan for his Patrimony, in which he was ≈øucceeded by his Son Chri≈øtian, who≈øe Grand-Daughter Adelheid, by his Son Otho the Simple, was married to Theodorick (or Diderick) the happy Earl of Oldenburg.

II. John the Second, who, in the divi≈øion afore≈øaid, had the County of Oldenburg ≈øettled on him, and was Father of Conrade, by his Wife Margaret, Counte≈øs of Lippe. Conrade begat Chri≈øtian the Fifth, Canon of Cologne, who, ≈øeeing his Brother Maurice like to die with I≈ø≈øue Male, quitted his Canonry, and married Agnes of Hohen≈øtein, by whom he had
1. Chri≈øtian the Sixth, taken and Impri≈øoned by the Inhabitants of Bremen, and not di≈ømi≈ø≈øed but on very hard terms; he afterwards died without I≈ø≈øue. And,
2. Theodorick (or Diderick) the Happy, who, by a Marriage with his Cozen Adelheid, Heire≈øs of Delmenhor≈øt, reunited the two Counties: After her Decea≈øe he took a Second Wife, namely, Hedewig, Si≈øter of Adolph, Earl of Hol≈øtein, who bore him three Sons; Chri≈øtianus the Fir≈øt, born 1425. Maurice and Gerrard.

div.p:
¬ß. III. Of the≈øe, Chri≈øtian the Fir≈øt, as has been already ob≈øerved in the beginning of the la≈øt ¬ß. was elected King of Denmark and Norway, in the Year 1448. and ten Years after, of Sweden al≈øo; tho' he lo≈øt that Kingdom again in a few Years after. He purcha≈øed the County of Hol≈øtein for 34000. and re≈øtored that of Sle≈øwick to the Crown. He likewi≈øe obtain'd of the Emperour Frederick the Third, the Inve≈øtiture of the Dutchy of Hol≈øtein; and open'd an Univer≈øity at Copenhagen on the fir≈øt of June 1479. His Queen was Dorothy, the Relict of his Predece≈ø≈øor King Chri≈øtopher, by whom he had this following I≈ø≈øue:
1. Margaret, given in Marriage to James the Third, King of Scotland, together with the I≈øles of Orkney, lying in the Northern Seas, as ≈øecurity for her Dowry, which was to be Fifty Thou≈øand Florins.
2. John, born 1455. And,
3. Frederick, of whom more in the next Sect.

John ≈øucceeded his Father in the Throne, and was Crown'd King of Denmark and Norway, in the Year, 1483. About five or ≈øix Years after he reduced Sweden, and was Crown'd there al≈øo. He once more ≈øeparated the Dutchy of Hol≈øtein and Sle≈øwick from the Crown, and divided them 'twixt him and his Brother Frederick. In 1500 he ≈øuffered a great defeat from the Rebellious Inhabitants of Dietmar≈øh; and was al≈øo outed by the Swedes ≈øome time after. In the Year 1513. he departed this Life of a Fever, which he took by a fall
from his Hor≈øe in the Water, leaving I≈ø≈øue by Queen Chri≈øtina, Daughter of Erne≈øtus, Elector of Sax. only one Son and a Daughter, namely,
I. Elizabeth, born 1455. Married to Joachim the Fir≈øt, Elector of Brandenburgh, 1502. Decea≈øed a Widow, 1555.
II. Chri≈øtianus the Second, born 1481. The undutiful Son of a mo≈øt Indulgent Father, who≈øe Cur≈øe at length, he drew upon his Head. In his Father's Life-time, he was elected to ≈øucceed him in his Kingdoms of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden. His Paramour was the fair Columbula, whom he kept with a certain Old Woman, named Sigberta, wholly en≈ølaving him≈øelf to her Will. He refu≈øed the Propo≈øals of a Reconciliation with his Uncle Frederick, in the Year 1519. and making an Expedition into Sweden, ≈øeized on the Capital City of Stockholm; cau≈øed him≈øelf to be Crown'd King, and was Author of the bloody Slaughter there. Afterwards he was Outed of all his Kingdoms, and forced to fly into the Low-Countries; from whence returning, he was ≈øeized and confined by his Subjects, and at length ended his Days in 1559. in the Seventy Eighth Year of his Age. The Partner of his Bed and Fortunes was I≈øabella, Si≈øter to the Emperour Charles the Fifth, by whom he had only two Daughters, that out-liv'd him; his Son John dying in the Hungarian Service, 'gain≈øt the Turks, An. 1532. The Daughters names were,
1. Dorothy, born 1515, married to Frederick the Second, Elector Palatine, Decea≈øed 1580. And,
2. Chri≈øtina, born 1573 who≈øe fir≈øt Hu≈øband was Francis Storza, Duke of Milan, and after his Decea≈øe, Francis Duke of Lorrain. She dyed 1590.

¬ß. IV. We mu≈øt now look back to Frederick the Fir≈øt, elected King of Donmark and Norway, in the Year 1523. by the unanimous con≈øent of the Nobility, upon their rejecting King Chri≈øtian. This Prince abrogated the Act of Hereditary Union of the Three Northern Cowns, in the Year 1524. at a Convention of the States then held at Malmugen. He made Profe≈ø≈øion of the Reformed Religion, and after he had thrown out the Monks in 1527. introduced the ≈øame into his Countries. He was twice married; his fir≈øt Wife being Anne, Daughter of John Cicero, Elector of Brandenburg, who dyed 1521. And his ≈øecond, Sophia, Daugher of Bog ‚Ä¢ ≈ølans the Tenth, Duke of Pemeranta, Decea≈øed 1568. By the≈øe he had I≈ø≈øue.

list.item: I. Dorothy, born 1494. Married to Albert, Duke of Pru≈ø≈øia, Decea≈øed 1547.
II. Chri≈øtianus the Third, born 1503. of whom more in the next Sect.
III. John, Surnam'd The Elder, born 1521. Decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue 1580.
IV. Elizabeth, Married in 1542. to Magnus, and after his Decea≈øe, in 1556. to Ulrick. Dukes of Meckleburg; ≈øhe dyed 1586.
V. Anne, Decea≈øed of the Plague.
VI. Dorothy, Married to Chri≈øtopher, Duke of Meckelburg in 1573. Decea≈øed 1575.
VII. Adolph the Fir≈øt, Duke of Sle≈øwick, born 1526. of whom, more hereafter, in the Ducal Line of Sle≈øwick.
VIII. Frederick, Bi≈øhop of Hilde≈øheim, born 1529. Decea≈øed Oct. the 27th. 1556.

div.p:
¬ß. V. Of the≈øe, Chri≈øtian the Third ≈øucceeded to the Throne, about the Year 1537. the beginning of who≈øe Reign was perplexed with many Difficulties; all which he Ma≈øter'd in the end. He e≈øtabli≈øhed the Reformed Religion throughout his Dominions, and cau≈øed the Holy Bible to be Tran≈ølated into the Dani≈øo Tongue; and above all, made it his chiefe≈øt care to enjoy a peaceable and quiet Reign. He departed this Life 15 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . leaving behind him the Character and Example of a Devout, Peaceable, and Excellent Prince. By his ≈øecond Marriage, which was with Dorothy, Daughter of Magnus, Duke of Sax-Lawenburg, he had live Children; the Daughters being Anne and Dorothy; the fir≈øt Married to Augu≈øtus, Elector of Saxony; the other to Ulrick Duke of Lunenburg. The Sons names were,
1. Magnus, Bi≈øhop of Derpte, in Livonia, who, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Ru≈ø≈øe, attempted, but in vain, the Reduction of Livonta. He departed this Life in Poland, An. 1585. leaving only a Daughter, who being carried into Mu≈øcovy, by her Mother, who was John Ba≈øilides, the Cza ‚Ä¢
's Daughter, was there Educated and Married to Albert Janowitz, Lord High Chancellor of that Country.
2. John the Second, Progenitor of the Ducal Line of Hol≈øtein, of whom more in the Eleventh Section. And,
3. Frederick the Second, Elde≈øt of the Three, tho' la≈øt named, who ≈øucceeded to the Throne after his Father's Decea≈øe, in the Year 1559. This Prince gave the I≈øle of hay to Tycho Brahe, that he might the better be at lei≈øure to make his A≈øtronomical Ob≈øervations. He had great Wars with the Swede, till the Year 1570. In 1574. he began to build Cromenburg; and two Years after open'd an Univer≈øity at Sora. He likewi≈øe highly adorned and advanc'd the Order of the Elephant. His Queen was the Prince≈øs Sophia of Meckeburg. By whom he had the≈øe following Sons and Daughters.
1. Elizabeth, born 1573. Married to Henry Julius, Duke of Brun≈øwick, 1590. Decea≈øed 1627.
2. Anne, born 1574. given in Marriage to James King of Scotland, and afterwards of Great Britain, on the 20th. of Aug. 1590. Decea≈øed March the 2d 1618.
3. Augu≈øta, born 1580. Married to Adolph, Duke of Hol≈øtein Gottorp, Decea≈øed 1629.
4. Hedewig, born 1581. and Married Chri≈øtianus the Second, Elector of Saxony; ≈øhe departed this Life 1602.

The Sons were,
1. Chri≈øtian the Fourth, born 1577.
2. Ulrick, Bi≈øhop of Sle≈øwick, Decea≈øed 1624. And
3. John, born 1583. who went into Mu≈øcovy, where, in hopes of ≈øucceeding to that Crown, he Married the Prince≈øs Alexia, but being ≈øeiz'd by an Apoplexy, dyed without I≈ø≈øue, An. 1602.

Chri≈øtian the Fourth, was elected King, at the Age of Thirteen, his Father being yet living, who having his thoughts on War, tho' in time of Peace, gave Orders for the rai≈øing ≈øeveral Fine Fortifications; namely, Chri≈øtian≈øtadt in Schonen, Chri≈øtiania in Norway, Chri≈øtianople in Bleking, Gluck≈øtadt upon the Elbe, and Chri≈øtian-Presk in Hol≈øtein. He was engaged in ≈øeveral great Wars; as fir≈øt, with the Swede, then with Count Schaumburg; a ≈øecond time with the Swede in 1611. followed by a Peace in 1613. Then with the Emperour in 1625. on behalf of the Circle of the Lower-Saxony, by who≈øe Forces he was defeated in a Battel fought not far from Lutheram Bohrenburg; then again with the Swede in 1643, at which time he had various Succe≈øs, till at length a Peace was concluded with 'em at the Town of Brem≈øbroe, in the Year 1648. In 1618. he ≈øet out a Fleet for the I≈øle of Zeilan in the Ea≈øt-Indies, the fir≈øt that ever ≈øailed from Denmark for tho≈øe Parts, which returned Freighted with Spice. The Partner of his Bed and Fortunes was Anne Catharine, Daughter of Joachim Frederick Elector of Brandenburg, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Chri≈øtian, born 1603. elected to ≈øucceed him, but dyed in the Prime of his Age, An. 1647.
2. Frederick, of whom more in the next Sect. And,
3. Ulrick, born 1611. decea≈øed in Sile≈øia, of a Wound receiv'd by a Musquet-≈øhot, An. 1631.

Be≈øides the≈øe, he had many natural Children; namely, John Ulrick of Guldenlow, by a certain Lady, named Catharina Andraea: As al≈øo Chri≈øtian Woldemar, Earl of Hil≈øtein, Decea≈øed at Lublin, in the Swedi≈øh Service again≈øt the Poles, An. 1656. Frederica Sophia, Married to Chri≈øtian Earl of Penzen, Councellor of State: Frederica Eleanora, Married to Cornifitz, Count d' Ulfeldt, the King's chief Ta≈øter, decea≈øed, 1684. Frederica Elizabeth, given in Marriage to John de Lindenau, Councellor of State: Chri≈øtina to Hannibal a Gee≈øtadt, Governour of Norway: Frederica Hedewig e≈øpous'd to Ebbo d' Uhlefeldt: And Dorothy, who changed her Religion, and took the Habit of a Nun: Which Seven were born him, by Madam Catharine Munkin. La≈øt of all, by Madam de Wibiken, he was Father of Ulrick Chri≈øtianus de Guldenlow, decea≈øed 1661. And Elizabeth, Married to Nicholas Count d' Ahlefeldt.

9. VI. Frederick the Third, Bi≈øhop of Bremen, being beaten out of his Bi≈øhoprick by the Swede, was after his Father and Brother Chri≈øtian's Decea≈øe, elected King of Denmark and Norway, in the Year 1648. He di≈øcover'd Count Uhlefeldt's Con≈øpiracy: And had War with the Engli≈øh, as al≈øo with the Swede, till a Peace was made at Ro≈øchild, 1654. But the War breaking out a fre≈øh the next Year, Copenhagen was be≈øieged by the Swedes, and Tuyen recovered by the Danes; When a Peace was
again concluded in 1666. In his Reign, the con≈øtitution of the Government was altered, and of an elective Monarchy made Hereditary. His Queen was Sophia Amalia, Daughter of George Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue as followeth:
1. Chri≈øtian the Fifth, the pre≈øent King of Denmark.
2. Anna Sophia, born 1647. and married in 1666. to John George the Third, Elector of Saxony.
3. Frederica Amalia, born 1648. and married in 1667. to Chri≈øtian Albert, Duke of Sle≈øwick.
4. Wilhelmina Erne≈øtina, born 1650. the now Relict of Charles late Elector Palatine.
5. George, who cro≈ø≈øing the Seas, went for England, where he married the Prince≈øs Anne, Daughter of James Duke of York, ≈øince King of England, on the 28th of July, 1683. by whom he has had many Children; but all Daughters, and ≈øhort lived. However, in Aug. la≈øt, this pre≈øent Year, 1689. ≈øhe was at length brought to Bed of a Prince, the Joy and Hopes of the Engli≈øh Nation.
6. Ulrica Eleanora, born 1656 and married to Charles the Eleventh, the pre≈øent King of Sweden, May the 16th. 1680.

Be≈øides the≈øe, he left a natural Son, Ulrick Frederick, Count de Guldenlow, the now Governour of Norway, who, by a certain noble Lady, is Father of Woldemar, Baron of Lowenthal, a Colonel in the Dani≈øh Forces. Afterwards he
took to Wife Antonia Augu≈øta, Daughter of Anthony Count Oldenburg, in the Year 1677. by whom he has many Children, and among≈øt the re≈øt Frederick Chri≈øtianus; As for the Good King, he departed this life, Feb. the 9th. 1670.

¬ß. VII. And now for Chri≈øtian the pre≈øent King, his Son and Suce≈ø≈øor, born 1645. who, in ≈øhort, has had ≈øharp Wars with Sweden: Has Impri≈øoned his Chancellor Greiffenfield for life: Sat down before Hamburgh, but was forced to rai≈øe his Siege: Has re≈øtored the Danobrogick Order of Knighthood: Has ≈øurrendred the Dutchy of Sle≈øwick to the Duke of Hol≈øtein, and is married to Charlotte, Daughter of William Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, by whom he has I≈ø≈øue a fair Race of Princes, viz.

list.item: 1. Frederick, born Oct. the 21≈øt. 1671.
2. Chri≈øtianus, Oct. the 18th. 1675.
3. Sophia Hedewig, Aug. the 28th. 1677.
4. Chri≈øtiana Charlotte. Jan. the 18th. 1679.
5. Charles, Oct. the 25th. 1680. And,
6. William, 1687.

div.head: Of the Augmentation of the Regal Family.
div.p:
¬ß. VIII. AFter it had been enacted in the Reign of Queen Margaret, that for the future, Denmark, Sweden, and Norway, ≈øhould be Governed by the ≈øame Prince; Chri≈øtianus the Fir≈øt, Earl of Oldenburg, became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the≈øe Three Kingdoms, by Right of Election; that is to ≈øay, fir≈øt of Denmark, to which appertained Jutlandt, Zelandt, Tuyen, Schonen, Halland, Bleking, Temeren, Bornholm,
Al≈øen, Lang-Landt, Lalandt, Hyen, &c. ≈øecondly ‚Ä¢ f Norway, and its Dependencies, to which ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øo belonged the I≈øles of Orkney and I≈øeland;
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ irdly of Sweden, together with both the Sothlands, Lapland, Finland, and other its appurtenances. In the Year 1459. Chri≈øtianus he Fir≈øt bought the Earldom (or County) of Hol≈øtein, for three and thirty Thou≈øand Florins. „Äà‚óä„Äâ 1474. the County of Hol≈øtein was erected into a Dutchy of the ≈øacred Roman Empire. Upon the Death of Adolph, Duke of Sle≈øwick, that Dutchy, as held in Fee, fell to the Crown. Chri≈øtian the Third, bought the I≈øle of Oe≈øel, and Lord≈øhip of Auron in Livonia, where likewi≈øe he had the City of Ravel, delivered up ‚Ä¢ o him, by Maurice Wrangel, Bi≈øhop thereof. ‚Ä¢ n the Year 1676. Anthony Gunther, the la≈øt Earl of Oldenburg, dying without I≈ø≈øue, the pre≈øent King, by right of Inheritance, became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Counties of Oldenburg and Del
‚Ä¢ enbor≈øt; as al≈øo the Lord≈øhip of Kniphu≈øe. In the Year 1682. there was an acce≈ø≈øion to this Lrown, of the Lord≈øhip of Jevern, by the Grant of the French King. La≈øt of all, Chri≈øtian Adolph, Duke of Hol≈øtein in Sunderburg was nece≈ø≈øitated to part with his Soveraignty to the pre≈øent King.

div.head: Of its Decrea≈øe.
div.p:
¬ß. IX. THe fir≈øt, and indeed the greate≈øt diminution ≈øuffered by the Royal Family of Denmark, was in the Year 1469. at which time the Prince≈øs Margaret was given in Marriage to James the Third, King of Scotland,
together with the I≈øles of Orkney and Hetland, as ≈øecurity for her Portion, which was fifty thou≈øand Florins of the Rhine. In 1524 the Kingdom of Sweden was torn from it. In 1544. at a divi≈øion then made of Lands in the Dutchy of Hol≈øtein, 'twixt King Chri≈øtian the Third, and his Brother Adolph, the King parted with the Governments of Trictou, Oldenburg, and Neu≈øtadt, together with the Mona≈øtries of Ci≈ømar and Rheinbeck; as al≈øo the whole Dutchy of Sle≈øwick, tho' this la≈øt was to be held by Adolph and his Po≈øterity, only as a Fife of the Crown. In 1564. at another divi≈øion of Lands then made, 'twixt King Frederick the Second, and his Brother John, the latter obtain'd the I≈øles of Al≈øen and Arroe; as al≈øo the Praefectures or Governments of Ploen, Rheinfeld, and Arensburg, with their Dependencies. About the Year 1585. the then King of Denmark lo≈øt Oe≈øel, as al≈øo what-ever el≈øe he held in Liffland. In 1658. Halland, the I≈øle of Bornholm. Schonen, and Bleking, were ≈øet over to the Swede by the fifth Article of the Peace of Ro≈øchild: As was al≈øo the Government of Babuys in Norway, with the City and Ca≈øtle thereof, together with the Government of Drontheam, and whatever el≈øe the Danes had been hitherto po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of in the I≈øle of Rugen; tho' afterwards by the Articles of Peace concluded on in the Year 1660. Drontheam and Bornhelm were again ≈øurrendred to the Danes. In 1689. Chri≈øtian the pre≈øent King of Denmark, re≈øtored the Dutchy of Sle≈øwick to Chri≈øtian Albert the pre≈øent Duke, together with the ab≈øolute and independent Sovereignty thereof. The ≈øame
Year, in the Month of Aug. the Lord≈øhip of Jevern by an amicable agreement, was ≈øurrendred to the Prince of Anhalt-Serve≈øten.

div.head: Of the Preten≈øions of this Hou≈øe.
div.p: ¬ß. X. THe Claims of the Kings of Denmark, are to the City of Hamburg, as built and enlarged by the ancient Earls of Hol≈øtein, of the Family of Schaumburg; See Harman de Lesbeke, Monk of Minden his Chron. Com. Schavenb. inter opu≈øcula rerum German. Celeberr. Henrici Meimbomii. And to the I≈øles of Orkney, as Mortgaged to the ancient Kings of Scotland.

div.head: Of the Ducal Line of Hol≈øtein.
div.p: ¬ß. XI. IT has been already ≈øaid in the fifth Section, Numb. 2.
