That John Brother of Frederick the Second, King of Denmark, and Son to King Chri≈øtian the Third, was the fir≈øt Progenitor of the pre≈øent Ducal Line of Hol≈øtein, who being twice Married, became the Father of a very numerous I≈ø≈øue, which ≈øpread it ≈øelf into the four branches of Sunderburg, Nordburg, Glucksburg, and Pleen.

div.head: Of the Branch of Sunderburg.
div.p:
¬ß. XII. THis Branch began in Alexander, born 1573. who, in the divi≈øion of Lands with his Brethren, had Sunderburg, part of the I≈øle of Al≈øen, and part of the Penin≈øula of Sunderwick, for his Patrimony. Of this
Prince's Po≈øterity we ≈øhall ≈øpeak in the fir≈øt place: As for him≈øelf, he departed this Life in 1627. having had Ten Children by his Wife, the Lady Dorothy of Schwartzburg; the Sons being,
1. John Chri≈øtian, Duke of Hol≈øtein in Sunderburg, who decea≈øed in the Year, 1653 leaving I≈ø≈øue by his Wife, the Lady Anne of Oldenburg, a Son named
1. Chri≈øtian Adolph, Duke of Hol≈øtein, &c. who now lives at Frantzhagen in Sax-Lawenburg, which was his Wife's Portion, together with his Son, Prince Leopold Chri≈øtian, born 1678.
2. Erne≈øtus Guntherus, who lives at Augsburg, with his Wife Augu≈øta, Daughter to his Uncle Philip, Duke of Glucksburg; by whom he has had I≈ø≈øue, Frederick, who, now ≈øerves in the King of Denmark's Army: Erne≈øtus Philip, ≈ølain at the Siege of Stetin: Frederick William, Provo≈øt of the Cathedral Church at Hamburg: Lovi≈øe Charlotte, married to Lewis Frederick Prince of Hol≈øtein in Beck: And Erne≈øtus Guntheras, who turned his Religion, and was made Canon of Colegne.
3. Alexander Henry, This Prince turn'd Catholick, and died in the Year 1667. leaving I≈ø≈øue by his Wife (a certain Reform'd Mini≈øter's Daughter) Three Sons, named, Ferdinand Leopold, Provo≈øt of the Cathedral at Bre≈ølaw: Alexander Rudolph, Canon of Ble≈ølaw and Amuzen: And George Erne≈øtus, Lieutenant General in one of the Imperial Armies.
4. Augu≈øtus Philip, who purcha≈øed the Ca≈øtie of Beck, where he died, An. 1675 leaving I≈ø≈øue Sophia Lovi≈øe, married to Frederick, Count de Bukeburg: Augu≈øtus, Captain of the Guards to his Electoral Highne≈øs the Duke of Brandenburg, who married Lovi≈øe, Daughter of Philip, Count de Lippe, in Bukeburg, and died of a Dy≈øentery at the Siege of Bon, An. 1689. Lewis Frederick, likewi≈øe Captain of the Brandenburg Guards, married Jan. the 11th. 1685. to Lovi≈øe Charlotte, his Uncle Erne≈øt Gunther's Daughter: Maximilian, Anthony Gunther, and Erne≈øtus Camire.
5. Philip Lewis, born 1620. who bought the Ca≈øtle of Wi≈øenburg in Mi≈ønia, but lives at pre≈øent in the Ca≈øtle of Oberkozau in Voightlandt, where he begot three Sons, who≈øe names are,
1. Frederick, Lieutenant-General among≈øt the Imperiali≈øts, who took to Wife Charlotte, Dutche≈øs of Lignitz, by whom he has I≈ø≈øue Leopold, born Jan. the 12th. 1674.
2. Charles Lewis, Captain of the Guards to the Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe. And,
3. William Chri≈øtian, born 1661. a Captain in the Elector of Saxony's Forces.

div.head: Of the Branch of Nordburg.
div.p:
¬ß. XIII. THe ≈øecond Son of John Duke of Hol≈øtein, was Frederick, Propagator of the Branch of Nordburg, who changed this Life for a better, An. 1658. his Children being,
1. John Bugi≈ølaus, born 1629. decea≈øed a Batchellor, 1680.
2. Chri≈øtian Augu≈øtus, who twice Travelled over Palae≈øtine, and highly approv'd him≈øelf in the Wars, by his good Services to the Dutch and Engli≈øh.
3. Rudolph Frederick, Colonel in the Dutch Forces, who married the Counte≈øs Bibiana, Daughter of Sigi≈ømund Sifrid, Count de Promnitz, the Baron de Lippe's Relict, decea≈øed 1685. having born him a Son, and a Daughter; namely, Sophia Henrietta, born 1682. and Erne≈øtus Leopold, 1684 both which are brought up in the Court of Wolfembuttel. He him≈øelf died in November, 1688.
4. Elizabeth Juliana, born, May the 24th. 1634. and married to Anthony Ulrick, Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg, 1656.
5. Dorothy Hedewig, formerly Lady Abbe≈øs of Gander≈øheim, but turn'd Catholick, and married Chri≈øtopher Count de Ranzan. And,
6. Lovi≈øe Amaena, married to John Frederick, Count de Hohenlob, in the Year 1665.

div.head: Of the Branch of Glucksburg.
div.p:
¬ß. XIV. THe Third Son of Duke John of Hol≈øtein, was Philip, Propagator of the Branch of Glucksburg, who≈øe Wife Sophia Hedewig of Sax-Lawenburg, bore him Eleven Children, whereof Five were ≈øhort-liv'd, the re≈øt being,
1. Chri≈øtian, born 1627. who lives in the Ca≈øtle of Glucksburg, with his Three Sons, Philip Erne≈øtus, born 1673. Joachim Adolph, 1679. And Chri≈øtian Augu≈øtus, 1681.
2. Mary Elizabeth, born 1628. married to George Albert, Marque≈øs of Brandenburg-Culmbach, 1651. decea≈øed 1604.
3. Sophia Hedewig, married to Maurice, Duke of Saxon-Zeitz. She died 1652.
4. Augu≈øta e≈øpou≈øed by her Cou≈øin-Germain Erne≈øtus Gunther of Augsburg, 1651.
5. Chri≈øtina, born 1634. and married to Chri≈øtian Duke of Sax Mersburg, 1650. And,
6. Dorothy, married fir≈øt to Chri≈øtian Lewis, Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg and after his decea≈øe to Frederick William the Great Elector of Brandenburg, An. 1668. She died 1689.

div.head: Of the Branch of Ploen.
div.p:
¬ß. XV. IT remains, we now ≈øpeak of the Branch of Ploen, which was propagated by Joachim Erne≈øtus, Duke John's Fourth Son, who died in the Eightieth Year of his Age, An. 1671. The I≈ø≈øue of his Body now living are,
1. John Adolph, born 1634. the Husband of Dorothy Sophia, Daughter of Rudolph Augu≈øtus, Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg, by whom he has had Three Sons; namely, Adolph Augu≈øtus, born 1680. Joachim Erne≈øtus, 1681. decea≈øed the ≈øame Year; And John Ulrick, 1684.
2. Augu≈øtus, born 1636. ≈øometime Admini≈øtrator of Magduburg; Father of Two Sons, by his Wife, the Prince≈øs Charlotte, Elizabeth of Anhalt; who≈øe names are, Joachim Frederick, born 1668. and Chri≈øtian Charles, born 1674.
3 Joachim Erne≈øtus, born 1637. General of the Foreign Hor≈øe, in the Service of the Spani≈øh Netherlands.

div.head: Of the Ducal Line of Sle≈øwick.
div.p:
¬ß. XVI. 'TIs now time to treat of the Ducal Line of Sle≈øwick, the Author whereof was Adolph, younge≈øt Son of King Frederick the Fir≈øt, born 1526. who, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Nephew King Frederick the Second, overthrew the Rebels of Dietmar≈øh, and made them ≈øubject to his Government, and thro' the whole cour≈øe of his Life, highly approved his Courage, on many other occa≈øions. Moreover, he was Con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Slewick and Hilde≈øheim. At his Death he was ≈øucceeded in his Dutchy by his Son John Adolph, who had been Arch-Bi≈øhop of Bremen, and Bi≈øhop of Lubeck, ever ≈øince the Year, 1585. which Provinces, however, he made over to his Brother John Frederick, upon his coming to be Duke. In 1603. he had Homage done him by the Hamburgers, as Duke of Hor≈øtein. His Sons were,
1. Adolph Slain at the Battel of Leip≈øick, 1631.
2. John, Con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Lubeck, decea≈øed 1655. leaving only one Son, named, John Augu≈øtus, who being
weak in his Intellects, lives under the Ward≈øhip of his Cou≈øin-Germain, the pre≈øent Bi≈øhop of Lubeck. And,
3. Frederick, elde≈øt of the Three, tho' la≈øt named, who ≈øucceeded his Father, Anno 1616.

This Prince very much inlarged the publick Library, and built the City Frederick≈øtadt. Moreover he ≈øent an Emba≈ø≈øie to the Courts of Mu≈øcovy and Per≈øia; and in 1658. took off the Feudatory Obligation, which, till then, lay on the Dutchy of Sle≈øwick, to the Crown of Denmark. He departed this Life, in the Year 1659. having had to Wife Mary Elizabeth, Daughter of John George, the fir≈øt Elector of Saxony, who died 1684. and by her, this following I≈ø≈øue,
1. Magdalen Sibilla, born 1631. and married to Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, Duke of Meckleburg Gu≈øtrow.
2. Hedewig Eleanor, born 1636. the now Relict of Charles Gu≈øtavus late King of Sweden.
3. Anne Dorothy, born 1640. as yet unmarried.
4. Augu≈øta Maria, given in Marriage to Frederick Magnus, Marque≈øs of Baden Durlach, An. 1670.
5. Chri≈øtian Albert, the pre≈øent Duke, born Feb. the 3d. 1641. who ≈øucceeded his Father, and in 1665. opened an Univer≈øity at Kiel. In 1676. he lo≈øt the whole Dutchy of Sle≈øwick, but the difference being ≈øome Years after amicably made up 'twixt him and the King of Denmark,
'twas again re≈øtored him by His Maje≈øty, An. 1689. His Dutche≈øs is Fred ‚Ä¢ rica Amalia, Si≈øter to the pre≈øent K. of Dermark by whom he has I≈ø≈øue, Sophia Amalia, 1670. Frederick, 1671. Chri≈øtian Augu≈øtus 1673 And Mary Elizabeth, 1678.
6. Augu≈øtus Frederick, the pre≈øent Bi≈øhop of Laiveck, who has taken to Wife Chri≈øtina, Daughter of Augu≈øtus, late Duke of Saxony, and Admini≈øtrator of Magdeburg, but in all appearance like to have no I≈ø≈øue by her.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Hou≈øe of Sweden.
div.p:
¬ß. I. ABout the beginning of the la≈øt Century, the Nobility of Sweden, grown weary of the Tyranny of Chri≈øtian the Second, King of Denmark, elected Gu≈øtavus, Son of Erick of Wa≈øa √† Grypsholm, fir≈øt Governour, then Duke, and la≈øt of all in the Year 1523. King of Sweden, Gothland, and the Vandals; at which time he had a ≈øharp War with the Danes, as al≈øo with the Ru≈ø≈øe, tho' afterwards he had Peace with the fir≈øt. He had al≈øo a di≈øpute with the City Lubeck in Saxony; and departed this Life in the Year, 1660. His Queens were, Mary, Daughter of Erick Abraham of Laholm; and Catharine,
Daughter of Gu≈øtavus, Governour of We≈øt-Gothland, by which Ladies he had I≈ø≈øue Three Sons, Erick, John, and Charles.

Erick the Fourteenth of the Name, ≈øucceeding his Father in the Throne, was Crown'd in the Year 1561. and had Wars with the Panes and Pole. He committed his Brother John to Cu≈øtody, and marrying Catharine, a Woman of a ba≈øe Birth, and his Concubine before, cau≈øed her to he Crown'd Queen at Stockholm, An. 1568. upon which falling into the contempt and hatred of his Brethren, he was the Year following ≈øeized and Impri≈øoned, together with his new Concubine Queen, in the very Ca≈øtle of Stockholm. Hereupon the Government de≈øcended to John the Third, ≈øecond Son of Gu≈øtavus, by his Wife Mary of Laholm. This Prince in 1570. concluded the Peace of Stetin with the Danes; as al≈øo with the City Lubeck; but continued the War with the Czar. His Son Sigi≈ømund, by Catharine Daughter of Sigi≈ømund King of Poland, was Crown'd King of Poland, Dec. 17. 1587. Him≈øelf died 1592. having fir≈øt ≈øecured the Succe≈ø≈øion of Sweden, to his Son Sigi≈ømund, who was accordingly Crown'd, Feb. 19. 1594. tho' the Swedi≈øh Nobility renounc'd their Allegiance five Years after, viz 1699. and deprived him of the Kingly Dignity, ≈øub≈øtituting in his place his Uncle, Charles the Ninth, Third Son of the above named Gu≈øtavus, and Brother by the ≈øame Mother, to the late King John the Third; under whom a War immediately broke out with the Poles for Liffland, which afterwards gave ri≈øe to another bloody One with the Danes.
There was ≈øurviving, at this time, another Son of John the Third's, by his Wife Gunilla, Daughter of John Bielk, who≈øe name was al≈øo John: He was created Duke of Finland, and Ea≈øt-Gothland, and died without I≈ø≈øue, 1618. notwith≈øtanding he had married Mary Elizabeth, Daughter to his Uncle Charles the Ninth.

¬ß. II. Upon which Charles, and his Po≈øterity of both Sexes, the Crown was ≈øettled, Sigi≈ømund and his Race being excluded for ever. He was Crown'd in the Year 1607. having been Governour of the Common-wealth, now more than ≈øeven Years. His Death bears date 1611. in the ≈øixty fir≈øt Year of his Age. The fir≈øt Wife he married, was Anne Mary, Daughter of Lewis Elector Palatine, by whom he had a Daughter named Catharine, living at his Death; married to John Ca≈øimire, Count Palatine of Deux-Ponts, and by that match, Grandmother of the pre≈øent King. His ≈øecond Wife's name, was Chri≈øtina, Daughter of Adolph, Duke of Hol≈øtein, who bore him Two Sons, and as many Daughters, viz.

list.item: 1. Chri≈øtina, decea≈øed in her Infancy.
2. Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, of whom more in the next Sect.
3. Mary Elizabeth, married to John Duke of Finland. And,
4. Charles Philip, Duke of Sudermanland, decea≈øed 1622.

div.p:
¬ß. III. Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, who ≈øucceeded his Father, was born in the Year 1594. and Crowned King of Sweden, 1617. Two years
after his Father's Death he made Peace with the Danes, An 1613. and with the Mu≈øcovites, the ≈øame Year he was Crown'd. He continued the War with the Poles, and reduced all Liffland, in the Year 1625. making Pru≈ø≈øia Regal the ≈øeat of War. In 1630. he made an Expedition into Germany, for ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the Enemies of the Reformed Religion, where he was ≈ølain at the Battel of Lutzen, Nov. 16. 1632. leaving I≈ø≈øue by Mary Eleanor, Daughter of John Sigi≈ømund, Elector of Brandenburg, only a Daughter, the Prince≈øs Chri≈øtina; who, under the Regency of her Mother, carried on the War in Germany, by her General, Charles Gu≈øtavus of Deux-Ponts, her Father's Si≈øter's Son. In the mean time, the Dani≈øh War broke out a fre≈øh, till a Peace was again concluded with 'em in the Year 1645. As al≈øo with the Emperour and his Confederates. In 1648. ≈øhe changed her Religion, and turned Catholick; and taking her way thro' France, went for Rome, where ≈øhe continued till the day of her Death, which was in the Year 1689. on April 9. Old Stile.

¬ß. IV. Hereupon the Government fell to Charles Gu≈øtavus, as next of Blood, being Son to Catharine, Gu≈øtavus Adolphus's Si≈øter, as hath been already ≈øaid. He was Crown'd King of Sweden, June 16. 1654. and immediately ingaged in a War with the Pole, wherein, by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Ally, Frederick William the Great, Elector of Brandenburg, he made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of almo≈øt all Poland and Pru≈ø≈øia. In the mean time the Mu≈øcovites make an Incur≈øion
into Liffland, and the Danes invade Bremen, both which he oppo≈øed with good ≈øucce≈øs. He departed this Life, Feb. 13. 1660. leaving by Hedewig Eleanor, Daughter of Frederick, Duke of Sle≈øwick, Charles the Eleventh, the pre≈øent King, at the Age of five Years, to ≈øucceed him. Who being educated under the Government of his Mother, and the Nohility, by the Mediation of the French King, concluded the Peace of St. Olives (in the fir≈øt Year of his Reign, 1660.) with the Emperor, the King of Poland, and his Serene Highne≈øs the Elector of Brandenburg. Afterwards making an Alliance with the French, he had a fre≈øh War with the Danes, as al≈øo the Elector of Brandenburg and his Allies, e≈øpecially with the Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg, till Peace was once more re≈øtored by the Treaty of Nimeguen. In 1680. he ≈øettled the Monarchy, and revoked all Grants of the Crown Demeans, made to this or that Family by any of his Ance≈øtors; and the ≈øame Year married Ulrica Eleanora, Prince≈øs of Denmark, by whom he has I≈ø≈øue,
1. Hedewig Sophia, born June 26. 1681.
2. Charles, Prince Royal, born June 17. 1682.
3. Ulrick Eleanor, Jan. 21. 1688. as for Gu≈øtavus Ulrick, and Charles Gu≈øtavus, they were both ≈øhort liv'd.
¬ß. V. It remains, we ≈øay ≈øomething of Sigi≈ømund the Third, King of Poland, who left Two Sons.

list.item: 1. Uladi≈ølaus the Fourth, his Succe≈ø≈øor in that Kingdom, who brought the Mu≈øcovites to ≈øuch terms, as made 'em Surrender to the Poles, whatever they had taken from them till that time; neverthele≈øs died without I≈ø≈øue, May 20. 1648. And,

2. John Ca≈øimire, Je≈øuit and Cardinal, who upon his Brother's decea≈øe, was by a di≈øpen≈øation from the Pope, Elected and Crowned King on the 17th. of January in the ≈øame Year; yet afterwards abdidicated the Government, and re≈øumed his Mona≈øtick Habit, being the la≈øt of the Swedi≈øh Race in Poland.

div.head: Of the Augmentation of This Family.
div.p:
¬ß. VI. IT has been already ob≈øerv'd, how Gu≈øtavus of Wa≈øa was the fir≈øt of the pre≈øent Royal Family of Sweden: He was Crowned in 1523. and at the ≈øame time had Sweden, properly ≈øo called, put into his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, together with Nord-Land, Gothland, Finland, and whatever el≈øe appertained at that time to the Kingdom of Sweden. In 1578. the Soldiers of Liffland put them≈øelves, with their Families and Effects, under the Protection of Erick King of Sweden, which was afterwards confirmed by the Peace concluded at the Mona≈øtry of St. Olives in Dantzick; by which Peace all Livonia beyond the Dwina was adjudged to the Swede for ever; Article the 4th. Sect. 1. In 1618. Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, by the Peace then made with the Mu≈øcovite, gained the Ru≈ø≈øian Carelia and Ingermanlands.
In 1648. the hither Pomerania, with the I≈øle of Rugen, &c. were yielded up to the Swedes, as were al≈øo the City of Wei≈ømar, Dutchy of Bremen, and Principality of Ferden, by the In≈øtrument of the Peace of O≈øenburg, Art. 10. By the Peace of Ro≈øchild, concluded with the Danes, 1658. there was an Acce≈ø≈øion to this Crown of Halland, Schenen, and Bleking, together with the Government and Citadel of Babuys, all which was ratified by the Treaty of Nimeguen.

div.head: Of its Decrea≈øe.
div.p: ¬ß. VII. THere is ≈øcarce any In≈øtance to be given in this Family, of any diminution ≈øuffered by It; unle≈øs the Inhabitants of Ingermanland's leaving their Native Country, and retiring into Mu≈øcovy, with their Families and Effects, be looked upon as One; and therefore can have no Claims, were it not that the pre≈øent King of Sweden has a ju≈øt preten≈øion to the Dutchy of Deux-Ponts, taken from his Family by the French King.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Hou≈øe of Portugal.
div.p:
¬ß. I. HOw Portugal then called Lu≈øitania, together with all Spain, became fir≈øt ≈øubject to the Roman Government; how the Goths beat out the Romans, and e≈øtabli≈øhed them≈øelves there; how afterwards, about the Year 714. the Moors and Saracens, after a total defeat given Roderick, the la≈øt King of the Goths, made them≈øelves Ma≈øters (in a manner) of the whole Country; the brevity of our de≈øign will not permit us to di≈øcour≈øe at large. If any are de≈øirous to be acquainted with the particulars of the≈øe Tran≈øactions, let 'em con≈øult the famous Pufendorf, and tho≈øe other Authors, mentioned by Beckman, in the fir≈øt Chapter and fir≈øt Section, of his Civil Hi≈øtory. 'Tis ≈øufficient for us to know, that towards the latter end of the Eleventh Century, Alphon≈øo the Sixth, King of Ca≈øtile, had very frequent and bloody Wars with the Moors, in which a certain Prince named Henry, de≈øcended (as ≈øome ≈øay) from the Hou≈øe of Burgundy (as others) from that of Lorain, was chiefly ≈øignalized for his Valour, and good Services to the Crown. King Alphon≈øo, in reward of his Merit, gave him Portugal, then lately recovered from the Moors, under the Title of an Earldom, together with his natural Daughter There≈øia
to Wife; neverthele≈øs with this condition, that he ≈øhould continue a Va≈ø≈øal to Ca≈øtile. This Prince's Son was Alphon≈øo the Fir≈øt, who throwing off the Spani≈øh Yoak, and having ≈øubdued ≈øeveral petty Kings of the Moors, cau≈øed him≈øelf to be Proclaimed King of Portugal, about the Year 1139. And departed this Life 1185. leaving for his Succe≈ø≈øor Sanctius the Fir≈øt, Father of Alphon≈øo the Second, who died in the Year 1223. and was ≈øucceeded by Sanctius the Second, who dying without I≈ø≈øue, in the Year 1246. the Crown fell to his Brother Alphon≈øo the Third. This Alphon≈øo had Algarve given him in Dowry with his Queen, the Prince≈øs Beatrix, Daughter of Alphon≈øo the Tenth, King of Ca≈øtile; and was Father of Denys, of who≈øe eminent Vertues, and great Actions the Pertugue≈øe to this day relate Wonders: It was he that Founded the Univer≈øity of Coimbra, and died in the Year 1325. His Son was Alphon≈øo the Fourth, who begat Peter, (or Pedro) Father of Ferdinand, King of Portugal, who, after many bloody Engagements with the Moors, ended his days without I≈ø≈øue, in the Year 1333.

¬ß. II. Hereupon followed an Interregnum, of almo≈øt two Years continuance, when, by the unanimous con≈øent of all the Nobility, John the Ba≈øtard, natural Son of Peter, mentioned in the precedent Section, was Proclaim'd King; and had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Henry, born 1401.
2. Peter, Duke of Coimbra, put to death by his Nephew, King Alphon≈øo the Fifth, in the Year 1449.
3. Ferdinand taken Pri≈øoner by tho≈øe of Barbary, and carried into Africk, where he died 1443.
4. Henry, who fir≈øt di≈øcovered the Madera I≈øland in 1420. and died 1460.
5. Alphon≈øo the Ba≈øtard, Duke of Braganza, (a natural Son) decea≈øed 1461.

Edward the Elde≈øt, who ≈øucceeded in the Throne, married Eleanor, Daughter of Ferdinand King of Ca≈øtile; and died of the Plague, in the Year 1438. leaving I≈ø≈øue Two Sons,
1. Alphon≈øo the Fifth, born 1432. And,
2. Ferdinand, Infant of Portugal, and Duke of Vi≈øco, decea≈øed 1470.

Alphon≈øo the Fifth, at his Father's death, a≈øcended the Throne; and had ≈øharp and frequent Wars with the Moors; as al≈øo with Ferdinand the Catholick King of Ca≈øtile. His Death bears date 1481. at which time he was ≈øucceeded by his Son.

1. John the Second, who, notwith≈øtanding he had taken his Cou≈øin-Germain, the Lady Eleanor, Daughter of Ferdinand Duke of Vi≈øco, to be his Queen, yet had he no I≈ø≈øue that out-liv'd him; his only Son Alphon≈øo coming to an accidental Death in the Year 1491. whereas him≈øelf Surviv'd till 1495.

Look we back therefore to Ferdinand, Duke of Vi≈øco, and his Po≈øterity, who≈øe Male I≈ø≈øue were,
1. James, Duke of Vi≈øco, put to death in the Year 1484. by his Cou≈øin-Germain, King John the Second.
2. Emanuel, 1469.

¬ß. III. This Emanuel, after the Death of King John the Second, was Crowned King of Portugal, in the Year 1495. He expelled the Moors out of his Countries, and obliged the Jews to profe≈øs the Chri≈øtian Faith: He ≈øubdued great part of the Ea≈øt-Indies, and planted Bra≈øil with Colonies from Portugal. His fir≈øt Queen was I≈øabel, Daughter to his Catholick Maje≈øty Ferdinand King of Spain: His ≈øecond, Mary, I≈øabella's Si≈øter: And his la≈øt, Eleanor, Daughter of Philip the Fir≈øt, King of Spain, married afterwards to Francis the Fir≈øt King of France. By the fir≈øt Lady he had I≈ø≈øue only one Son, Prince Michael, who had he liv'd, wou'd have Heired all the Spani≈øh Territories: But by the ≈øecond and third Venture,
1. John the Third, the no le≈øs happy Succe≈ø≈øor of a Fortunate Father, born 1502. married to Catharine, Daughter of Philip the Fir≈øt King of Spain; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue John, Infant of Portugal, decea≈øed before his Father, who died not till the Year 1557. At which time there was ≈øurviving of the Body of John, Infant of Portugal, by Joan his Wife, Daughter of Charles the Fifth, Emperour and King of Spain, Prince Seba≈øtian, a Child about Three Years of Age, born 1554. who ≈øucceeded his Grand-Father John the Third in the Kingdom of Portugal. This unfortunate Prince, ≈øome Years after, making a de≈øcent upon Africk, peri≈øhed there with his whole Army, Aug. the 4th. 1578.
2. I≈øabella, born 1503. married to Charles the Fifth, Emperor and King of Spain, 1526. decea≈øed 1593.
3. Henry, born 1512, promoted to a Red-Hat 1546. And afterwards, upon the mo≈øt unhappy death of his Nephew Seba≈øtian, to be King of Portugal, but died 1580.
4. Edward, Infant of Portugal, born 1515. decea≈øed 1540. who≈øe Wife was I≈øabel, Daughter of James Duke of Braganza, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Catharine, married to John Duke of Braganza, who≈øe Grand≈øon became afterwards po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Crown of Portugal, as will appear, in the next Section.
5. Lewis, Infant of Portugal, decea≈øed 1555. leaving only a natural Son, called Antonio, who, upon the death of his Uncle Henry, was elected King 15‚Äî. But being in the ≈øame Year beat out of his Country, by Philip the Second, King of Spain, fled into France, and ended his days at Paris, An. 1595.

¬ß. IV. Thus fell the Government into the hands of the Spaniards; for Philip the Second, partly becau≈øe he was Son of I≈øabella, Daughter of Emanuel King of Portugal; and partly becau≈øe he had married Mary, Daughter of John the Third; on the≈øe Pretences made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of the Kingdom by force of Arms, in the Year 1580. Neverthele≈øs, 'twas again lo≈øt by his Grand≈øon, in the Year 1640. for the Portugue≈øe, actually rejecting the Spani≈øh
Yoak, elected John Duke of Braganza to be their King. This Prince, born March 19. 1604. was de≈øcended of the Po≈øterity of Alphon≈øo, the fir≈øt Duke of Braganza, who was natural Son of John the Fir≈øt, King of Portugal, as you may ≈øee, by looking back to the ≈øecond Section, Numb. 5. And his Grand-mother was Catharine, Daughter of Edward Infant of Portugal, mention'd by us in the precedent Section, Numb. 4. He governed the State of Portugal, from 1640. till 1656. in which Year he departed this Life Nov. 6. His Queen was Donna Lucia, Daughter of John Emanuel Perez de Gu≈øman, Duke of Medina Sidonia, who bore him I≈ø≈øue as followeth:
1. Theodo≈øius, Infant of Portugal, decea≈øed 1653.
2. Catharine, born at Villa Vico≈øa, Nov. 15. O. S. 1638. and e≈øpou≈øed at Port≈ømouth, by His late Maje≈øty King Charles the Second, in the Month of May, 1662.
3. Alphon≈øo the Sixth, born 1643. who under the Regency of his Mother had ≈øharp Wars with the Spaniards, with whom at length he concluded a Peace in the Year 1668. In 1667. he took to Wife the Lady Mary Frances Elizabeth, Daughter of Charles Amadeus de Savoy, Duke of Nemours, who, after ≈øixteen Months living with him, procured a Divorce, and retired to a Cloy≈øter. In 1668. he was depo≈øed, as judged incapable either of a ≈øecond Marriage or the Government, and ≈øent the Year following to the Tercera I≈øland, where he ended his days 1683.
4. Peter, born 1648. who, upon his Brother Alphon≈øo's being Depo≈øed in 1668. was made fir≈øt Regent, and after his death, King of Portugal. By a di≈øpen≈øation from his Holine≈øs, he married the Prince≈øs Mary Frances Elizabeth, his Brother's Wife, who, departing this Life Dec. 27. 1683. he in 1687. took to Wife the Lady Mary Sophia, Daughter of Philip William, Elector Palatine. He has a Daughter by the fir≈øt Venture now living, viz. Mary Elizabeth, born 1669. and in 1689. Contracted to John William, elde≈øt Son of Philip William, Elector Palatine. As for the pre≈øent Queen, ≈øhe was brought to Bed Aug. 30. 1688. of a young Prince, who≈øe date of Life was very ≈øhort; for it died the third of Sept. in the ≈øame Year. However, there is ju≈øt now arrived an Expre≈øs, whil≈øt we were writing this, with the happy news of the Birth of a ≈øecond Prince, born this pre≈øent October, 1689. to whom God grant long Life, and happy Succe≈øs: His name is John.

div.head: Of the Augmentation of This Hou≈øe.
div.p:
¬ß. V. BY what has been already ≈øaid, it plainly appears, how Alphon≈øo the Fir≈øt made Him≈øelf King of Portugal. Afterwards Alphon≈øo the Third obtained the Kingdom of Algarve, by way of Dowry with his Queen, the Prince≈øs Beatrix, Daughter of Alphon≈øo the Tenth, King of Ca≈øtile. In 1415. John the Ba≈øtard po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf of the City
of Ceuta in Africk. His Son Henry di≈øcovered the Madera, and ≈øubdu'd the Fortunate I≈ølands, and put his Country-men in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of them, An. 1620. Alphon≈øo the Fifth took Tangier, Arcilla, and Alca≈ø≈øar in Africa. Emanuel, by his General Albuquerque, made him≈øelf Ma≈øter of the Cities of Ormus, Malaca, Cochin, and Goa in the Ea≈øt-Indies. In Africk he ≈øubdued great part of Barbary, Guinee, Congo, the I≈øle of St. Thomas, Mo≈øambique, Melinda, Mombaza, and Zefala; as al≈øo Bra≈øil in America. Moreover, the Portugue≈øe hold the City of Maoco, ≈øituate in an I≈øland not far from China, as al≈øo the Azores I≈ølands, the chiefe≈øt of which is Tercera.

div.head: Of its Decrea≈øe.
div.p: ¬ß. VI. THo' Portugal, for ≈øome con≈øiderable time, acknowledged the Spani≈øh Government; yet it was re≈øtored to it ≈øelf in the Fortieth Year of this Century. Since which time little or no Encroachments have been made on it by any King or State, except the Hollanders, who≈øe Ea≈øt-India Company have, by little and little, wre≈øted from the Portugue≈øe (in a manner) all they were po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of in tho≈øe Parts, ≈øome few Places excepted. From all which it is plain, that This Family has Preten≈øions to no other Places, but tho≈øe taken from it by the Dutch.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Palatine and Bavarian Family.
div.p:
¬ß. I. HEnry the Lyon, Duke of Bavaria and Saxony (of whom we ≈øhall make farther mention, when we come to treat of the Hou≈øe of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg) being Pro≈øcribed and Outed of all his Territories, by the Emperor Frederick Barbaro≈ø≈øa. Otho, Earl of Wittelsbach and Scyre‚Äî. was created Duke of Bavaria by the ≈øaid Emperor, in the Year 1180. This Otho begat Lewis, Father of Otho the Second: Otho the Second married Agnes, ≈øole Daughter and Heire≈øs of Henry the Younger, Prince Palatine of the Rhine, and by rea≈øon thereof, obtained of the Emperor Frederick the Second, the Inve≈øtiture of that Palatinate, together with the Electoral Dignity, An. 1227. His death bears date 1253. And his I≈ø≈øue were,
1. Lewis the Severe, born Ap. 13. 1229. of whom more in the next Section.
2. Elizabeth, married after the decea≈øe of the Emperor Conrade the Fourth, her fir≈øt Husband, to Meinhard, Earl of Goritia and Tyrole; decea≈øed 1270.
3. Sophia, the Wife of Albert Count d' Albersberg. And,
4. Henry, born 1235. who had the Lower Bavaria for his Patrimony, and married the Daughter of Bela the Fourth, King of
Hungary, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Three Sons.
1. Otho, his Succe≈ø≈øor in Bavaria, elected al≈øo King of Hungary, in oppo≈øition to Charles Martel, An. 1305. but afterwards taken Pri≈øoner by the Veywode of Tran≈øilvania, and died 1312. having fir≈øt regained his liberty, and leaving I≈ø≈øue an only Son, who was named Henry, and taken off by a ≈øuddain and accidental death.
2. Lewis, decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue, 1296. And,
3. Stephen, Duke of the Lower Bavaria, decea≈øed 1 ‚Ä¢ 11. leaving I≈ø≈øue, 1≈øt. Otho, decea≈øed I≈ø≈øuele≈øs. 2dly. Henry, who begat John; which John took to Wife his Cou≈øin Elizabeth, Daughter to the Emperor Lewis of Bavaria; but dying without I≈ø≈øue, his Father-in-law the Emperor, ≈øeized on the Lower Bavaria, notwith≈øtanding the Preten≈øions and Prote≈øtations of Adolph, Elector Palatine, the nearer Kin≈øman. 3dly, Beatrix, married to Henry Earl of Goritia. 4thly. Elizabeth, given in Marriage to Otho of Au≈øtria, Fifth Son to the Emperor Albert the Fir≈øt. And 5thly, Agnes, who was veiled a Nun.

¬ß. II. We now return to Lewis the Severe, Count and Elector Palatine, who elected Rudolph the Fir≈øt, Emperor; but was afterwards Pro≈øcribed him≈øelf, by Adolph of Na≈ø≈øau, the ≈øucceeding Emperor; yet, upon making his
Innocency appear, was receiv'd again into favour, and ended his days at Heidelberg, An. 1294. This Prince had Three Wives; the fir≈øt of which was Mary, Daughter of Henry Duke of Brabant, beheaded by him, out of Jealou≈øie, Feb. 1. 1256. The ≈øecond, Anne, Daughter of Conrade, Duke of Glogow, decea≈øed 1268. And the third, Mechtilda (or Maud) Daughter to the Emperor Rudolph the Fir≈øt, decea≈øed Decemb. 23. 1304. His I≈ø≈øue by the≈øe Ladies were,
1. Lewis the Second, decea≈øed before his Father, An. 1290. being accidentally, but mortally wounded at a Tournament.
2. Rudolph, born 1274. of whom more in the next Section.
3. Another Lewis, of whom we ≈øhall treat in the 18th. Section, as Author of the Bavarian Line.
4. Anne married to Henry Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe. And,
5. Mechtilda (or Maud) to Otho Duke of Lunenburg.

div.head: Of the Palatine Line in particular.
div.p:
¬ß. III. RUdolph ≈øucceeded his Father Lewis in the Palatinate and Electoral Dignity, and was Author of the Rudolphine Line, whereof mention is made in the Fourth Art. of the In≈øtrument of the Peace of O≈ønaburg. This Prince oppo≈øed him≈øelf to the De≈øigns of the Emperor, Albert the Fir≈øt, which created him much mi≈øchief. Nor cou'd he ever agree with his Brother Lewis, who reduced him in
the end to ≈øuch extremities as forced him to take Refuge in England, where he died in Exile, An. 1319. He had to his fir≈øt Wife, Mechtilda (or Maud) Daughter to the Emperor Adolph of Na≈ø≈øau, decea≈øed 1315. And to his ≈øecond, an Engli≈øh Prince≈øs of the ≈øame name. By the fir≈øt Venture he had I≈ø≈øue that out-liv'd him.

list.item: 1. Adolph the Fir≈øt, born 1300. decea≈øed 1327. of whom more in the next Section.

2. Rudolph the Second, made Elector after his Brother Adolph's decea≈øe; and being reconciled to his Uncle Lewis of Bavaria, the Emperour had the whole Palatinate put into his hands. He departed this Life 1353. leaving I≈ø≈øue by his Wife Anne, Daughter of Otho Duke of Carinthia, only one Daughter of her Mother's name, and afterwards married to the Emperor Charles the Fourth.

3. Rupert the Fir≈øt, who opened the Univer≈øity of Heidelberg, in the Year 1346. and after his Brother Rudolph's decea≈øe, ≈øucceeded in the Electoral Dignity. He made an Expedition 'gain≈øt the Impo≈øtor of Brandenburg, who pretended to be Waldomar, the late decea≈øed Marque≈øs of that Country; in which War Rupert him≈øelf was taken Pri≈øoner by Rudolph Elector of Saxony, but ran≈øomed by the Emperor Charles the Fourth. The day of his death hapned in 1390. and notwith≈øtanding he were twice Married, his fir≈øt Wife being Elizabeth, Counte≈øs of Namur; his ≈øecond Beatrix, Dutche≈øs of
Bruges, yet left he no I≈ø≈øue, except a natural Son named An≈øelm, Knight and Lord of Hemsbach.

div.p: ¬ß. IV. Wherefore we mu≈øt look back to Adolph the Fir≈øt, ≈øurnamed The Simple, who begat

1. Rupert the Second, which Rupert had Wars with the Cities of Weteraw and Al≈øace, in which he defeated their Forces. He likewi≈øe ≈øeverely puni≈øhed ≈øeveral notorious Incendiaries of tho≈øe Times. In 1387. he repaired the Univer≈øity of Heidelberg, and departed this Life 1398. His Prince≈øs was Beatrix, Daughter of Frederick King of Arragon, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Rupert the Third.
2. Anne, married to William Duke of Juliers. And,
3. Elizabeth, to Procopius Marque≈øs of Moravia.

Wence≈ølaus, King of Bohemia, being depo≈øed from the Imperial Dignity, Sept. 1. 1400. Rupert the Third was elected Emperor. He gave Orders for Founding the Cathedral of the Holy Gho≈øt at Heidelberg, in which his Tomb and Epitaph are to be ≈øeen to this day. He likewi≈øe made an Expedition into Italy, but with bad Succe≈øs. His Empre≈øs was Elizabeth, Daughter of Frederick the Sixth, Burgrave of Norimberg, who bore him this following I≈ø≈øue,
1. Rupert the Fourth, who, by a Marriage with Elizabeth, Daughter of John Earl of Sponheim, was the fir≈øt that Intituled
his Family to that County: Neverthele≈øs, he decea≈øed before his Father, and without I≈ø≈øue, at Amberg, An. 1395.
2. Lewis, ≈øurnamed Barbatus (or Long-beard.)
3. John the Fir≈øt, who had Sultzbach in the Upper Palatinate for his Patrimony; but of all his Sons, only Prince Chri≈øtopher liv'd to be of Age; who, in 1439. was Crowned King of Denmark, Sweden, and Norway; partly by Election, and partly in Right of his Mother, who was Si≈øter of King Erick, de≈øcended of the Dukes of Meckleburg; as we have already taken notice of in the fir≈øt Paragraph of the Dani≈øh Family. Neverthele≈øs, this Chri≈øtopher died without I≈ø≈øue, An. 1448. notwith≈øtanding he had taken to Wife, Dorothy, Daughter of John the Alchymi≈øt, Marque≈øs of Brandenburg.
4. Frederick, who liv'd a Batchelor at Amberg, in the Upper Palatinate.
5. Stephen the Fir≈øt, born 1385. of whom we ≈øhall make farther mention in the ≈øeventh Section.
6. John, Canon of Augsburg.
7. Margaret, married to Charles the Bold, Duke of Lorrain.
8. Agnes to Adolph, Duke of Cleves. She died 1404.
9. Elizabeth, married to Frederick the Third of Au≈øtria, decea≈øed 1409. And.
10. Otho, who obtained Mosbach and Newmark in the Upper Palatinate, for his Portion, where he had four Sons that outliv'd him; Otho, who lead a ≈øingle Life;
Rupert the Eighth, Bi≈øhop of Ratisbonne; John, Pre≈øident of the Chapter of Ausburg, And Albert, Bi≈øhop of Strasburg.

¬ß. V. Lewis, ≈øurnamed Barbatus, who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Electoral Dignity, had great Wars with the Turks in Palae≈øtine, as al≈øo with the Bi≈øhop of Mentz, and Marque≈øs of Baden in Germany. He was Pre≈øident of the Council of Con≈øtance; and in the Emperor's name commanded the Sentence there pa≈ø≈øed upon John Hu≈ø≈øe, and Jerom of Prague, to be put in Execution. He likewi≈øe Impri≈øon'd Pope John the Two and Twentieth, depo≈øed by the ≈øaid Council. In his old Age, he began to learn the Latin-Tongue, and departed this Life, An. 1439. being merely worn out with Years, and having fir≈øt lo≈øt his Eye-≈øight. His fir≈øt Wife was Blanche, Daughter of Henry the Fourth King of England. And his ≈øecond, Maud, ‚Äî Daughter of Amadeus, Duke of Savoy, By the Engli≈øh Lady he had I≈ø≈øue an only Son, named,

1. Rupert, ≈øurnamed Anglicanus, decea≈øed before his Father, An. 1426. But by the other,
1. Lewis the Fourth, ≈øurnamed The Mild, his Father's Succe≈ø≈øor, born 1424. In 1444. he had a War with Lewis Dauphin of France; and died five Years after, leaving I≈ø≈øue by Margaret, Daughter of Amadeus, Duke of Savoy, Maud, married to Lewis, Earl of Wirtemburg; and after his decea≈øe to Albert of Au≈øtria; and Philip, who ≈øucceeded his Uncle Frederick in the Electorate,
of whom more in the next Section.
2. Frederick the Fir≈øt, born 1425. who, by rea≈øon of his Nephew Philip's Infancy, obtain'd the Electoral Dignity for Life, provided he ≈øhould never Marry, but adopt his ≈øaid Nephew. This Prince had many Wars during his Regency, in which he generally got the better. The Counts of Lutzel≈øtein in Lorrain, were beat out of their Country by him; and his Cou≈øin-Germain, Prince Lewis of Deux-Ponts, together with the Counts of Leiningen, Bi≈øhop of Spire, and ≈øome others ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed. Moreover, he got the Victory in a Battel Fought again≈øt the united Forces of the Marque≈øs of Baden, Bi≈øhop of Metz, and Earl of Wurtenburg. He had al≈øo many Di≈øputes with the Emperor, Frederick the Third, and would often refu≈øe him Homage. He lived with Clara √† Tettingen, as with a Wife, from whom the Counts of Lowen≈øtein have their de≈øcent. And at la≈øt ended his days at Heidelberg, Dec. 12. 1476.
3. Rupert the Sixth, born 1427. elected Arch-Bi≈øhop of Cologne, 1436. decea≈øed 1479.

¬ß. VI. Return we therefore to Philip the Fir≈øt, ≈øurnamed The Sincere, who grew up under the Tuition and Regency of his Uncle Frederick, after who≈øe decea≈øe he took the Government upon him≈øelf. He created him≈øelf much mi≈øchief, by ≈øupporting his Son Rupert's Title to the Lower Bavaria; in≈øomuch as he
had like to have lo≈øt all his own Dominions on that Account: Neverthele≈øs was at length reconciled to the Emperor, yet died of Grief, Feb. 28. 1508. having ≈øeen him≈øelf the Father ‚Ä¢ f Thirteen Children, by his Wife Margaret, Daughter of Lewis, ≈øurnam'd The Rich, Duke ‚Ä¢ f Bavaria, who≈øe Names were as follow,
1. Lewis the Fifth, born July 2. 1478. who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Electorate, and was a great Lover of Peace and Concord. At the Dyet of Worms he publickly oppo≈øed the Papi≈øts, who looked upon them≈øelves as not obliged to ob≈øerve the ≈øafe Conduct, granted to ≈øuch as ≈øhould come hither on Luther's behalf: Moreover, he ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed the Seditious In≈øurrections of the Country Boors, by force of Arms. In 1532. he obtained the Peace of Religion, which was the fir≈øt that was ever granted tho≈øe of the Reformation. When the Imperial Crown was offered him, he refu≈øed it; and was highly e≈øteem'd and belov'd by the Emperor Charles the Fifth. Whil≈øt he was yet a Papi≈øt, he permitted a free Toleration of Religion to the Prote≈øtants. He departed this Life March 16. 1544. having had to Wife Sibilla, Daughter of Albert the Fourth Duke of Bavaria; but by her no I≈ø≈øue.
2. Philip the Second, born May 7. 1480. Con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Trei≈øing, 1496. of Naumburg, 1512. decea≈øed 1541.
3. Rupert the Tenth, ≈øurnamed The Vertuous, born May 14. 1581. and Elected Bi≈øhop of Frei≈øing, which Bi≈øhoprick he afterwards ≈øurrendred
to his Brother Philip, and married the ≈øole Daughter and Heire≈øs of George the Rich, Duke of Bavaria, which Match gave ri≈øe to a mo≈øt bloody War, 'twixt the Palatine and Bavarian Lines. This Prince departed this Life before his Father, An. 1504. leaving I≈ø≈øue by Elizabeth, Daughter of George Duke of Bavaria afore≈øaid,
1. Otho Henry, born 1502. in the beginning of his Life an unhappy Princes Of all his Mother's Inheritance, he obtained only the Dutchy of Newburg. In 1542. he made publick Profe≈ø≈øion of the Reformed Religion; and ≈øucceeding in the Electorate, at the decea≈øe of his Uncle Frederick the Second, wholly extirpated the Romi≈øh Religion out of all the Palatinate. He was al≈øo Founder of the Library a ‚Ä¢
Heidelburg; and died without I≈ø≈øue, 1559. And,
2. Philip the Third, born 1503. who is 1529. bravely defended Vienna, again≈øt the dreadful A≈ø≈øaults of the Turki≈øh Army, being at that time Governour o ‚Ä¢ the City, where he highly ≈øignalized his Courage. He decea≈øed a Batchellor, 1548.
4. Frederick the Second, ≈øurnamed The Wi≈øe, as al≈øo The Pious, born Dec. 9. 1483. This Prince ≈øpent his Youth in the Court of Philip of Au≈øtria; and was afterwards made‚Äîto Charles the Fifth. He was likewi≈øe pre≈øent at the Election of the ≈øaid
Charles, as Proxy for his Brother Lewis the Elector; and in 1519. ≈øent to him to ≈øignifie his Promotion to the Imperial Throne. After that he was often his Deputy and Vicar in his Ab≈øence. In mo≈øt of the Dyets he was one of the chief Coun≈øellors; and Pre≈øident of that held in 1528. He twice headed the Imperial Armies again≈øt the Turks, and forced Solyman to rai≈øe his Siege from before Vienna. In 1544. he ≈øucceeded his Brother in the Electoral Dignity. In 1546. he made Profe≈ø≈øion of the Prote≈øtant Faith, and began to introduce the ≈øame into his Dominions. Neverthele≈øs he admitted the Book, Intituled, Interim, for fear he might too far incen≈øe the Emperor, Charles the Fifth. He departed this Life in the 73d. Year of his Age, An. 1556. having had to Wife, Dorothy, Daughter of Chri≈øtian the Second, King of Denmark, but by her no I≈ø≈øue.
5. George the Fir≈øt, born Feb. 10. 1486. elected Bi≈øhop of Sponheim, 1513. He began to build the Fortification and Ca≈øtle of Udenheim, ≈øince called Philipsburg; and died 1529.
6. Henry, Bi≈øhop of Worms, born Feb. 15. 1587. decea≈øed 1552. or 1554.
7. John, Bi≈øhop of Ratisbonne, born 1488 decea≈øed 1538.
8. Wolfgang, ≈øurnamed The Wi≈øe, born Oct. 31. 1494. He liv'd at Newmark, where he likewi≈øe died of Old Age, Apr. 2. 1558.
9. Otho Henry, born and dead the ≈øame Year, viz. 1496.
10. Aemilia, the Wife of George the Fir≈øt, Duke of Stetin, decea≈øed 1524.
11. Helen, married to Henry Duke of Meckleburg, decea≈øed 1513.
12. Elizabeth, e≈øpou≈øed by William, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, An. 1498. and after his decea≈øe, by Philip, Marque≈øs of Baden; ≈øhe died 1522. And,
13. Catharine, who was Veiled a Nun.

¬ß. VII. Matters thus far cleared, we now return to Stephen, fifth Son to the Emperor Rupert, of whom we made mention in the fourth Section, Numb. 5. This Prince had the County of Simmeren for his Patrimony; and took to Wife the Lady Anne, the only Daughter of Frederick Count Veldentz, with whom he had that whole County, as al≈øo great part of the County of Sponheim. She likewi≈øe bore him I≈ø≈øue,
1. Frederick, born 1417.
2. Margaret, decea≈øed a Maid, An. 1426.
3. Lewis, of whom more below in the twelfth Section.
4. Rupert the Seventh, Bi≈øhop of Strasburg, decea≈øed Oct. 18. 1478.
5. John the Third, Bi≈øhop of Mun≈øter, afterwards Arch Bi≈øhop of Magdeburg, decea≈øed Nov. 13. 1475.
6. Stephen the Second, Canon of Cologne, decea≈øed 1481. And,
7. Another John Canon of Strasburg.

Of the≈øe Frederick the Elde≈øt, ≈øurnamed Der Hundes Xuecten, obtained the County of Simmeren, and upper part of the County of
Sponheim, by Virtue of his Father's Will, and died 1486. leaving I≈ø≈øue by Margaret, Daughter of Arnold, Duke of Guelderland, the≈øe Five following Princes,
1. John the Sixth, of whom more in the next Section.
2. Rupert the Ninth, Bi≈øhop of Ratisbonne decea≈øed 1507.
3. Stephen the Third, Provo≈øt of the Cathedral at Cologne.
4. William, Canon of Triers. And,
5. Frederick the Second, Canon of Cologne.

¬ß. VIII. John the Sixth ≈øucceeded his Father in the Palatinate of Simmeren; and departed this Life in the Year 1509. having begot on his Wife Joan of Na≈ø≈øau, John the Eighth, and Frederick, Provo≈øt of the Cathedral Church of Strasburg.

John the Elder of the Two ≈øucceeded his Father, and was a very learned Prince; upon which account he was made Pre≈øident of the Imperial Chamber at Spire, by the Emperor Charles the Fifth. He departed this Life, An. 1557. having had Two Wives; the fir≈øt being Beatrix, Daughter of Chri≈øtopher, Marque≈øs of Baden; the other, Mary Jacobaea, Daughter of James Earl of Ettingen. By the fir≈øt Lady he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Elizabeth, married to George Count d' Epach.
2. Sabina, given in Marriage, An. 1544. to Lamoral Count d' Egmont, who was publickly Beheaded by the common Executioner at Bruxels, An. 1568. by the command
of the Duke d' Alva, then Governour of the Netherlands.
3. Frederick the Third, born Feb. 14. 1515. of whom more in the next Section.
4. George, born Feb. 20. 1518. a Prince of great Courage, who ≈øerv'd the Spaniard, again≈øt the French. He was of the Reform'd Religion, and took to Wife Elizabeth, Daughter to William Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, yet died without I≈ø≈øue, May 19. 1569.
5. Richard, who, upon his Brother George's Decea≈øe without I≈ø≈øue, became Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Principality of Simmeren. He was a great Stickler for the Lutheran Confe≈ø≈øion, which was the rea≈øon he was kept from the Manage of Affairs, and Guardian≈øhip of his Nephew Frederick the Elector, during his Minority, who was brought up a Calvini≈øt. He likewi≈øe died, as his Brother George did, without I≈ø≈øue, notwith≈øtanding he was thrice Married, An. 1598.
6. William, decea≈øed an Infant.
7. Helen, the Wife of Philip, Count de Leining.
8. Magdalen, married to Philip, Earl of Hanover.
9. N‚Äî Lady Abbe≈øs of Newburg, born 1516. decea≈øed 1562.
10. Jean, Priore≈øs of Poppart. And,
11. Ottilia. all Veiled Nuns.
12. Mary, and all Veiled Nuns.
13. Catharine. all Veiled Nuns.

¬ß. IX. Frederick the Third, upon the Death of the Elector Otho Henry, (mention'd by us in the ≈øixth Section, Numb. 3.) without I≈ø≈øue, ≈øucceeded him in the Electorate, as next of Blood, An. 1559. This Prince e≈øtabli≈øhed the Reformed Religion in his Dominions, upon which Account he ≈øuffered very much. In 1560 he cau≈øed a Conference to be held at Heidelberg, and Publi≈øhed the Heidelberg Catechi≈øm, three Years after. He was likewi≈øe a vigorous Promoter of the Hugonets Cau≈øe in France; and ≈øent a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the Dutch. His fir≈øt Marriage was with Mary, Daughter of Ca≈øimire, Marque≈øs of Brandenburg, decea≈øed Oct. 21. 1567. After which, he took to Wife the Lady Aemilia, Daughter to Humbert, Earl of Meurs and Nevenaer, Henry Brederode's Widow, who died 1602. as him≈øelf had done ≈øome Years before, viz. 1576. His Children are ≈øaid to be,
1. Albert the Second, born 1538. decea≈øed 1553.
2. Lewis the Sixth, born July 4. 1539. of whom more in the next Section.
3. Elizabeth, born 1540. married to John Frederick, Duke of Saxony, 1558. decea≈øed 1594.
4. Herman Lewis, drowned in France, 1556.
5. John Ca≈øimire, born March 7. 1543. who, by his Wife Elizabeth (as others Anne) Daughter of Augu≈øtus, Elector of Saxony, had an only Daughter, named Dorothy; born 1580. married to John George, Prince of Anhault De≈ø≈øau, 1598 (or 95) decea≈øed 1618. or (1610.)
6. Su≈øanna Dorothy, born Nov. 19. 1544. married to John William, Duke of Saxony, 1560. decea≈øed March 4. 1592.
7. Albert, decea≈øed an Infant, An. 1546.
8. Anne Elizabeth, born 1545. and married in 67. to Philip the Second, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe; and again in 1599. to John Augu≈øtus, Count Palatine in Deux Ponts; ≈øhe died 1609.
9. Charles, decea≈øed in his Infancy, 1552.
10. Cunigunda Jacobaea, born 1556. e≈øpou≈øed to John Count Na≈ø≈øau in Dillenburg; decea≈øed 1586.
11. Chri≈øtopher, born June 13. 1551 ≈øent by his Father to the Wars in Flanders, and there Slain at the Battel of Mockerheiden, 1574.

Lewis the Sixth was his Father's Succe≈ø≈øor, and wholly addicted to Luther's way of Wor≈øhip, as al≈øo a con≈øtant Reader of the Holy Scriptures. Moreover he ≈øub≈øcribed the Book of Concord, being a very Peaceable Prince, never medling with other Mens matters. His fir≈øt Prince≈øs was, Elizabeth, Daughter of Philip, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe; who decea≈øing in 1582. he took to Wife Anne, Daughter of Ezhard, Earl of Ea≈øt-Fri≈øeland. By the fir≈øt Lady he had I≈ø≈øue Eleven Children; whereof only Two were living at his Death, which happened in the Year 1583. namely, Frederick the Fourth, and Mary Anne, born 1561. who was married to Charles Duke of Sudermanland, afterwards King of Sweden, and died 1580.

¬ß. X. Frederick the Fourth was born March 5. 1547. and brought up a Prote≈øtant. In 1606. he built Manheim, and began to fortifie the ≈øame. He likewi≈øe very much enlarged the Univer≈øity of Heidelberg; and took no le≈øs care for the Improvement of the whole Province. His Death bears date, Sept. 9. 1610. His Prince≈øs being Lovi≈øe Juliana, Daughter of William Prince of Orange, and his I≈ø≈øue by her, as followeth;
1. Lovi≈øe Juliana, born June 16. 1594. married to John the Second, Count Palatine of Deux-Ponts, 1612. decea≈øed 1640. (or 1637.)
2. Frederick the Fifth, Prince Elector, born Aug. 16. 1596.
3. Elizabeth Charlotte, born Nov. 7. 1597. married to George William Elector of Brandenburg, 1616. decea≈øed 1657. (or 1660.)
4. Lewis Philip, born Nov. 23. 1602. who being Ship'd in the ≈øame bottom, was obliged to run the ≈øame Ri≈øque with his Brother Frederick. Neverthele≈øs, he had the Palatinate of Simmeren re≈øtored him, by the In≈øtrument of the Feace of O≈øenburg, and died afterwards at Berlin, An. 1654. His Prince≈øs was Mary Eleanor, Daughter of Joachim Frederick, Elector of Brandenburg, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Herman Maurice Francis, born Oct. 1. 1640. in whom the Branch of Simmeren withered, and became extinct, by his dying without I≈ø≈øue, An. 1673. And,
2. Elizabeth Charlotte Mary, born Oct. 24. 1638. and affianced to George Duke of Lignitz: ≈øhe departed this Life, 1664.

Frederick the Fifth ≈øucceeded his Father in the Electorate, and was Elected and Crown'd King of Bohemia al≈øo, in oppo≈øition to Ferdinand the Second, Nov. 4. 1619. but being defeated the Year following by the Emperor's Forces, in a great Battel Fought in a place called the White Hill, not far from Prague, was forced to fly into Holland; whereupon he was forthwith Pro≈øcribed, depo≈øed from his Electoral Dignity, and beat out of all his Dominions, notwith≈øtanding the great di≈øta≈øt ≈øhown thereat by the Electors of Saxony and Brandenburg, and many other Princes. Neverthele≈øs, the greater part of the Palatinate being recovered, after the Battel of Leip≈øick, by Gu≈øtavus Adolphus, King of Sweden; Frederick, after ten Years Exile, came to Frankfort, in the Year 1632. and continued in tho≈øe Parts for ≈øome time: But this was only a Mockery of Fortune; for he died at Mentz, on Nov. 19. in the ≈øame Year, O. S. not many Months after the Death of His Swedi≈øh Maje≈øty, who was Slain at the Battel of Lutz, leaving the Prince≈øs Elizabeth, Daughter of James the Fir≈øt, King of Great Britain, a di≈øcon≈øolate Widow, and by her this following I≈ø≈øue;
1. Frederick Henry, born Jan. 1. 1614. and drowned in Harlem Meer, on the 7th of the ≈øame Month, An. 1629. and the 15th of his Age.
2. Charles Lewis, born Dec. 22/12. 1617. of whom more in the next Section.
3. Elizabeth, born Dec. 26. 1618. ≈øhe was made Lady Abbe≈øs of Hervorden in Germany, being mightily addicted to the Mu≈øes, and ≈øtudy of Philo≈øophy, e≈øpecially Des Cartes's (or the new) and departed this Life on Jan. 8. 1680.
4. Rupert the Eleventh, born Dec. 17. 1619. at Prague in Bohemia, but brought up in Holland. At the Battel of Lemgow, he was taken, and ≈øent Pri≈øoner to the Emperor at Vienna. From whence, being ≈øet at liberty, he came for England; where in 1642. he oppo≈øed with good Succe≈øs, the Rebellious Forces of the Parliament, rai≈øed again≈øt the Government of King Charles the Fir≈øt. In 1650. he left England, and went for Portugal, and from thence into Germany to his Brother. After the Re≈øtauration of Charles the Second, King of England, he returned into that Country; where he was made Admiral, and at length died a Batchellor, on the 19th of Nov. 1682.
5. Maurice, born Dec. 27/17. 1620. Peri≈øhed by Shipwrack in the Atlantick Ocean, An. 1654.
6. Lovi≈øe Hollandina, born 1622. and brought up a Prote≈øtant; but ≈øhe changed her Religion, and went into France, where ≈øhe became Lady Abbe≈øs of Maubui≈øon, and died July 5. 1684.
7. Lewis, born 1623. decea≈øed two Years after.
8. Edward, born Oct. 6. 1624. who ≈øought his Fortunes in France, where, in ≈øhort, he
married Anne Gonzaga, Daughter of Charles Duke of Nevers, turn'd Catholick, and died March 13. 1663. leaving I≈ø≈øue Three Daughters,
1. Mary Lovi≈øe, married to Charles Oths, Count de Solmes, decea≈øed Mar. 11. 1679.
2. Anne, born July 23. 1647. married to Henry Julius de Bourbon, Duke d' Enghien, Dec. 11. 1663. decea≈øed. And,
3. Benedicta Henrietta Philippina, born 1648. and married in 1668. to Frederick Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg. She is now a Widow, and lives at Paris.
9. Henrietta Maria, born 1626. ≈øhe was married to Sigi≈ømund, Prince of Tran≈øilvania, and died Sept. 18. 1651.
10. Philip, born Sept. 16/26. 1627. and Slain at the Battel near St. Stephens, Dec. 15. 1650.
11. Sophia, born Octob. 13. 1630. and married in 1658. to Erne≈øt Augu≈øtus, Bi≈øhop of O≈øenburg, and Duke of Brun≈øwick and Lunenburg.
12. Gu≈øtavus, born Jan. 14. 1632. decea≈øed in the ≈øame Month, 1641. And,
13. Charlotte, decea≈øed an Infant, 1631. but born 1628. and ≈øhould have been mentioned next Prince Philip.
¬ß. XI. We now return to Charles Lewis, who during his Father's Exile, was brought up in Holland, where he made great Proficiency in the Study of Languages and other Sciences.

By the Peace of Prague, there was only an
Allowance ≈øettled on him and his Brethren, ≈øuitable to their Quality; but at length by that of Mun≈øter and O≈øenburg in 1648. He had the Lower Palatinate, and Berg≈øtra≈ø≈øe re≈øtored him, and was con≈øtituted the Eighth Elector, and Chief Trea≈øurer of the Empire. At the ≈øame time was the Univer≈øity of Heidelberg re≈øtored; Liberty of Con≈øcience granted the Prote≈øtants; Mea≈øures taken for re≈øtoring Peace to the Church, and Manheim repaired. Upon the Decea≈øe of the Emperor Ferdinand the Third, there was a Di≈øpute betwixt him and the Elector of Bavaria, touching their right to the Vicar≈øhip of the Empire, during the Inter-regnum: He had al≈øo ≈øeveral Conte≈øts for the Wildtangiate. In 1650. he took to Wife Charlotte, Daughter of William the Fifth, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, who afterwards was parted from him, and returned home, upon ≈øome Di≈øcontents that aro≈øe between 'em. Neverthele≈øs, he had I≈ø≈øue by her, Charlotte Elizabeth, born 1652. and married in 71. to Philip Duke of Orleans, the pre≈øent French King's only Brother; and Charles, born March 31. 1651. who indeed ≈øucceeded him, but out-liv'd him only five Years, decea≈øing May 16. 1685. and that without I≈ø≈øue; notwith≈øtanding he had taken to Wife, Wilhelmina Erne≈øtina Daughter of Frederick the Third, late King of Denmark, and Si≈øter to Chri≈øtian the Fifth, the pre≈øent King. Moreover, 'tis to be noted of Prince Charles Lewis the Father, that be≈øides the Prince≈øs of He≈ø≈øe, his lawful Wife, he ≈øuper-induced another, who≈øe name was Lovi≈øe Degenfeld, by whom he had this I≈ø≈øue living at his Death.

list.item: 1. Charles Lewis, the Rhinegrave, born 1658.
2. Charlotte, born 1659. and married to Meinhard Count Schomberg, 1683.
3. Lovi≈øe, born Jan. 15. 1661.
4. Aemilia Elizabeth, born March 22. 1663.
5. Charles Edward, born May 9. 1668.
6. Charles Maurice, Dec. 30. 1670.
7. Charles Augu≈øte, Oct. 9. 1672. And,
8. Charles Ca≈øimire, Apr. 22. 1675.

div.p: ¬ß. XII. 'Tis now time that Lewis, ≈øurnamed The Black, mentioned by us in the ≈øeventh Section, Numb. 3. be brought once more on the Stage. In the divi≈øion of the Hereditary Provinces, 'twixt him and his Brother Frederick, he obtain'd the Dutchy of Deux-Ponts, and County of Veldentz, for his Patrimony, wherein he was ≈øucceeded at his death, An. 1489. by his Son Alexander, who marrying the Lady Margaret, Daughter of Crato Earl of Hohenloh, had I≈ø≈øue Lewis the Second, born 1502. George, Canon of Cologne and Triers, and Rupert, who became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Counties of Lautereck and Veldentz, by the grant of his Nephew Wolfgang of Newburg; and was ≈øucceeded in the ≈øame by his Son George John, who, by the donation of his Kin≈øman Otho Henry, the Elector, became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the County of Lutzel≈øtein al≈øo; and departed this Life 1592. leaving I≈ø≈øue by Anne Mary, Daughter of Gu≈øtavus King of Sweden, as followeth.

list.item: 1. George Gu≈øtavus, born Feb. 6. 1564.
2. Anne Margaret, married to Richard Count Palatine in Simmeren, An. 1591.
3. Ur≈øula, born 1573. married to Lewis, Duke of Wurtenburg, of the Line of Mompelgart, 1585. decea≈øed 1636.
4. John Augu≈øtus, born 1575. decea≈øed without I≈ø≈øue, Sept. 18. 1611.
5. Lewis Philip, born 1577. and Slain at Heidelberg, by accident in a Tournament, An. 1601.
6. Joan Elizabeth, born 1579. decea≈øed 1599.
7. George John, born 1586. who≈øe Wife was the Lady ‚Äî Daughter of Otho Henry Count Palatine in Sultzbach, by whom he had four Children; but none of them out-liv'd him.

div.p:
Wherefore George Gu≈øtavus, who departed this Life 1634. was the only Propagator of the Branch of Veldentz, having had by his Wife Mary Elizabeth, Daughter of John the Fir≈øt, Count Palatine of Deux-Ponts, this following I≈ø≈øue; namely,
1. Anne Magdalen, born 1602. and married to Henry Duke of Mun≈øterberg: ≈øhe died, 1630.
2. John Frederick, Colonel of the Swedi≈øh Regiment, decea≈øed 1632.
3. Charles Lewis, who likewi≈øe ≈øerv'd under His Swedi≈øh Maje≈øty, and died of his Wounds at Wolmer≈øtadt, July 17. 1631.
4. Magdalen Sophia, born Nov. 24. 1622. decea≈øed 1631.
5. Mary Sibilla, who was an Abbe≈øs, and died 1649.
6. Leopold Lewis, born Feb. 1. 1625. By the Peace of O≈øenbrug, he recovered the County
of Veldentz; and in 1654. he became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of that of Lutzel≈øtein al≈øo, by right of Inheritance. Neverthele≈øs, in the la≈øt French War, he was beat out of all, and has ever ≈øince liv'd in Exile. His Children, by the Prince≈øs Agatha Chri≈øtina, Daughter to Philip Wolfgang, Count of Hanaw, are,
1. Anne Sophia, born 1650.
2. Gu≈øtavus Philip, born 1651. decea≈øed 1679.
3. Elizabeth Joan, born 1653. and married to John, Rhinegrave in Mortchingen.
4. Chri≈øtina, born 1654. decea≈øed the Year following.
5. Chri≈øtian Lewis, born 1656. decea≈øed 1658.
6. Dorothy, born 1658.
7. Leopold Lewis, 1659. decea≈øed 1660.
8. Charles George, born May 27. 1660. and Slain at the Storming of Buda, 1686.
9. Agatha Eleanor, born 1662. decea≈øed 1664. And,
10. Augu≈øtus Leopold, born 1663. and Slain at the Siege of Mentz, 1689.

¬ß. XIII. We mu≈øt now look back to Lewis the Second, of whom we made mention in the beginning of the la≈øt Section. He ≈øucceeded his Father Lewis the Black, and had the Dutchy of Dexu Ponts ≈øettled on him; as al≈øo the Counties of Veldentz and Sponheim; out of all which Provinces he totally extirpated the Romi≈øh Religion, and embraced Luther's Faith. He departed this Life in the Year 1532. and was
≈øucceeded by his Son Wolfgang, born 1526. This Wolfgang had Newburg, on the Danube, and Sultzbach, afterwards given him by his Kin≈øman Otho Henry the Elector: Whereupon he made over the Counties of Veldentz and Lautereck to his Uncle Rupert. Afterwards he order'd by his Will, that his Po≈øterity ≈øhould Branch them≈øelves into two Lines, viz. Deux-Ponts and Newburg; and that in both, the Right to Succe≈ø≈øion by Birth-right ≈øhould be ob≈øerv'd: to Newburg he ≈øubjected Sultzbach, as Birkenfeld to Deux-Ponts. His Death fell in the Year 1569. at which time he had Four Sons ≈øurviving by his Wife the Prince≈øs Anne, Daughter of Philip the Stout, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, who≈øe names were, Philip Lewis, born Oct. 1. 1547. John the Fir≈øt, born May 18. 1550. Otho Henry, July 22. 1556. decea≈øed 1604. and Charles, Propagator of the Branch of Birkenfeld, Sept. 4. 1560.

div.head: Of the Line of Newburg.
div.p:
¬ß. XIV. PHilip Lewis, in whom this Line began, was a Prince famous for his great Prudence, in the Government of his Family, as al≈øo for his Zeal to Religion. He departed this Life in the Year 1614. leaving I≈ø≈øue by Anne, Daughter of William Duke of Cleve,
1. Anne Mary, born Aug. 12. 1575. married to Frederick William, the fir≈øt Duke of Sax-Altenburg, decea≈øed Feb. 1. 1643.
2. Dorothy Sabina, born 1576. decea≈øed 1598.
3. Wolfgang William, born Oct. 28. or 29. 1587.
4. Otho Henry, born 1580. decea≈øed 1587. or (1598.)
5. Augu≈øtus, Author of the Branch. of Sultzbach, born Oct. 2. 1582. of whom, and his Po≈øterity, we ≈øhall ≈øay more in the next Section, when we come to treat of that Branch.
6. Aemilia Hedewig, born 1584. decea≈øed 1607. And,
7. John Frederick, born Aug. 23. 1587. decea≈øed 1647. His Wife was Sophia Agnes, Daughter of Lewis, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe-Darm≈øtadt, by whom he had Six Children, yet not one of them ≈øurvived him.

Wolfgang William, who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Dutchy of Newburg, An. 1614. turned Papi≈øt the ≈øame Year, and by that means was very unea≈øie to his Mother and Brethren. He was embroiled in the Low-Country Wars for the Succe≈ø≈øion to the Dutchy of Juliers, and departed this Life 1653. having had three Wives; the fir≈øt being Magdalen, Daughter of William Duke of Bavaria, decea≈øed 1628. The ≈øecond, Catharine Charlotte, Daughter of John the Second, Dake of Deux Ponts, decea≈øed March 21. 1651. and the third Mary Frances, Daughter of Francis Egon, Earl of Fur≈øtenburg, who died the ≈øame Yeat ≈øhe was married, viz. May 7. 1652. By the fir≈øt of the≈øe Ladies he was Father of Philip William, the pre≈øent Duke, born Nov. 24. 1615. who ≈øucceeded him at his Death, An. 1643. In 1666. the difference 'twixt him and the Elector of Brandenburg,
touching their Right of Succe≈ø≈øion to the Dutchies of Cleves and Juliers, was fairly accommodated, after ≈øeveral ≈øharp Di≈øputes, which at length ended in Blows. After the decea≈øe of Charles, Elector Palatine, which hapned (as hath already been ≈øaid) in 1685. He became po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Electorate, by Virtue of the In≈øtrument of the Peace of O≈øenburg, Art. 5. Neverthele≈øs, he has been ≈øince thrown Out, contrary to all Law and Equity, by the French King. An. 1688. And altho' he had recovered many Places in It, in the Year 1689. by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Confederates; yet he continues as yet at Newburg. In 1642. he took to Wife the Prince≈øs Anne Catharine Con≈øtance, Daughter of Sigi≈ømund the third King of Poland. After who≈øe decea≈øe, An. 1651. he mo≈øt happily contracted him≈øelf, a ≈øecond time, in the Year 1653. to the Prince≈øs Elizabeth Amalia, Daughter of George Prince of He≈ø≈øe-Darm≈øtadt, his pre≈øent Dutche≈øs, by whom he is Father of a fair Race of Princes; their Names as follow,
1. Eleanor Magdalen There≈øia, born at Du≈ø≈øeldorp, Jan. 6. 1655. married Jan. 6. 1677. (or Dec. 14. 1676.) at Pa≈ø≈øau, to the pre≈øent Emperor, Leopold the Fir≈øt.
2. Mary Adelheid Anne, born Jan. 6. 1656. decea≈øed Dec. 23. in the Year following,
3. Sophia Elizabeth, born 1657. decea≈øed 1658.
4. John William Jo≈øeph, Prince Hereditary, born at Du≈ø≈øeldorp, Ap. 19. 1658. and married at New≈øtadt in Au≈øtria, on Oct. 25. New-Stile, 1678. to the Prince≈øs Mary
Anne Jo≈øeph, Daughter of the Emperor Ferdinand the Third, by Eleanor of Mantua his third Wife. In 1683, ≈øhe was brought to Bed of a Boy, but Still born. In 1686. ≈øhe Mi≈øcarried a ≈øecond time, after which ≈øhe never had her Health well, but died within three Years after at Vienne, viz. Ap. 17/7. 1689.
5. George Wolfgang, born 1659. and de≈øigned for Bi≈øhop of Bre≈ølaw, but died June 3. 1683.
6. Lewis Anthony, Grand Ma≈øter of the Teutonick Order, born at Du≈ø≈øeldorp, July 9. 1660.
7. Charles Philip, born Nov. 4. 1661. and married at Berlin, on July 24. 1688. to Lovi≈øe Charlotte de Ratzeville, Lewis Marque≈øs of Brandenburg's Widow.
8. Alexander Sigi≈ømund, Dean of Augsburg, and Pre≈øident of the Chapter of Con≈øtance, born at Newburg, Ap. 16. 1663.
9. Francis Lewis, born at Newburg, July 24. 1664. and elected Bi≈øhop of Bre≈ølaw, Jan. 30. 1683.
10. Frederick William, born at Du≈ø≈øeldorp, July 20. 1665.
11. Mary Sophia Elizabeth, born Aug. 6. 1666. and married in 1687. to Peter King of Portugal.
12. Mary Anne, born at Du≈ø≈øeldorp, Oct. 28. 1667. and affianced to Charles the Second, King of Spain, Aug. 28. 1689, to which Prince ≈øhe is now going to be ≈øent.
13. Philip William Augu≈øtus, born Nov. 18. 1668.
14. Dorothy Sophia, July 12. 1670.
15. Hedewig Elizabeth Amalia, July 18. 1673
16. John, decea≈øed, 1675.
17. Leopoldina Eleanor Sophia, born May 27. 1679.

div.head: Of the Branch of Sultzbach.
div.p:
¬ß. XV. 'TIs now time that Augu≈øtus, Propagator of this Branch, again appear; having been already mention'd by us, in the beginning of the la≈øt Section, Numb. 5. His Wife was Hedewig, Daughter of John Adolph, Duke of Hol≈øtein, who bore him,
1. Anne Sophia, married to Joachim Erne≈øte, Count Ettingen; decea≈øed 1675.
2. Chri≈øtian Augu≈øtus, born July 16. 1622. a Prince of as many and as great, both natural and acquired Accompli≈øhments, as humane Nature is capable of. His Prince≈øs was, Amalia of Na≈ø≈øau, who departed this Life 1669. having born him I≈ø≈øue, as followeth;
1. Hedewig Augu≈øta, born 1650. married to Julius Francis, Duke of Sax-Lawenburg; decea≈øed 1681.
2. Amalia Sophia, a Profe≈ø≈øed Nun, born 1651.
3. Julianus Augu≈øtus, born 1654. decea≈øed 1657.
4. Chri≈øtian Ferdinand, born 1656. decea≈øed 1658. And,
5. Theodore, born Feb. 14. 1659. the Joy and Hopes of his aged Parent.
3. Adolph Frederick, decea≈øe 1624.
4. Augu≈øta Sophia, born 1624. ≈øhe was married to Wence≈ølaus, Duke de Lobkowitz, and died 1682.
5. John Lewis, decea≈øed 1649. And,
6. Philip, born Jan. 19. 1630. who≈øe Courage and Conduct in Military Affairs, is ≈øufficiently known to all Europe. He has hitherto lived a Batchellor.

div.head: Of the Line of Deux-Ponts.
div.p: ¬ß. XVI. PRince John, ≈øecond Son of Wolfgang, Duke of Newburg and Deux Ponts, of whom we ≈øpoke in the thirteenth Section, was Author of the new Line of Deux-Ponts; his Wife being Magdalen, Daughter of William Duke of Cleve, Juliers and Mons, by whom he had ≈øeven Children; which we ≈øhall ≈øet down in the following Order.

list.item: 1. Lewis William, born 1580. decea≈øed 1581.
2. Mary Elizabeth, born 1581. married to George Gu≈øtavus, Count Palatine of Veldentz and Lautereck; decea≈øed 1637.
3. Anne Jacobea, born 1582. decea≈øed the Year following.
4. Anne Magdalen, decea≈øed in her Infancy.
5. John the Second, born 1584. of whom again a little below.

6. Frederick Ca≈øimire, born 1585. who≈øe u≈øual Re≈øidence was at Landsberg; where he left an only Son, ≈øurviving at his death, which happened in 1645. born him by his Wife, the Prince≈øs Amalia, Daughter to William Prince of Orange, An. 1619. and named,

div.p:
1. Frederick; which Frederick ≈øucceeded in 1661. by Right of Inheritance to the Dutchy of Deux-Ponts, upon the decea≈øe of his Cou≈øin Frederick, without I≈ø≈øue Male, as you will ≈øee below. Neverthele≈øs he lo≈øt it again in the la≈øt French War; and departed this Life April 1. 1681. leaving only two Daughters, notwith≈øtanding the numerous I≈ø≈øue, he had born him, by his Wife the Prince≈øs Juliana Magdalen of Deux-Ponts, his Cou≈øin-Germain. Their names are,
1. Charlotte Amalia, born 1653. and affianced to John Philip, Count I≈øenburg: And,
2. Elizabeth Chri≈øtina, born 1656. and married in 1678. to Emico Count de Leiningen.
7. John Ca≈øimire, born 1589. of whom more below.

We now return to John the Second, who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Dutchy of Deux-Ponts: This Prince obtained of the Emperor a Power to Sit and Vote in the Diets of the Empire; and dyed in the Year 1635. having had to his fir≈øt Wife, Catharine, Daughter of Renatus Count Roven, decea≈øed 1607. and by her a Daughter, named Magdalen Catharine, who was married to Chri≈øtian the Fir≈øt of Birckenfeldt, and died 1648. His ≈øecond Dutche≈øs was Lovi≈øe Juliana; Daughter of Frederick the Fourth, Elector Palatine; decea≈øed 1640. or 1637. by which la≈øt Lady he had I≈ø≈øue, as followeth,
1. Elizabeth Lovi≈øe, Lady Abbe≈øs of Hervorden, born 1613.
2. Frederick, born Ap. 5. 1614. decea≈øed 1661. His Prince≈øs was Anne Juliana of Na≈ø≈øan, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue only Daughters; namely,
1. Elizabeth, born 1642. married to Victor Amadeus, Prince of Anhult, 1667. decea≈øed Ap. 17. 1677.
2. Sophia Amalia, born 1646. and married in 1678. to Sigfrid Count de Hobenl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .
3. Charlotte Frederica, born 1653. and e≈øpou≈øed to William Lewis Count Wherefore Frederick dying without I≈ø≈øue Male, the Succe≈ø≈øion to the Dutchy of Deux-Ponts, fell to his Con≈øin-Germain, Frederick of Landsberg, mentioned by us a little above.
3. Catharine Charlotte, born 1615. married to Wolfgang William, Duke of Newburg, 1631. decea≈øed March 20. or 21. 1651.
4. Anne Sibilla, born 1617. decea≈øed 1641.
5. John Lewis, born 1619. decea≈øed 1647.
6. Juliana Magdalen, born 1621. affianced to Frederick Lewis Count Palatine in Landsbery, in 1644. decea≈øed Marchs 5. 1672
7. Mary Aemilia, born 1622. decea≈øed 1641.

Now follows John Ca≈øimire, younge≈øt Son of Duke John the Fir≈øt, who Travelled into Sweden; where he performed many notable Services for Charles the Ninth, King of that Country, both again≈øt the Poles and Denes. In 1615. he married the Prince≈øs Catharine, Daughter of the ≈øaid King; and died 1652. leaving I≈ø≈øue,
1. Chri≈øtina Magdalen, born 1616. married to Frederick the Third, Marque≈øs of Baden Durlach, decea≈øed 1662.
2. Charles Gu≈øtavus, born Nov. 8. 1622. to whom Queen Chri≈øtina gave up the whole Kingdom of Sweden, with all its Claims and Dependencies. His Queen was Hedewig Eleanor, Daughter of Frederick, Duke of Sle≈øwick, now a Widow; by whom he had I≈ø≈øue Charles the Eleventh, the pre≈øent King; of whom and his I≈ø≈øue, ≈øee more above in the Swedi≈øh Family.
3. Mary Euphro≈øyna, born Feb. 4. 1625. e≈øpou≈øed by Magnus Gabriel, Count de la Gardie, Arch-Drozet of Sweden; decea≈øed in Decemb. 1687.
4. Eleanor Catharine, the late Relict of Frederick, Landtgrave of He≈ø≈øe, in E≈øchwegen; born May 17. 1626. decea≈øed 16‚Äî.
5. Adolph John, born Oct. 11. 1629. decea≈øed Oct. 14. 1689. po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a very large E≈øtate in Sweden, where he married two Wives; the fir≈øt being Elizabeth Beata, Daughter of Peter Brahe, Earl of Wi≈øenburg; decea≈øed 1653. The other Elizabeth, Daughter of Nicholas Brahe, Erick, Count Oxen≈øtern, late Lord Chancellor of Sweden's Widow, decea≈øed al≈øo la≈øt March, 1689. His Children now living, are two Sons, and as many Daughters; namely, Adolph John, born Aug. 13. 1666. Gu≈øtavus Samuel, born Ap. 2. 1670. Catharine, An. 1661. And Mary Elizabeth, 1663.

div.head: Of the Branch of Birckenfeld.
div.p:
¬ß. XVII. WE are now come to mention Charles, younge≈øt Son of Wolfgang, Duke of Newburg and Deux-Ponts, who propagated the Branch of Birckenfeld, by a Marriage with the Prince≈øs Dorothy of Lunenburg, of the Line of Zell, who bore him a Daughter, named Sophia, married to Crato, Earl of Hohenloh; decea≈øed Nov. 6. 1676. And Three Sons,
1. George William.
2. Chri≈øtian. And,
3. Frederick, born 1594. decea≈øed a Bachellor, 1626.

In the I≈ø≈øue of the Two fir≈øt, the Branch of Birckenfeld, ≈øubdivided it ≈øelf into two le≈ø≈øer Branches; that of Birckenfeld, properly ≈øo called, and that of Bi≈øchweiler. The fir≈øt began in George William, born 1593. who had the Territory of Birckenfeld for his Portion, and took the Lady Dorothy of Solms to his fir≈øt Wife, who dying in the Year 1625. he was re-married to the Rhinegrave Juliana, from whom he was afterwards divorced; and thereupon e≈øpou≈øed the Lady Anne Elizabeth of Ettingen, his third and la≈øt Wife. His Death bears date, 1669. And his Children, by the fir≈øt Venture, were,
1. Anne Sophia, born Ap. 2. 1619. decea≈øed 1680. ≈øhe was Lady Abbe≈øs of Quedlingburg.
2. Juliana, and, decea≈øed both in their Infancy.
3. Elizabeth, decea≈øed both in their Infancy.
4. Charles Otho, a Valiant Champion of the Go≈øpels; decea≈øed 1672. who≈øe Wife was Hedewig, Crato Count Holenloh's Daughter, by whom he had I≈ø≈øue; Charles William, decea≈øed an Infant, 1660. Charlotte Sophia Elizabeth, born 1661. And Hedewig Eleanor Dorothy, in 1663.
5. Mary Magdalen, born 1622. and married to Anthony Gunther, Count Swartzburg, An. 1644.

Return we now to Chri≈øtian of Bi≈øchweiler, born 1598. decea≈øed Aug. 10. 1654. who≈øe two Wives were Magdalen Catharine, Daughter of John the Second, Duke of Deux Ponts, and Mary Joan of Helfen≈øtein. By the fir≈øt of which he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. Dorothy Catharine, born July 3. 1634. and married to John Lewis Count Na≈ø≈øau in Otweiler.
2. Lovi≈øe Sophia, born 1635. as yet unmarried.
3. Chri≈øtian the Second, born June 22. 1637. In 1667. he married the Lady Catharine Agatha (Daughter of John James the la≈øt Earl of Rappol≈øtein) decea≈øed 1683. by whom he has I≈ø≈øue now living, Magdalen Claudia, born 1668. Charlotte Wilhelmina, 1672. And Chri≈øtian the Third, Nov. 7. 1674.
4. John Charles, born Oct. 17. 1638. a Prince of great Experience in Military Affairs. In 1685. he took to Wife Sophia Amalia, Daughter of Frederick Duke of Deux-Ponts, Sigfrid Count Hohenloh's Widow, brought to Bed of a Daughter, Feb. 1. 1686.
5. Anne Magdalen, born 1640. and married to John Rheinhard, Earl of Han ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lt, Oct. 18. 1659.

div.head: Of the Bavarian Line.
div.p:
¬ß. XVIII. IT has already been ob≈øerved in the ≈øecond Section of this Chapter, that Lewis the Third was third Son of Elector Lewis the Fir≈øt. He was Born 1277. carefully brought up by his Mother at Vienna in Au≈øtria, had the Upper Bavaria for his Patrimony, and was elected Emperor 1314. After the decea≈øe of his Cou≈øin John, Duke of the Lower Bavaria, who had married his Daughter, he entered on the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the greate≈øt part of his Inheritance. He likewi≈øe ≈øeized on the Electorate of Brandenburg, upon the death of Woldemar, Marque≈øs thereof, be≈øtowing the ≈øame on his own Son Lewis. Moreover, he had War with Frederick the Fair; Arch-Duke of Au≈øtria, whom he took Pri≈øoner in the end, An. 1324. and was likewi≈øe at variance with the Pope, who plagued him very much. In 1347. he died of an Apoplexy, occa≈øioned by his Bodies being grievou≈øly brui≈øed, by a fall from his Hor≈øe, as he was hunting the Bear; having had to his fir≈øt Wife, the Lady Beatrix of Gloga ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; and William, Earl of Holland and Zealand's Daughter to his Second. His I≈ø≈øue by the fir≈øt were,
1. Lewis the Fourth, who had the Marqui≈øate of Brandenburg given him by his Father, An. 1319. which he defended, again≈øt
the pretended Woldemar, and his adherents. He decea≈øed in the Year 1361. having had to Wife Margaret Maulta≈øchen, Daughter of Henry Duke of Carinthia and Stiria, Earl of Tirole, &c. And by her an only Son, named,
1. Mainhard, who followed his Father by a too ha≈øty Fate, An. 1363.
2. Mechtildis (or Maud) married to Frederick, Landtgrave of Thuringe, and Marque≈øs of Mi≈ønia; decea≈øed 1346.
3. Beatrix, affianced to Charles Martel, King of Hangary; decea≈øed 1315.
4. Stephen, ≈øurnamed Fibularus, of whom in the next Section, as Pre≈øerver of the Line.
5. Anne (or as others, Agnes.) decea≈øed 1353.

div.head: Children of the Emperor Lewis by his ≈øecond Wife.

list.item: 1. Lewis, ≈øurnamed The Roman, who had the Marck a≈ø≈øigned him by his Brother Lewis; but died without I≈ø≈øue 1366. (or 69.)
2. William, who had the Government of Holland and Zealand, in the Netherlands, ≈øettled on him by his Mother; but fell di≈øtracted, and died ≈øo, 1377.
3. Anne, affianced to Gunther, Count Swartzburg.

4. Elizabeth, remarried, after the decea≈øe of her fir≈øt Husband, John Duke of the Lower Bavaria, to Ulrick Count Wirtenberg; and again, after his decea≈øe, to
Scaliger, Duke of Verona.
5. Otho Henry, his Brother's Succe≈ø≈øor in the Marck; which neverthele≈øs he Sold for 200000 Florins to Wence≈ølaus, Son to the Emperor Charles the Fourth, and died 1379.

6. Albert the Fir≈øt, who ≈øucceeded his Brother William in the Government of Holland and Zealand, and left the ≈øame to his Son, William the Second. He departed this Life 1404. (or according to Others, 1405.) having had Margaret, Daughter of Lewis Duke of Brieg in Sile≈øia to his fir≈øt Wife; and another Margaret, Daughter of Adolph, Duke of Cleve, to his ≈øecond. His I≈ø≈øue by the≈øe Ladies, were,
1. William the Second, who ≈øucceeded his Father in the Counties of Holland, Zealand, and Haynalt; and died 1417 having had Mary, Daughter of Charles the Fifth King of France to his fir≈øt Wife; and, after her decea≈øe, Margaret, Daughter of Philip the Bold, Duke of Burgundy; by which la≈øt he had I≈ø≈øue, an only Daughter, named Jaqueline; married to the Dauphin of France, and after his untimely Death, to John of Burgundy, Duke of Brabant; by which Match the Provinces afore≈øaid were pa≈ø≈øed over to the Hou≈øe of Burgundy. This Lady Jaqueline, after many turns of Fortune, departed this Life Oct. 8. 1436.
2. Albert the Second, who liv'd at Stranbingen in Bavaria, where he likewi≈øe decea≈øed, An. 1399.
3. John, elected Bi≈øhop of Liege, An. 1400. with the Inhabitants of which City he had afterwards much ado. Neverthele≈øs, upon his Brother's decea≈øe, he quitted both Orders and Bi≈øhoprick, taking to Wife Elizabeth of Lutzelburg, yet departed this Life without I≈ø≈øue, An. 1424. but not without ≈øu≈øpicion of Poy≈øon.
4. Margaret, married to John the Bold, Duke of Burgundy, An. 1385. decea≈øed 1426.
5. Joan, affianced to Albert the Fourth of Au≈øtria, decea≈øed 1390.
6. Catharine, to Edward Duke of Guelderland. And,
7. Anne, to Wence≈ølaus afterwards Emperor, An. 1377. ≈øhe died 1388.

div.p:
¬ß. XIX. Return we therefore to Stephen, in who≈øe I≈ø≈øue this Line was continued: He departed this Life 1375. having had Elizabeth, Daughter of Lewis King of Sicily and Hungary, to his fir≈øt Wife; and another Elizabeth, Daughter of John the Second, Burgrave of Norimberg, to his Second. His I≈ø≈øue, by the fir≈øt Venture, were,
1. Stephen the Second, who had Ingol≈øtadt, and the Lands belonging thereunto for his Patrimony; a Prince renown'd for his Piety and Courage, and very dear to his Subjects on that account. He departed this Life in the Year 1413. having been twice married, fir≈øt to Thaddaea the Vice-Count of Milan's Daughter; and after
her decea≈øe, to Margaret, Daughter of Adolph, Duke of Cleves: By the fir≈øt he had I≈ø≈øue,
1. I≈øabel, married to Charles the Sixth, King of France, 1385. decea≈øed 1435.
2. John, Bi≈øhop of Ratisbonn ‚Ä¢ , decea≈øed 1409.
3. Lewis Barbatus (or Long-beard) a Prince of an unea≈øie Temper; impatient either of an Equal or Superior. He had Wars with his Son Lewis the Crooked, whom he would have di≈øinherited, in favour of his natural Son; in which he was taken Captive by his Son, and Impri≈øoned at Newburg.
